speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise this morning with some reluctance. I do not believe that the behaviour of a legislative committee chair has been brought to the attention of the House before.
I want to say that the hon. member for Ontario, who is the chair of the legislative committee for Bill C-91 looking into the Patent Act is, of course, the Speaker's delegate appointed by the Speaker, was not elected, and reports through the Speaker to the House.
This chair is charged with maintaining the same role in committee as the Speaker is in the House. He must remain impartial. This is important. He must sustain the will of the majority while safeguarding the rights of the minority.
Very briefly I want to refer to Beauchesne's Parliamentary Rules and Forms, sixth edition, section 168, where it
says:
Confidence in the impartiality of the Speaker is an indispensable condition of the successful working of procedure, and many conventions exist which have as their object, not only to ensure the impartiality of the Speaker but also to ensure that there is a general recognition of the Speaker's impartiality.
It is with a heavy heart that I have to report to the House that last night, and also this morning, the chair of the legislative committee spoke in a very partisan way to the media about the proceedings of the legislative committee regarding Bill C-91.
The fact that he spoke to the media is perhaps open to some question but that he made a number of comments-I will not read them out to the House this morning-that were very partisan, very critical of certain
members and very critical of the opposition's role in the proceedings, is not carrying on the tradition that we have come to know and respect in this House through you, Mr. Speaker.
I ask if you would review this situation. It is most unacceptable. Because of the now common use of time allocation and closure, much of the important debate on bills goes on in the various legislative committees since it does not occur in the House.
Therefore to maintain the impartiality of the chair, as you do in this House, Mr. Speaker, is perhaps even more critical than ever considering the need for open debate and the chair ensuring not only the will of the majority but the fact that the role of the opposition is recognized.
I wonder about the appropriateness of the member for Ontario continuing on in that role because of this breach of impartiality.
I would ask that in order to enable that committee to proceed as a legislative committee ought to proceed, you look into this matter at your earliest convenience.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I acknowledge that my friend from Kamloops said this was a very unusual thing to be doing. He is seeking to do in the House what ought to remain within the committee.
I do not think it is appropriate to comment on the substance of what he is alleging. What is before us is whether it is appropriate for you to deal with the conduct of a legislative committee. As the House is well aware the committee has been striving to deal with this legislation for a number of days now and is encountering what I can only describe as filibustering from the other side.
To come to the heart of the matter, the problem is not time allocation. The problem is the committee dealing with the issue of the bill before it. On the matter that my hon. friend has raised I would just draw his attention to Beauchesne's sixth edition, citation 760(3):

Point of Order
The Speaker has ruled on many occasions that it is not competent
for the Speaker to exercise procedural control over the committees.
Committees are and must remain masters of their own procedure.
The matter begins and ends there.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: I may not need very much more advice on this matter, but I will hear from the hon. member for Cape Breton-East Richmond.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me confirm what my colleague from the New Democratic Party has said concerning the behaviour of this particular committee chairperson.
The parliamentary secretaiy opposite has made a timely intervention but the only appeal that we have is to you, Mr. Speaker, who presides over this Chamber. As indicated previously, this particular chairperson is a delegate of yourself.
I hope you will reflect on the comments which have been made with regard to this particular chairperson. The activities that are taking place in the committee are highly unusual in view of the large number of witnesses which have been requested.
I do not want to get into a substantive debate on that particular point, but I think the Chair should make a careful examination as to exactly what is taking place in this particular instance.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext:
The hon. member for Kamloops has raised a matter rising out of a legislative committee and he has cited to the House some appropriate procedural law with respect to the role of the Speaker. He has reminded the House that particularly the chairman, who is the subject of this intervention is, of course, appointed by the Chair.
However the hon. member for Kamloops has restrained himself, and I think properly so, from getting into substantial debate here on the floor of the House as to what was said. The hon. member for Cape Breton-East Richmond has also constrained himself and I appreciate that. I thank him for not getting into the substance of the debate.
The hon. parliamentary secretary has pointed out that generally speaking the Chair does not interfere with the
affairs of a committee. I understand because I have been apprised of this and I thank the hon. member for Kamloops for saying that the matter has been at least partially raised in committee this morning.
The proper course is for the committee to deal with it further if the committee so wishes. I would hope that the matter would be satisfactorily resolved there. At least for now that is where I am going to leave it.

speakerposition: Chief Government Whip; Whip of the Progressive Conservative Party
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, it is normal practice in the Chamber that when a member's behaviour is brought up on the floor of the House, that member be notified and generally would be present. I think the record should show that the member in question is not present and has not had an opportunity to make comment, if that member feels aggrieved in some way.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: That certainly is the usual custom and I thank the hon. member for reminding the House of it. However, in view of what has been said and in view of my response, that is where the matter should be left at the moment.

Mr. Speaker, I do not want to pursue this matter but I want to seek clarification.
Since the matter was raised earlier today in the committee at the appropriate place, and the chair of the committee simply ruled out any further discussion, I take, not from your ruling but from your suggestion, that this ought to be pursued in the committee as opposed to the floor of the House of Commons. If we still have a grievance with the Chair that is the place where it should be raised. Is that correct?

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext:
The hon. member for Kamloops is correct. I have been apprised of how far it has gone in the committee. It is up to the committee and up to members to decide whether they wish to take it any further in the committee. For now that is where it should be left.
Again I am very conscious of what the hon. member for Calgary West has said. Ordinarily, if we were going to get into the substance of the complaint, I would not have proceeded without the chairman being here. Under the circumstances that is where we ought to leave it for now.

The Minister of Multiculturalism and Citizenship has had in his hands for quite some time a report from the Standing Committee on Human Rights and the Status of Disabled Persons. That report is entitled Paying too Dearly and is with regard to the Court Challenges Program.

November 26, 1992

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have the honour to table a petition from people in Manneville, Sainte-Gertrude, Launay, Malartic, Guyenne, Lebel-sur-Quevillon and Val-d'Or in Abitibi. The petitioners say that violent movies on television are dangerous and therefore unacceptable because they incite more violence.
They mention that all toys which incite violent games are unacceptable and should not be made. They also say that the freedom of the press to report acts of violence should be limited and that information on violent acts which is repeated too often on all television stations and on radio can incite others to commit the same acts of violence.
Therefore the petitioners humbly ask Parliament to legislate on the above-mentioned points to eliminate violence in our society in order to protect our children more and give all our fellow citizens a better quality of life.

Madam Speaker, this is another petition in the growing number of petitions that I have submitted recently regarding the proposal by Multinational Resources, a company which has intentions of damming a portion of the flow of the North Thompson River and diverting that flow into the California water market.
The residents of Falkland, a community in my riding of Okanagan-Shuswap, are concerned about the impact of this water diversion proposal. They urge the government to state categorically that it will not permit our fresh waters to be dammed and diverted into U.S. and possibly Mexican markets and to state that our Canadian rivers are not for sale.

Water is the life-blood of our country. These Canadians are expressing their concerns about these water export and diversion proposals. They call upon the Government of Canada to state categorically that it will not permit our fresh water rivers to be dammed and diverted to the U.S.A. and to state that our Canadian rivers are not for sale.

Madam Speaker, it is my pleasure to rise today and present a petition. It is signed by people from all over the province of British Columbia and throughout Alberta who are concerned with the intention of the United States to divert water from Canadian rivers into the United States for use in the San Diego, California, area and other parts of the United States and northern Mexico.
They are concerned that these diversions have not been specifically prohibited either in the free trade agreement or in the proposed North American free trade agreement. They ask this government to specifically and categorically state that it will not permit our fresh water rivers to be dammed and diverted into the United States of America, and to state that our Canadian rivers are not for sale.

Madam Speaker, I have the honour to present two petitions. One is signed by approximately 300 petitioners from Moosomin, Saskatchewan, Vancouver, B.C., and Oko-toks, Alberta.
These people are very disappointed that this government in its ideological frenzy gunned down the most cost effective and socially useful housing program this country ever had, the co-op housing program. Madam Speaker, the second petition is signed by approximately 600 residents of my own constituency of Prince Albert-Churchill River. These people are surprised that the drug multinationals should be in a panic thinking that perhaps President Clinton will bring in a drug program much like the Canadian one. Madam Speaker, it is a privilege to present a petition on behalf of a number of constituents who point out in their petition that crimes of violence against the person are intolerable and constitute the most abhorrent crimes that society faces.
They point out that sentencing for crimes of violence does not appropriately reflect society's abhorrence toward violence in order to act as a true deterrent and to protect the public by removal of the offender from society.
Therefore they are asking Parliament to recognize that crimes of violence against a person are serious and abhorrent and that Parliament amend the Criminal Code of Canada accordingly.

Madam Speaker, my second petition points out that progress toward true equality for Canadian women continues to be very slow. They are asking the government to introduce legislation that would end wage discrimination in the federal Public Service.

speakeroldname: Mr. Bill Domm (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister for Science):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Science
subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I rise today with not the easiest job in the world but one that is very necessary. That is to proceed now with third reading of Bill C-63.
I say that for a couple of reasons. Hon. members are all aware of the government announcement in February
Government Orders
1992 in the budget that a total of 46 government agencies, boards, commissions, corporations or advisory bodies would be eliminated or consolidated or perhaps deferred or privatized.
This bill, the Corporate Dissolutions Act, is the first legislative measure giving effect to this commitment. It dissolves six agencies: the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council of Canada, the International Centre for Ocean Development, The Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Law Reform Commission and the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council.
In order to fully understand the rationale behind Bill C-63 it is very necessary to look at the bill in the broader picture. By this I mean looking at it in terms of the principles that underline the government's decision to restructure and streamline its own operations. This bill is part of the government's initiative to streamline government. In the consolidations leading up to the budget Canadians told us they wanted government to be leaner, more efficient and less expensive, and we have responded.
The government has taken a hard look at how it can eliminate overlap and duplication in its own operations. Bill C-63 is part of this initiative. This bill is also consistent with the thrust of the Nielsen task force which was set up shortly after our government came into office in 1984.
I firmly believe, as do my colleagues on this side of the House, that governments have a fundamental obligation to ensure that their financial resources, the taxpayers' money, are effectively employed. Like the private sector, government must also ask itself tough questions about whether it can afford to do everything it does now. The slow economic growth this country is experiencing has put substantial pressure on the deficit. The recently released numbers for the fiscal year just ended show a deficit of $34.6 billion, the highest in six years.
While the government managed to maintain operational surplus revenues less program spending of $6.6 billion, the interest charges we must pay on the debt are more than six times greater than that surplus; they are $41.2 billion. The total debt itself stands at $422 billion.

November 26, 1992
Government Orders
The burden of debt has grown from the legacy we and all Canadians inherited from the previous government. Since 1984 we have run an operational surplus of more than $20 billion. All the growth and the debt since then have come from compounding interest charges on the debt we inherited.
Clearly measures must be taken to reduce spending and bring our fiscal situation back on track. The savings we will see from the winding up of these six organizations are only small steps in that direction, but they are necessary and very important steps.
The critics of the actions called for in this bill have not really offered very many meaningful alternatives and the public is tired of hearing politicians and interest groups say: "Do not cut here", because the bottom line ends up not cutting anywhere.
If we enjoyed better economic times than we do currently, or if we had inherited a sounder fiscal balance when this government came into office in 1984, an argument could be made to keep these organizations in operation. However, at a time when businesses across Canada are having to make hard decisions about the priorities in their operations, the government cannot hold itself aloof or exempt.
When Canadians in every part of the country are forced to make tough choices as they balance family budgets in the light of financial hardships, we cannot pretend that government need not make difficult choices as well, It is this understanding of the financial reality facing Canadians that has led us to put forward Bill C-63.
Simply put, Canada can no longer afford to maintain these organizations given our heavy national debt and the high taxes this brings with it. This is doubly true when the key activities these organizations perform can be and will be addressed by existing departments and private sector resources.
In context Bill C-63 is clearly not an arbitrary measure. It is part of a long-range strategy by the government to reduce its size given today's fiscal realities.
The government believes that Canadians generally will welcome the initiative that we will save taxpayers dollars by eliminating functions that are not essential and by reducing overlap and duplication wherever possible.
My colleague, the parliamentary secretary, in his speech to the House yesterday outlined the savings we expect. Let me just recap the numbers. For the full 46 agencies and bodies we are eliminating, restructuring, deferring or privatizing, including the six covered by this legislation, the saving will be $22 million this fiscal year. This will increase to $71 million in 1993-94 and the total saving over the next five years is estimated to be in the range of $310 million.
The organizations affected by Bill C-63 have all given valuable services to the people of Canada. No one is denying that. I know that many Canadians have been wondering what happens to the invaluable work that was being done by these organizations and also how the tasks performed by these organizations will be continued.
The assets of each organization being wound up are being transferred to the appropriate department or other body. This means that all valuable files and the resource libraries established over the years will be maintained. The bottom line is the government has made sure that these valuable resources are kept intact.
As well the activities performed by the organizations being wound up have been reviewed. Those that are consistent with the government priorities and that are not being performed by other government organizations will be continued.
Already ongoing projects have been taken up by the department or organization best able to see them through. In fact, in many cases public policy actually can be better served by organizations that balance competing interests within themselves, rather than by single interest agencies.
This is particularly true at a time when funds are scarce and people in every sector need to pool resources and work together rather than compete against one another. It makes little sense to incur expensive managerial and administrative costs by dividing functions among individual agencies simply because of different interests.
We deeply regret any personal dislocation that has come about by the phasing out or elimination of these organizations but government and those who work for the Canadian taxpayer cannot expect to be immune to economic reality. Every day the business sector and its employees face the obligation to increase efficiency and at the same time make every effort to control costs. It is high time that the government did likewise.
November 26, 1992

I should put this another way. I want to emphasize that this legislation is part of a wide-ranging commitment to reduce the burden of government on this economy. This includes ensuring that taxpayers receive optimum value for the resources they entrust to us.
To deliver this value, we have to recognize that government agencies and organizations must be judged by tougher, more competitive standards than was the case in past decades. If we do not accept this obligation, then we as elected representatives are failing in our duty to all Canadians who must work in a tougher and much more competitive world in the 1990s. I urge my colleagues to give speedy passage to this bill.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I listened carefully to my hon. colleague opposite in his listing of the reasons the government has felt it necessary to dissolve these sue agencies. He has referred to other agencies that were listed and enumerated in the throne speech and which the government feels at this time it must dispense with.
I cannot agree that it is appropriate or even that it is cost saving in the end to do this. I have reasons for saying that it is not going to save us very much money.
The government believes and has characterized this initiative as one which will streamline and reduce government and which will save money. It is really killing off agencies that would have continued to provide very important functions to the Government of Canada.
I want to point that the government is coming to this House and saying that it must dispose of agencies and the initiatives it manages and co-ordinates. At the same time the government is doing that, it is sometimes coming to this House-and sometimes not-and embarking on new initiatives just as costly but all in the same realm.
The one which comes to mind immediately is the government's so-called prosperity initiative on which there are millions of dollars being spent, not just on substance because prosperity cannot be implemented by
Government Orders
legislation or by policy. This is something that the people, the country and the communities generate. The government is also advertising hand over fist to show Canadians that prosperity is attainable, that they can be a part of it and let us all join together to produce it.
That kind of prosperity initiative is one of several which have been announced this year. This is at the same time as the government is saying it has to get rid of the Economic Council of Canada which has itself recommended initiatives similar to the prosperity initiative. It just does not make sense to me that the money the government wants so badly to save and the streamlining it wants so badly to implement are counterbalanced by increased spending and less streamlining embarking on all these new initiatives.
I do not see the cost saving. What I see is that the government has saved enough money by killing off these agencies in a way which will enable it to spend funds and create new initiatives of its own. Keep in mind that all of the agencies which are being killed off here were initiated just prior to the date in 1984 when this government took office.
One element of the initiative I want to make sure is on the record at third reading is the disturbing procedure of the government in embarking on the streamlining, on the killing off and the dissolutions without the authority of Parliament.
It is clear from the statute that this bill does not ratify previous actions of the government. This bill does not say we agree that the government should have killed off or dissolved this agency. It says that the government may dissolve the agency and wrap up its affairs. In fact the bill authorizes the minister to do the things necessary to wrap up and dissolve the agency.
What we found here over the last few weeks, in fact since the end of June, is that the government has already wound up the affairs of these agencies. It has terminated employment. It has terminated leases. It has liquidated equipment and inventory. It has done all of the things that would be done upon a dissolution or wind-up and it has done it all without the authority of this bill.

Government Orders
I do not understand why we are even going through this exercise if the government is so embolden that it would take on an initiative and complete a task before the authority has been given by this House.
In any event, I could ask what would happen if this bill were not passed or the act never proclaimed. What kind of a situation would we be in then? Canadians would be entitled to ask and be entitled to accuse the government of acting without legal authority. While I am reluctant to say now that the government has acted unlawfully, it has certainly acted without law. The law simply was not in place and it is still not as we debate it now.
A theme that has dogged this debate and one we cannot lose sight of is that most of the agencies the government is dissolving were providing a type of advice, guidance, direction and research to the government that we characterize as independent.
These agencies were set up to provide independent, non-governmental advice and direction to government. It was done because it was recognized that a lot of times in government once a decision is made or once a high official has some idea in his or her head, that is precisely what is going to happen.
There is ex post facto a desire on the part of the bureaucracy and the minister to justify, after the fact, that everything has occurred exactly within the mandate and the prescription of what was originally ordained. A lot of time government digs itself a great big hole trying to justify what the minister has decided one, two, three or four years ago. For that reason the government of the day, pre-1984, recognized that independent advice and research were extremely healthy and maybe even integral in assisting the government to make decisions on epolicy, marshalling resources and spending taxpayers' dollars effectively and efficiently.
In the natural course of things there is not enough incentive on the part of public officials, bureaucrats and administrators to provide advice and leadership to a department in a way that could be seen as being adverse to the views of the minister or the people who are higher up on the ladder of authority in the department.
Once a chunk of the department begins its work and starts down the road in a certain direction, it does not have a hope in hell of changing direction because everybody in the system is going to say: "Yes, minister,
we are heading in the right direction and I am doing my job. We are a great team". In the worst case scenario the unfortunate minister has no idea what is going on and does not realize things are heading in the wrong direction because he has not had good, independent advice.
Another problem occurs if we dispense with all the independent advice giving, the independence and objectivity. Let us get rid of it all and let the government and the officials proceed on their own. The public has a problem as it monitors what government is doing. Parliament monitors government and asks: "Mr. Minister, what advice are you getting on this? What are you doing? Ten times out of ten the response is: "I am sorry, I cannot tell you what we have recommended to the minister because it is confidential". Advice to ministers is guarded and secret, therefore the public does not get a chance to know what advice is given. The debate is all behind closed doors.
Through the use of independent agencies there is an opportunity to see some of the advice the public sector is receiving. I want to give an example because I think it is a good one. Just recently the Economic Council of Canada, one of the agencies that was being dissolved on April 29 this year, concluded a study on a topic of extreme importance to Canadians at this time. I am sure everyone in this House will agree it is a matter of extreme importance. It had to do with making recommendations for a coherent education system which would link employers, schools and governments, boost the standards and produce graduates better equipped for a more competitive work world.
Those words reiterate what we have been hearing from the government. I do not know who put the words together first, but this was an excellent report on our national system of education, its effectiveness and its cost-effectiveness. That independent report stated the system then in place was a failure. Those are the words. It said: "This is a sign of failure". I could not imagine an official of the minister's department publicly releasing a document that said: "This is a sign of failure". It simply would not happen. I hope I have made the point here that it is only through independent advice giving agencies the public has an opportunity to see the ebb, flow and interplay of ideas and initiatives government will undertake.
November 26, 1992

We are simply going to be without it in relation to the work of the Economic Council of Canada, the Law Reform Commission, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, and the other agencies we are dealing with here.
The government has said it wants to be more efficient and it can do that by dispensing with these agencies. I do not see the rationale or the linkage. I do not understand how it can become more efficient by getting rid of the agencies that provide it with an objective road map of where it wants to go.
The government has said these agencies do overlapping work of other agencies or other non-governmental organizations. That may be true in some cases, but maybe it is more appropriate to say the other non-government agencies may also be overlapping the work of these agencies. In this debate the government has not given examples of the overlap, so we are unable to judge just how important the fact of the overlap is in the government's decision making.
In relation to the Law Reform Commission, for example, let us say there is some overlap in the work it is doing. Let us say the justice department, a university faculty of law, or some other agency, is doing work that is overlapping.
That is a possibility, but if that is the case then almost every other developed and lesser developed country in the world has the same darned problem. As we look at dissolving the Law Reform Commission we could only find two other countries that did not have a law reform commission or similar body. I think they were both in Africa. One of them was Zimbabwe.
We are going to get rid of overlap while Zimbabwe perhaps never had overlap. I do not think that is a great club to be in. All of the other nations of this world recognize how important it is to have a law reform body as a guide light, as a road map to the future in terms of legal reforms.
This government has said it is getting out of business and privatization seems to be the theme. With what we are seeing here, I say to this House the government is getting out of government. It is getting out of essential aspects of modem day government, the facilities by which we use independent advice.
Government Orders
Every one of these agencies has facilitated the decision-making process of government. Drawing an analogy between government and a ship at sea, if I were a captain of a ship I do not know why I would throw my most effective, objective navigator overboard. I would want a navigator on my ship who was not going to say yes to me just because I was the captain. I would want a navigator who would tell me if I were steering a wrong course, and do it boldly and objectively.
I feel that is what the government is doing by ditching the Economic Council of Canada, the Science Council of Canada, the Law Reform Commission, and the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. It does not want to hear objective navigators any more. It just wants to hear its own advice. It will decide what it is going to do. It will make the decisions. All of the bureaucrats do their best from inside the cocoon of government to advise the decision-makers in government what is going on. It is just not enough in this very complex world.
There will be others here today who will rail against how government has grown out of control in terms of its size. I hope the members of this House will listen to those who objectively and calmly tell the government these agencies help government and have not made it grow out of control. They may actually add some efficiency to government.
At the end of the day I hope the bill will not be adopted by the House. I say this knowing in almost every case the government has already killed, dissolved, sold off, or liquidated the agency involved. We cannot even get them on the phone.
One individual, I think in the Ministry of Science and Technology, indicated they did keep their phone number because they were legally advised to keep the agency alive until Parliament passed the bill. It was heartening to hear that, but none of the other agencies could be reached. They were gone. The leases were expired. The furniture had been moved out.
The cost savings hoped for by the government perhaps have not begun quite yet. It probably has to settle some leasing arrangements with landlords. It is starting to save a little bit of money, but it is embarking down the path of losing the independent advice these agencies have so well provided the government, in some cases for 30 years. I will close here and hope members will vote against this bill.

November 26, 1992
Government Orders

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to speak on third reading of Bill C-63, which is the government legislation to wind up the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the Law Reform Commission of Canada, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Economic Council of Canada, the International Centre for Ocean Development and the Science Council of Canada.
I had an opportunity yesterday to speak on what it meant for Canada to wind up some of these commissions, institutes and councils. As I said last night, there are six ministers who used to receive advice from these institutions. I find it strange during this debate not a single one of them has held a press conference. It seems to be standard for the government to hold one at a $500 a plate dinner, or somewhere outside the House. Not a single one of them has come in and spoken in the House to explain to Canadians why this institution or that institution is no longer necessary.
Last night members on the government side suggested institutions such as the Law Reform Commission were no longer necessary because the justice committee of the House of Commons was going to be taking on this enormous task. Yet no money has been proposed to go to the justice committee. The library of the Law Reform Commission has not been transferred into the custody of the justice committee of this House.
The government members on that committee have not suggested a timetable or a way of dealing with the duties that were performed by the Law Reform Commission. I suggest that is a fraudulent argument being used by the government side in terms of the Law Reform Commission and the other five agencies.
In terms of the arguments we have just heard this morning, the Neilsen task force was to restructure and streamline government, make it leaner, more efficient and end duplication. I think in a matter of minutes I can lay all of thbse arguments entirely to rest. In each single instance of these institutes, commissions and bodies that gave independent advice to government, this government has not moved to replace them or make other arrangements with bodies that could at least be considered arm's length or potentially independent.
Instead as in many other cases with this government, it pork-barrels contracts in each of these initiatives out to friends of the party.
When the Prime Minister has $500 a plate dinners in Toronto; they have a list. Who is on the pork-barrel hit parade just phone them up. You need 500 donkeys, you phone 500 donkeys who had their snouts in the trough. You say-we gave you a contract for $50,000, we want you to buy a table, 10 seats at $500. This is called legitimate fund raising now by the government while it is in office.
The argument that these bodies, some of whom received a couple of million dollars, had a couple of dozen bodies doing research and so on for their institutions-the Science Council of Canada at $3 million, the Law Reform Commission at $4 million-the government claims there just is not that kind of money around any more.
Let us take a look at what the Auditor General had to say. He has now concluded that the prison built in the Prime Minister's riding at a cost of $68 million was totally unnecessary. This is not NDP research, this is not Liberal research, this is not the prisoners' complaints bureau of Canada. It is the Auditor General. He said it was unnecessary. We argued in this House that it was a bad location. We received phone calls and letters from people in the criminal justice system who said it was crazy.
I raised last night the movement of the immigration headquarters to Vegreville, Alberta. People who are actively involved in immigration issues in this country know that the overwhelming majority of immigrants that come to Canada come in through Vancouver. They come in through Montreal and they come in through Toronto. Why would any government in its right mind withdraw all of those positions from those offices, slash them by 10, 20 or 30 per cent and move them all to Vegreville, Alberta, in this day of high technology?
Computers can talk to each other. All the people do not have to be in the same lunch room, in the same building in Vegreville so that they can do all 400,000 immigration applications for the whole of Canada. It is pork-barrelling at its very worst. It is just like the penitentiary built in the Prime Minister's riding.
November 26, 1992

This is an incredibly old-fashioned pork-barrelling attitude, that you have to bring the bacon home. If you are in trouble politically, you have to build a prison or you have to open a new UI centre or you have to do this or you have to do that. This has to be stopped.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: We can't afford it.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
That is right. The government cannot have it both ways. We know it is going to fill the hotels in Vegreville and God bless the owners of the hotels. They will make piles of money because all the families who are involved in immigration cases will have to go from Montreal to Vegreville. They will have to go from Vancouver to Vegreville. Lawyers involved in getting access to cases will have to go from wherever they are, from Edmonton, Moose Jaw, Quebec City, or St. John's, Newfoundland, to Vegreville, rather than having immigration officials available in Montreal, Toronto, Vancouver, Prince George and Prince Rupert the way they are today.
It is an act of madness and I hope Preston Manning gets on it pretty darn quick, pointing out that this is not just your average pork-barrelling activity. This is stupid: s-t-u-p-i-d. You do not move people from all over the country to a given location to protect somebody politically-
I have never asked for such a thing in 14 years. I cannot imagine that the Deputy Prime Minister is such a cock-a-doodle-do that he has to have it. He is a good speaker. People trust him in Alberta so far as I know. Does he need a chunk of pork that fat and that thick?
Let me tell you what else the Auditor General had to say about this government. He told it years ago to do something about the purchases of the Department of National Defence bullets. What did the government do? It bought 12 million bullets that will not fly straight. That is typical of this group over here.
It cannot go in and audit and say: "Stop buying crooked bullets", but "get rid of the Science Council, get rid of the Law Reform Commission. We cannot have independent bodies; no, of course not". In the Ministry of Employment and Immigration 800 bureaucrats were cashed out, given $30,000, $40,000 and $50,000 to just go home and smoke rope, read the newspaper, have a couple of cool beers and then the same department hired
Government Orders
them all on again. The minister has not fired a single person for it.
I tell you, Madam Speaker, if I were the minister responsible, there would be heads lolloping down the street in this city for that kind of crap. We have to get rid of the Science Council they say.
What else does the Auditor General have to say? There is $3.5 billion in loan guarantees and in other aid that Ottawa provided on Hibernia, on Lloydminster's bi-provincial heavy oil upgrader and Regina's new heavy oil upgrader.
What does he conclude about this brilliant cabinet? This is $3.5 billion. We are talking about $3 million to wind up the Science Council of Canada. The government chops it off. There is not $3 million, but on $3.5 billion the Auditor General for Canada says that the cabinet made all of these financial arrangements "without having any clear idea what economic benefits the megaprojects will yield". Just dump'er down the hole, eh? They will get headlines for a while. What is a few billion of the taxpayers' dollars? What is a few billion? The government never bothered to assess whether anything at all will come back out of it.

speechtext:
What about the debt? The Tories love to travel around and say: Debt, debt, debt. It is all the Liberals' fault; debt, debt, debt. He points out in 1971,13 per cent of every dollar in this country went to payments on the debt.
What is it under the Tories? It is 33 cents and it will be 34 cents before the end of this year. They will go out and cackle and gaggle during the next election: "Oh the debt, the debt, the debt". The debt doubled under these donkeys. The Tories will probably try to blame it on the NDP. They will say: "Oh, it is the New Democrats. They forced us to do it. We had to get rid of the Science Council of Canada to deal with the debt".
Just while I am speaking, the amount of money to pay on our debt will be as much as would have been required to keep the Science Council of Canada for a whole bloody year. However these guys over here have wax a foot thick in their ears.

November 26, 1992
Government Orders
Let us take a look at a couple more. "Wealthy exploiting GST loophole". This was raised in the House yesterday by my friend from Newfoundland. He pointed out that you would need 35 children under the age of 18 to comply with the tax requirements to get your GST kickback.
More than 12,000 Canadians, making more than $100,000 were found by the Auditor General to be getting GST rebates. They do not have 35 children under the age of 18. They very cagily move their money out of the country. They make certain deals out there. They do not have to pay any tax on their profits outside the country and then they bring the money back in and of course they get their GST rebate anyway.
The Minister of Finance says: "No, no, the Auditor General does not have accurate figures on how many hundreds of millions this involves". The reporters who are not dumb walk across the street to see Mr. Desau-tels, the Auditor General, and they say: "The Minister of Finance says you do not have accurate figures on Canada losing a couple of hundred million a year". The Auditor General says: "Of course we do not. That is a very conservative estimate". He cannot get the accurate figures out of the Department of Finance because this is for all these rich monkeys, right? They make more than $100,000 a year. They hire a tax lawyer. The tax lawyer says: "Do this and that in Florida. Do this and that in Georgia. Hide your cash here. Hide your cash there. Make sure you go to these $500 a plate dinners. Make sure you stay on the right side of the governing party. Make sure you do that and nothing will happen".
That is hundreds of millions. They are losing hundreds of millions, and they are cutting the Science Council of Canada at $3 million a year because it was giving independent advice and we know why. This is politically motivated by the hatchetmen, the Praetorian Guard, as my friend from Winnipeg pointed out last night, who now surround the Prime Minister.
I honestly believe now that my friends on the government's side, most Tories have nothing to say about government policy. They come in here and try to defend it once in a while, but not very well. They try, but they know they do not have anything to say. Most of them were surprised when the Prime Minister and the Minister of Finance announced that these institutions were being cut.
They went: "Oh, my God, they are really doing that". Then they realized: "Oh, we are part of the zipped lip party. Keep that lip zipped. Zip that lip. Do not talk about anything. Be quiet in caucus and quiet on the street. Be quiet in the riding. Do not let anybody know that it is out of control".
There is this little group across in another building running the whole damn country. One day they say: "We have to have 10 nuclear submarines, $100 billion. We got to get up there. There are polar bears eating too many seals. We got to get up there. Away we go. Get these nuclear submarines fast".
Canadians go: Could it be true? The government realized that Canadians did not want nuclear submarines. We do not want them in B.C. Every mayor, every MLA and most MPs say: "Get them out of here. We do not want the American ones. We do not want anybody's".
Finally the government says: "Okay, we will not do the nuclear subs; we will do $4.4 billion in helicopters". I reminded the House last night about these helicopters. Since then I have spoken to reporters and they still cannot believe it. My friend behind the curtain cannot believe that any government that is reasonably rationally sane would buy $4.4 billion worth of EH-101 helicopters so that we can look for those nuclear submarines out there. We are not sure whose. I guess the American ones because they will not tell us where they are. They are our ally.
These helicopters cannot land on the frigates. The decks are the wrong size. They do not have enough fuel capacity to do long offshore work so they are no good for offshore fisheries work. They cannot look for subs. They cannot land on the frigates.
The public needs to know once again they cannot be used for search and rescue. They have 160 knots down-wash. Can you imagine. You are hanging on the edge of a mountain. Your plane has crashed. There you finally see it, search and rescue, there is the DND coast guard. Ah, they are coming to save you. They are coming to save me. One hundred and sixty knots downwash, that is more than 100 miles an hour. Have you ever stood up in a convertible at 100 miles an hour? Your eyeballs are in the hair at the back of your head.
November 26, 1992

You would be hanging on the edge of the cliff and whoops, down you would go. You are in the water. Your boat has sunk. Oh, fantastic, here comes the chopper. DND is going to save me. They pull over to pick you out of the water and it drives you 30 feet below the surface. Your last breath is under water. The incompetence goes beyond one's wildest imagination.
Let me give you a couple of other examples of the hundreds of millions that we are losing in taxes because this government will not collect from the wealthy. We lose billions from profitable corporations, from 12,000 Canadians who earn more than $100,000 a year. According to the Auditor General they collected the GST anyway even though they did not have 35 children under the age of 18 each. That was what was required if they were going to collect it.
Let us look at the Department of Indian Affairs and Northern Development. Carelessness at Indian Affairs costs 10,000 jobs a year and $200 million a year for some of the poorest people in Canada. Do we have anything done in the Department of Indian Affairs about it? It has been told about this for years and years and years. Did it do anything? Talks have been held for the past 15 years.
You wonder why unemployment rates are high among aboriginal people and why they cannot get any income. The department still does not have in place a proper means of legally stopping people from stealing the wood off the reserves. There is no way of doing anything about it. Logging companies just pull up, cut the trees down, load them up and drive away. The bands cannot do anything because the lands are held in trust by the Crown and the Crown has not prosecuted a single case.
Let us take a look at military spending. The government says that there is not enough money for these six agencies and that it is going to slash another 40 more. What does The Financial Post say? "Almost every federal project to buy new military equipments studied by the Auditor General either went over budget or took longer to deliver than planned. A detailed study of just 11 procurement projects worth $5 billion found that none followed the management system". None, and the government is telling us that the Science Council of Canada with a $3 million budget, with people like John Polanyi, a Nobel laureate, giving independent advice to the government, is too expensive.
Government Orders
When the sacred cow, the Department of National Defence, is squandering billions, hundreds and thousands of millions, the government will not do anything or say anything.
Let us take a look at the Auditor General's report because we deserve to lay to rest this balderdash coming from the government's side that this is making the government leaner, that this is efficiency in getting rid of duplication.
The Auditor General says: "We noted that direct pay and allowances alone cost the department $3.3 billion or 29 per cent of its 1989-90 budget". This is after the revelations last year that our Department of National Defence has more commissioned officers per non-commissioned officers than any other force in the world. The icing is six feet thick and you have a private down at the bottom. There is a general, a lieutenant-colonel, a major and a sergeant above him and the list just goes on and on. For every private there are about 800 generals. Is anybody doing anything about it? Has the Minister of National Defence called in a few of the generals and said: "Hey, guys, what about a few heads rolling?" This is a sacred cow. Of course the government would not want to do anything about it. The department spends between $18,000 and $47,000 per student per year and this is for cadets. All the Auditor General wanted was some kind of benefit evaluation. Will the department do it? Of course not.
Official languages training is a real sacred cow. No one in this country is supposed to want to talk about this stuff. In our 1990 report we recommended that National Defence redefine the goals of its official languages program in terms of the number of bilingual positions required and proficiency levels needed to meet clearly defined operational requirements. That is not unreasonable. Just identify how much you need.
We reported this program cost the department $500 million since 1980 and was expected to cost $1.4 billion over the next 15 years. There were 7,600 individuals on the language training in 1990-91. In 1989 the 9,000 anglophones at the language level closest to becoming bilingual were not given priority access to resources that would have enabled them to become effectively bilingual. In 1990-91, 75 per cent of the student population was still registered at the beginner level of the program.

Government Orders
I am sure one of my colleagues will have an intriguing question to put to me if I am able to complete this set. Canadians have the right to know about this kind of thing.

speechtext:
My colleague brought me back to the pith of my argument here today. There are many areas a government that was seriously managing government and the taxpayers' dollars would have gone to and drawn dollars from to protect these kinds of agencies.
We have 9,000 anglophones in the Department of National Defence involved in training, but the Auditor General finds they were never given access to the necessary resources. They still got the dough and the program still ran, but they were never given access to it. Therefore 75 per cent of them were still beginners three years later. It seems to me you could give them $20 on a Friday, tell them to go down and hang out in a beer parlour for 24 hours and they would learn more than they would by taking this kind of program which costs $500 million.
It gets worse. I know this is a sensitive area, but listen to the facts. Only 24 per cent of the candidates who took the 1990-91 non-commissioned member basic French course qualified as bilingual. Do you know what it cost, Madam Speaker? DND has not implemented our recommendation to incorporate bilingual posting priorities. Although this course lasts a full year and costs over $80,000 per person, in 1990-91 only 66 per cent of its graduates were actually assigned to a bilingual position. Now you cannot tell me this is competence. Bring me the generals and I will sign the firing slip. Bring them to me. I am sure even the government House leader would like to sign a couple. It just does not seem possible they were not placed after spending $80,000 a person for the year. You have 9,000 anglophones taking the course at $500 million and after three years 75 per cent of them are still in the beginner's course trying to figure out how to print. Give me a break. There is $500 million for this and this government says it had to get rid of the Science Council
because it cost $3 million a year. What about $80,000 a year to give someone language training? I get $62,000 a year and I get beaten over the head with baseball bats in my riding for being over-paid. Where are these guys on language training? What are they doing? Are they only learning the words: "Caviar, champagne please, where is my Cadillac, give me the keys, how soon do I get to retire?"
Give me a break. This government calls itself conservative. Conservative, my foot. It should be Cl for conservative incompetents, not PC.
Let us look further to what the Auditor General had to say because there are plenty of areas to save money. Let us take a look at training.
The Auditor General says: "We recommended in 1990 that the department compare costs between its own school system, civilian colleges and institutes of technology". That is not an unreasonable request from the Auditor General of Canada on behalf of Parliament and the taxpayers.
By way of example, in 1990 we reported it cost $265,352 for a Canadian forces fleet school to train one marine engineering technician, while it cost $71,923 in the community college system just down the street.
Now who is kidding whom? Maybe these are the people who attend the $500 a plate Tory fund raisers. Did that ever cross your mind, Madam Speaker? It costs seventy thousand bucks to be trained at any college or technical training school in the country. What is the government allowing? These are Tory years, 1990, 1991,
1992.	It costs $265,352, another two hundred grand, or 300 per cent more for Tory training. Canadians have to be outraged that the Science Council of Canada and the Law Reform Commission have been cut.
As I have said before, we know why a couple of the people in these institutions and on these commissions had harsh things to say about the government. This government is not fond of democratic institutions. We know that. Members' privileges are constantly being eroded. The rights of Canadians to have access to institutions they feel secure are at arm's length from the political process are being shot like ducks out of the sky by this government.
November 26, 1992

Where is it leading, we have to ask ourselves in this House? At least it is broadcast to a few people, and occasionally a few reporters watch this place and a few people listen and talk. But we have to ask, what is the underlying philosophy behind a political party that starts pulling the funding from independent institutions all over the country? We are doing six today and there are another 40 to go. We are talking lobotomies, guillotines, throat slitting and gut shooting.
Why is it doing this? It is not doing it for money. I just found the government somewhere in the neighbourhood of $20 billion in savings. I did this research this morning and found $20 billion. Where is the Minister of Finance? He should come in and give me one of the 125th medals so I could wear it around. They cost $1.86.
How can this government think Canadians are so gullible, stupid, unplugged and uncaring they would accept this kind of crap being peddled to us? Oh, we are getting rid of duplication. What about the 12 million crooked bullets? Can that not be stopped?
The Auditor General said: "Well, let us look again on medical care. This is something Canadians do care about". The DND medical support system costs at least $230 million per year. This is the Auditor General speaking. "Our 1990 audit recommended the National Defence determine the minimum dedicated medical support system needed in peace time". Now that is not unreasonable. Just figure out what your minimum needs are and start funding to that level. He found the department's peacetime medical system costs in our sample were 86 per cent higher than the average for similarly sized civilian hospitals.
Now you cannot just kick that under the rug and say it is because it is military. It seems to me that is inconsistent with what I have always been told by my father and my uncle who were both in the military. The whole idea of military systems is to run them as cheaply, efficiently and effectively as possible. And yet everywhere we look, after eight years, the Tories are lavishing and squandering. It is enough to make you economically bulimic, to
Government Orders
think these guys are pursuing these kinds of completely irrational expenditures across the street.
Let us take another look at training, efficiency and economy. This is the Auditor General speaking: "In 1990 we found that 62 per cent of individual training delivered by the Canadian forces training system was not relevant to the trainees present jobs or it duplicated what they already knew". The training cost $165 million a year. We are training people who have already been trained. They already have their ticket. They have already been paid at that category. The military says: "That is kind of boring. What are you, an auto mechanic? Okay, go take an auto mechanics course and we will pay you to do that".
Does it not sink in? This is from the Auditor General. The training cost $165 million a year and these people are talking about increasing the level of expenditures to DND. I could go over there today and carve out $1 billion. I could probably carve out $6 billion of their $12 billion a year. It is incredible that this sacred cow hangs around.
The purchasing would make you gag. The department purchases the parts from the same company it buys the original equipment from. No one does that anymore. Just because you happen to buy a tank that has a Ford motor in it and you get sort of chummy with the guy who cut the deal, does not mean you have to buy all the parts from him forever and a day. It is like the rental of this building over in Hull. The Auditor General says it is crazy to have 10 and 20 year contracts for space where there is no competition. You just do not do that.
These are the people who are always saying: "Oh, Bob Rae, Mike Harcourt, Roy Romanow. Oh, scandal, New Democrats, incompetent". It is time Canadians knew the truth about the nine governments we have held in four provinces and Yukon. We have always done better than the governments that came before us and those that came after us. The years of Douglas and Blakeney produced balanced budgets, which are unheard of under the Tories and Liberals. Barrett in British Columbia, produced a balanced budget. However, the Socreds, Liberals and Tories say: "Watch out for the New Democrats. They have wild spending habits".

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, an hour ago the parliamentary secretary and the hon. member for Peterborough was quite right when he said he had a hard job putting forward the first speech on behalf of the government in defence of this bill. This is corroborated by the fact we do not see a long line-up on the government benches of subsequent speakers on this bill as it is customary we rotate speakers from side to side. Obviously it is an extremely difficult bill to defend and I congratulate the member for Peterborough for his courage.
He based his whole reason for proceeding with this measure on the government's desire to restructure and streamline government, making it more efficient and eliminating overlap and duplication. One has great difficulty understanding how the government could be streamlined or made more efficient by eliminating the Science Council of Canada, the Law Reform Commission, the International Centre for Ocean Development, the Economic Council of Canada, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security and the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council. It really boggles the mind that these are the objectives to be obtained and the goals to be reached by way of the premise given to us by the member for Peterborough. He went on to say that meaningful alternatives had not been offered at the time of second reading and in committee by those who oppose this bill.
Meaningful alternatives are offered every year. We just heard a moment ago of the reports produced by the Auditor General who every year points to the mistakes, sometimes in good faith, sometimes because of administrative shortcomings, sometimes because of inefficiency or incompetence, which are inherent in large institutions at times. Nevertheless the Auditor General points out every year and has pointed out to this government since 1984 opportunities to eliminate inefficiencies, to reduce overlaps, to deal with inefficiencies and duplications and to streamline government. The latest report by the Auditor General is a clear indication of that.
Alternatives do exist and for the life of me we cannot understand why the government has to proceed with Bill C-63 in order to achieve objectives that cannot be achieved through this bill. There is a contradiction here in terms.
What can be achieved in terms of efficiency by eliminating the Law Reform Commission? What can be achieved in eliminating overlaps and duplication by removing the Science Council of Canada? What can be achieved in streamlining government by eliminating the Economic Council of Canada? What is the logic of the government in terms of efficiency that can be achieved by eliminating the Canadian Institute of International Peace and Security or the Employment and Immigration Advisory Council? It does not make sense.
One has to conclude that what one is dealing with is a mind-set of a government which has decided that the role of government is to be compared to the role of a business and that the role of government has nothing to do with the public interest. It has decided that the role of government is not to pursue long-term goals and longterm public interest. It has to eliminate, where it can, institutions which may cause criticism, perhaps alternative viewpoints and produce them. It has to be obsessed with only one thing and that is the bottom line. That is not what the majority of Canadians expect the government role to be.
I suspect that the role the majority of Canadians expects the government to play is one of looking at the long-term, providing policy, doing the research that is necessary, and keeping the country united by way of very intensive intellectual work which is in great competition with other countries.
I would like to know of any G-7 country, which are the other industrial nations with which Canada is grouped, or any other country that belongs to the OECD, to which we also belong, that has done away with their economic council, or has done away with their science council, or has done away with their law reform commission.
November 26, 1992

No modem industrialized nation in its right mind would take a step like this. We are becoming the laughing stock abroad. Nobody understands why we are doing these things.
Let me give an example, one that I have not mentioned yet, and that is the elimination of the International Centre for Ocean Development. It was very revealing at the time of the announcement of this bill what its vice-chairman said in Halifax. Mr. Vandermeulen is quoted by Canadian Press as saying: "This is the only international assistance group in the world that was working in the fisheries field with small island states. The agency was founded in the early eighties to help developing countries in the South Pacific, the Caribbean, and Indian Ocean to manage their ocean resources after the Law of the Sea conference established the 200-mile limit".
Since fish do not respect political boundaries, if stocks are mismanaged by one country then the whole community pays the price. This was the role of the International Centre for Ocean Development: to help in the South Pacific, Caribbean and Indian Ocean states to develop their policies and it is gone.
In eliminating the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security our critic, the member for Winnipeg South Centre, commented that the government "is intent upon snuffing out any kind of serious analysis of what is going on in the world". He may perhaps have attributed motives here, but one must say in all fairness that this institute has performed an extremely valuable role in providing government, Parliament and any agency interested in foreign affairs with in-depth analysis and alternative policies. We will not have that benefit any longer.
My colleague for Scarborough-Rouge River was quite right when he stated on March 10 of this year: "Agencies like the Science Council, the Economic Council, the Law Reform Commission, the Institute for International Peace and Security have provided valuable advice to the government and at a time when this country should focus on making Canada more competitive and better equipped and up to date, the last thing we
Government Orders
should be doing is getting rid of them". Those are very wise words.
One has to put Bill C-63 in a broader context, and that is what has happened to Canada in the last eight years. It is part of a pattern, part of the Prime Minister's commitment to change Canada's face, as he stated back in 1984. He is certainly changing Canada's face. He is certainly maintaining his promise of doing that.
One has to look at this measure together with other measures that have been gradually introduced over the years. It started very slowly and unobtrusively with the cancellation of programs for youth. I must remind members of the cancellation of Katimavik which was very strongly resented by some of our most distinguished colleagues in the other place. It went on with the cancellation of Environment 2000, a youth employment program for the summer. Over the years it escalated into a number of other initiatives of which this bill is the last.
I just have to remind my colleagues about the virtual cancellation of social housing in our urban centres. Just to quote another example, I remind them of the cancellation of the Court Challenges Program. The list is pretty long.
Coupled with the cancellations were cuts and a reduction in responsibilities that were gradually put into place. Let my remind everyone of what has been done in reducing the role of VIA Rail in placing an immense burden on its operation, in reducing its ability to tie together communities across the nation, as only VIA Rail could have done. However it did not stop with that.
It reduced the mandate of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation when it was announced by the government that the CBC should not pursue in its mandate the unity of Canada. That was a mind boggling announcement. The CBC was denied that mandate at a time, particularly after going through the referendum, when we very badly need institutions like the CBC and Radio-Canada to perform that bonding role of promoting and pursuing a sense of unity in the country. Its role is stressing what brings us together, what unifies us, rather than what makes us different from each other. The CBC and Radio-Canada could not perform during the weeks and

Government Orders
months preceding the last referendum as a result of a decision by this government.
Might I remind members of the cuts which were introduced in late 1984 and subsequently to the National Research Council which today operates on a very limited budget. Might I remind them of the fact that government contributions have been cut from the Unemployment Insurance Commission, thus severely limiting the funds available for the training of the unemployed, for the assistance to those who cannot find employment and may want to have an extension to the benefits they receive. In other words, the number of those who exhaust their unemployment insurance benefits and do not want to go on welfare has been reduced.
As a result of the cuts by this government, the unemployment insurance fund now can rely only on contributions by the worker and by the employer and no longer on the tripartite system we had of contributions coming from employer, employee and government.
The cuts and the denial of absolutely necessary budget increases to key departments like the Department of Employment and Immigration, the Secretary of State in charge of citizenship courts, the postal services, are just other indicators of how the government has gradually and systematically reduced the capacity of the federal government's employees to perform their jobs. What we have in our major urban centres are federal government offices, particularly in immigration, which are badly understaffed and badly overworked.
We have seen considerable cuts in the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources in the field of research and development, particularly in the field of research on renewal sources of energy. We have seen a shift almost entirely in favour of increasing Canada's dependence on non-renewable sources of energy which, as the name says, will exhaust themselves in due course. Also we have a very dangerous shift away from research and development on sources of energy that rely on biomass, solar energy and wind.
We have closed the consular offices in large numbers and reduced Canada's presence in a number of ways. We have reduced the support that the Government of Canada gives to non-governmental organizations. We have reduced the capacity of CIDA to perform its
mandate with adequate funds in helping developing countries in relation to the problems of mounting poverty, famine and disruptions abroad.
In other words, the promise the Prime Minister made in 1984 to change the face of Canada is being kept. Bill C-63 is an emanation, an expression and a fulfilment of that promise.
What this particular measure does to the Canadian taxpayer must be put on record. The average Canadian taxpayer will be deprived of some valuable and important initiatives once this measure goes through. We will oppose it inevitably but the numbers will not be on our side.
The five-year plan by the Science Council of Canada to influence the direction of science and technology for Canadian prosperity and Canadian well-being has been abandoned. Its study and the plan which commanded attention were extremely well received when published and would fit perfectly into any long-term economic policy of any government. With the abolition of the Science Council, we can kiss this five-year plan goodbye.
Then there are a number of studies which were also launched and were in process by the Science Council, namely, a study on genetics in health care, the role of venture capital in financing new technology, and the relationship between technology and economic development.
I will conclude by referring to the fact that the Economic Council of Canada had published just before its abolition a study on the economics of health care, a study on the economics of education, and an analysis on the impact of government on competitiveness.
The Law Reform Commission by virtue of its abolition has had its ongoing recodification of the Criminal Code of Canada frozen. The ongoing recodification will no longer be carried out as well as the completion of studies related to human rights, protection of life and administrative law.
Time does not permit me to elaborate on what is going to be lost as a result of this measure. I have no doubt that Bill C-63 will do profound damage to the fibre of Canada and to its ability to renew itself and to face emerging problems.
November 26, 1992

Not only that. It is also putting Canada in a position of great weakness. By the disbanding of these very important bodies we are losing the intellectual power and intellectual capital that these bodies represented and were able to produce on behalf of and for the benefit of present and future generations of Canadians. This is a very regrettable step. It is our hope that the government will reconsider it.

speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this is a wonderful opportunity for me to put a question to the member for Davenport. He may be in a very special, if not unique, position to answer it. It has to do with the role of independent advice to government. That independent advice and direction are products of many of these agencies we are dealing with.
The hon. member for Davenport has been a government minister as well as an opposition member. The opposition in Parliament, not being as well resourced as government is on a day-to-day basis, benefits as much from the independent advice and spade work of these agencies as does government.
I would like the member to comment on his own experience. As I have never served as a cabinet minister, I am curious about just how realistic my view has been that this kind of independent advice is useful to government. How effective is it? Is it money well spent? Maybe government never listens to these things. Maybe just the opposition does.
I would like to ask the member in his experience, with reference to, for example, the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the Economic Council of Canada, the International Centre for Ocean Development and the Law Reform Commission, any of these, how has he viewed the function of independent legal advice? Is it useful? Is it essential? How would he respond to that question?

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the answer is yes, it is extremely helpful. It is helpful both directly and indirectly-
It is helpful directly because it has an impact on the bureaucracy and the members of cabinet of the day. Collectively they have to take into account very seriously
Government Orders
alternative proposals and plans that are being made by independent agencies of the kind the member mentioned.
It has an effect indirectly because these reports impact on the composition of editorial writing of the intellectual and political community across the nation and not just in Ottawa. They provide food for thought, so to speak, for all those who are interested in policy development. Therefore, the policy development process is enhanced, enriched and widened. In the end the policy product the government announces is much better than without this kind of advice.
I would like to congratulate the member for Scarborough-Rouge River. In his statement of March 10 from which I am reading, he did stress the importance that governments should be nurturing and taking advice from these valuable agencies.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am very happy to take part in this debate particularly having had the opportunity to listen to my colleague, the hon. member for Davenport, and to say that I agree most whole-heartedly with the remarks he has made.
We on this side of the House are not opposed to the elimination of those bodies that no longer serve a public policy purpose. That is sensible and that is the norm for governments. However, we do stand opposed to Bill C-63 and to the elimination of a number of bodies in this country that not just serve a public policy purpose but serve a crucial public policy purpose.
In a country such as this one where literally all of us, even the native peoples, came from somewhere else originally, one of the unifying factors of this country is the desire for knowledge, the pure desire to know if you will, the respect for learning, the respect for lore that is garnered through experience, through research, through academic endeavour, through think-tanks, whatever. It is one of the things, I believe, and I know my colleagues on this side of the House believe, that makes Canadians again just a little bit different, just a little bit distinct from our neighbours on this continent.
All of us in this small country of ours, small in the sense of population, have been justly proud of organizations such as these that we now preside over the dissolution of.

Government Orders
There is a reason for everything this government does. It may not be a particularly good reason and as a matter of fact it usually is not a very good reason. However, I think the reason behind Bill C-63 and the dissolution of these bodies is particularly pernicious.
It is widely perceived that the elimination of organizations such as these which continue to serve a crucial public policy purpose is an attempt by this government to silence its critics on the right, most particularly its critics in the Reform Party. Indeed, many of this government's actions have been and continue to be guided by the desire to recapture the votes and loyalty of their own disaffected members who moved, yet again, to the right. What is happening because of this? As a country we are becoming hostage to a fringe party on the outer edge of the political spectrum.
Let us talk about the specific organizations we are going to lose when this bill becomes law because of the government's majority.
Let us first of all look at the Law Reform Commission. What kind of a country does not have a law reform commission? What can we expect in the area of developing legislation, in the area of far-seeing legislation, in the area of legislation that might anticipate our movement toward a global economy, toward a very different kind of life that Canadians are going to be dealing with in the 21st century, when the Law Reform Commission which is set up to develop and to bring forward the kinds of ideas that can help us make these transitions to the incredible speed of change in our modem society, is being thrown out, being wasted, being closed down?
What can we say about a government that deems all of the references to the commission to be references of the Crown, that confers the authority to close out the affairs of the commission to the responsible ministers and that repeals their constituent acts? We can say it is a government that is afraid to be told what it needs to do for the betterment of its people.
