speechtext:
Good. I will come back to the Law Reform Commission later in my remarks.
I want to speak a little bit now about the dissolution of another organization that is particularly close to my heart as the member for Halifax, because this act also
dissolves the International Centre for Ocean Development.
Again this is something that is going to be extremely hurtful for Canadians and has already been hurtful for Haligonians in the loss of jobs. We have lost people and not just from the region. I know a number of people who were involved with ICOD have left Halifax and gone to other organizations in Canada, but worse than that, a number of people have left ICOD and gone to organizations in other countries.
We have lost people with a specified area of expertise in ocean studies. We should be one of the ranking countries in the world leading the way in ocean development and we have lost these people. I have friends who were with ICOD in Halifax and are now in the South Pacific, in Australia, in the Far East, where governments are prepared to spend some money on the theory of ocean development. Here we are, a country with three oceans, and what are we saying? We are saying we are closing it down. It is a shame and a scandal but it is exactly what one has come to expect from a government that does not merely wear blinkers but a blindfold.
The Law Reform Commission has been totally shut down. It no longer exists. It is inconceivable that a government that is as committed to making Canada more competitive as it says it is would axe those agencies which provide us with an edge, which provide us with the data, analysis and direction which a modem country like ours so desperately needs.
Let me talk about two other bodies we are losing through this bill, that we have already lost: the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada. They were years ahead of politicians in tracking economic and scientific trends world-wide, in illustrating the consequences of these trends for the Canadian economy and Canadian society, and in offering solutions to deal with the problems that would be created.
They are gone. Why? Why are they gone? What does the government see that will replace the development in policy areas of these organizations? With the greatest of respect to my colleagues on the other side of the House, is it going to come from their caucus? Is it going to come from that cabinet? I do not think so. I have not seen anything that would lead me to think that we could get anything in the realm of public policy that might help from that side of the House.
November 26, 1992

I might add that on this side of the House we would never be so presumptuous as to think that could happen. That is not what we are for, that is what these organizations are for. The fact that Canadians will no longer have the benefit of these organizations is a shame and is tantamount to public scandal.
It is deceptive and downright irresponsible for this government to deny that Canadian society reaped tremendous benefits from the small amounts of money that were channelled into these agencies.
There is an old expression: penny wise and pound foolish. This government has been pounds and pounds and pounds foolish.
Let us go back to the Law Reform Commission for a moment and look at some of the things that the Law Reform Commission did in 22 years, from 1970 to 1992. It put out 32 reports, 61 working papers and 76 studies containing a vast spectrum of recommendations covering Criminal Code reform, hate propaganda, plea bargaining, safeguarding genetic heritage, pornography, euthanasia, sexual assault, arson, mental illness, and on and on and on.
As of 1990, Law Reform Commission studies have been cited in 211 Canadian court decisions, 39 of which were in decisions by the Supreme Court of Canada.
That is hardly an example of minimal impact on the people of Canada. That is hardly an example of an organization that did not give value for money. That is hardly an example of an organization that is not vital to the continued health of the legal system in this country, of the judicial system in this country, and indeed the continued health of the citizenry of this country, in a legal sense.
As a result of the dissolution of all these bodies Canadians will be deprived of the following studies that are of great importance to the development of our country: studies relating to the relationship between technology and local economic welfare, a study entitled the "Economics of Health Care and the Economics of Education". How many times have we sat in this Chamber and heard our colleagues on all sides talk about the
Government Orders
absolute necessity of education if we are to compete in a global economy?
How many times have every one of us heard, from the Prime Minister on down, about the sacred trust of our social programs? What is the jewel in the crown of our social programs but health care and medicare? Yet an organization that gives us a study on the economics of health care and the economics of education is trashed by this government. That does not show a whole lot of sense. I am not sure what it does show. I know that it does not show a true concern and care for what is in the best interest of the people of Canada.
Another study that we are losing from the Economic Council of Canada is an analysis of the impact of government on competitiveness. I can imagine why the government dissolved the Economic Council given the title of the study and given the impact of this government on every aspect of the economy in this country. It is an old and tired government that does not want to hear the bad news and does not know how to create any good news.
Another study, from the Law Reform Commission, concerns the ongoing recodification of the Criminal Code of Canada. Where does that leave us? There are studies relating to human rights, to the protection of life and studies relating to administrative law, again from the Law Reform Commission. A vacuum has been created and there has been nothing from this government to show that there will be anything to fill that vacuum.
With the proposed elimination of the Law Reform Commission of Canada we will become one of only three Commonwealth countries without an independent law reform body. The other two are Bangladesh and Zimbabwe.
The Minister of Justice has been trying to silence the Law Reform Commission since 1990 by leaving it without a quorum for two years, which has made it impossible for the commission to approve any reports that would have suggested changes to federal legislation. That shows a level of irresponsibility that is almost unique in the history of this country. Yet we are told by that minister and by other ministers that the decision to close this think-tank is simply a dollars and cents decision.

The minister has said that we have to ask ourselves at this time and in our fiscal situation what can we afford to do. She refers to the Law Reform Commission as a Cadillac approach to legal research. She may call it a Cadillac approach but she has not even left the people of Canada with a horse and buggy approach to law reform.
We have to ask ourselves questions parallel to that question posed by the Minister of Justice. Can we afford not to have a Law Reform Commission? Can we afford not to have an International Centre for Ocean Development? Can we afford not to have an Economic Council? Can we afford not to have a Science Council? Can we afford not to have a country? Can we afford not to have those component parts that decide public policy? Is this government so bankrupt of ideas, so bankrupt of memory of the traditions of this country?

speechtext:
The hon. member for Eglinton-Lawrence says "yes", and he knows I agree with him.
The answer is yes, this government is just that bankrupt. This government is just that cavalier about taking these component parts of the public policy process in this country and throwing them out. It is a cliche to talk about throwing out the baby with the bath water, but that is clearly what the government has done in this case.
The government is not doing anything near an adequate job in dealing with the economy. Everybody knows that. President-elect Clinton had a big sign in his office in Arkansas that said: "It's the economy, stupid". We all know that. Somehow that message has not got through to the people across the floor.
We cannot create legislation or policy in a vacuum. This government has created an intellectual vacuum in this country, and I suggest that in days to come the members of this government led by these ministers will be referred to as the intellectual Luddites of Canadian history.
It is a tragedy that Canadians will not be able to recover quickly from the devastating policies, the ridiculous decisions and the terrible cancellations that this government has hoisted upon us.

Mr. Speaker, this government continues to claim that it is fighting for accessible post-secondary education. Yet the Auditor General's report tells us otherwise.
Here is just a sampling of some of the areas of the Canada Student Loans Program in which the Auditor General gives the government a failing grade.

In 1990 the Auditor General noted that national post-secondary education objectives had not been clearly defined. Two years later these national objectives have yet to be set. The department has not produced an annual report on the Canada Student Loans Program since 1988. While the department has taken some minor remedial steps, much remains to be done to officialize and implement federal-provincial agreements and improve the management information system for student loans.

I strongly urge the government to undertake a full review of the Canada Student Loans Program and take action toward making education accessible to all Canadians.
November 26, 1992

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to report to this House the findings of research on community health services users.
The study revealed an underuse by young women from financially underprivileged families of the services provided such as prenatal programs. While teenage girls are more vulnerable, they do not show a marked interest in the content of community programs. They seem to consider that this model fits neither their values nor their ideas.
I think it is essential to create awareness for people to know what means are at their disposal.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, some bad ideas never go away.
Mr. Frank Dale, president of the Los Angeles based Foundation for Water and Power for North America, has started promoting the old idea of flooding the Rocky Mountain Trench to provide water to the United States. The plan is to direct water from Alaska through the river systems of British Columbia to the U.S.
I spoke to Mr. Dale last night and he is proceeding with plans to hold a conference on February 15 of next year in California to promote this idea.
Along with this issue there are other water diversion projects we are concerned about like Alcan's Kemano project and the plan to divert water from the North Thompson River in B.C. into the Columbia River system.
This government has already sold out our forests, our farms and our fish. Water is our life-blood. I call on this government to state categorically that our water is not for sale.

Mr. Speaker, one of the very positive aspects of the drug patent bill, Bill C-91, is the
significant impact it will have in the area of medical research. I am especially encouraged to learn of the positive effects it will have on research facilities such as the University of British Columbia.
In 1987 changes made to the Patent Act under Bill C-22 triggered one of the largest research and development expansion programs in medical research history. Annual research and development spending by the pharmaceutical industry soared from $102 million in 1987 to $286 million in 1992.
Recently following the government's endorsement of the GATT proposal to eliminate compulsory licensing and the tabling of Bill C-91, forecasts for new research investments are over $400 million.
Bill C-91 will mean more R and D jobs for companies, hospitals and universities like UBC. More and more of our Canadian university graduates will be able to find research jobs in expanding Canadian fields. It will also increase the odds for Canadian people suffering from medical ailments for which there are no cures. We must step up our efforts in medical research and Bill C-91 will certainly assist in this regard.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians and the world have watched with deep concern reports of racist, anti-refugee, anti-ethnic, anti-Semitic attacks in Europe. While it is unfair to let the violent actions of a few characterize a whole society, these unprovoked acts remind us of how important it is that racism be turned back wherever it rears its ugly head.
As we learn from history, if such attacks go unchecked they inevitably lead to far greater consequences. Remember, silence breeds complacency and it must not be left to stand.
Reports that neo-Nazi violence in Germany has resulted in murder arouse terrifying memories. Where will it stop? Along with all Canadians, let us be vigilant at home and abroad against racism of any kind. It goes against basic Canadian values, respecting differences of race, religion, gender and language. As Canadians we must speak out against acts of human hatred wherever they occur in this world.

November 26, 1992

Mr. Speaker, Canadians in general and the residents of the federal riding of St. Albert in particular are becoming increasingly concerned about the rising crime rate in our neighbourhoods.
At the national level we have been working hard to make Canada a safe place to live, implementing the national drug strategy, firearms safety regulations, the Young Offenders Act, the rape shield, the Extradition Act, and corrections and conditional release acts.
This is not enough. This past summer I convened hearings on law and order in my riding. The consensus: There is a great deal of work to be done to ensure our criminal justice system is more responsive to the needs of our citizens. There is a great concern for the victims of crime and the inadequacy of the Young Offenders Act.
On behalf of the constituents of the St. Albert riding, I urge the provincial and federal governments to act.
speakername: Mr. Walter Van  De Walle@St. Albert

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the deregulation of Canada's airline industry has not worked. In fact the Tories' vision of cut-throat competition has brought both Air Canada and Canadian Airlines to the brink of disaster.
Deep in his heart the Minister of Transport knows that the airline industry must be re-regulated, but tragically he cannot bring himself to say the r word. Instead, he suggests that they might recalibrate the transportation policy framework within which the airlines operate.
According to Roget's Thesaurus two of calibrate's synonyms are grade and measure. Does the minister want to grade or measure the airlines? To grade is to classify, differentiate, incline, level, order, size, smooth or sort. Which of these does the minister have in mind for the airlines? If the minister is to measure the airlines,
does he want to calculate, compare, fit, gauge, judge, number, quantify or average them?
I have a suggestion for the minister. He should admit that deregulation has created chaos and then admit that whatever word he uses, the airlines must be re-regulated so they can compete and survive on a rational basis.

Mr. Speaker, November is National Osteoporosis Awareness Month.
A number of people, and I am one of them, are familiar with this health problem, while others are not. Osteoporosis thins the bones and makes them brittle so that they fracture easily. In many cases it can cause serious incapacity, and it can even be fatal.
Educating the public is important, and the Osteoporosis Society of Canada has been doing this since 1982. The funds collected by this organization are also spent on the research that is essential to fight this disease.
The federal government also supports the Osteoporosis Society of Canada through its subsidy program for national volunteer health organizations.
The many volunteers who play an important role in our society are to be commended for their dedication. Thanks to them, the quality of life of people afflicted by this health problem has improved. I urge you all to take part in the activities organized this month to increase public awareness of this health problem.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to call on the federal government to shelve the report of the royal commission on transportation.
November 26, 1992

This report is an insult to every Canadian outside the central Canada corridor. This report ignores the essence of Canada and will put this country, which was once united by the national dream, to the point when we were little more than isolated pockets of population forced to look south rather than east to west.
If a family of four left P.E.I. by car today to go to New Brunswick, it would cost approximately $50 to take the car ferry. If this government implements this report, who knows how much it will cost tomorrow.
Canadians have come to believe in the sharing of responsibility and the sharing of costs which are necessary if this country is to continue as a united entity. It will not do so if the federal government allows the weaker and poorer regions of Canada to wither and die.
I call on the government to reject this report out of hand and reaffirm to Canadians that by living in this great nation they will continue to receive the same rights and privileges regardless of where they reside.

Canada comprises less than 1 per cent of the world's population, and yet at this moment our brave troops are fulfilling 10 per cent of all peacekeeping missions around the globe.
While we are very proud of the thousands of men and women who are on those duties, saving lives and sometimes even saving countries, Canada is serving beyond its capacity. If we are to continue in this role then a few common sense things have to happen. First, the United Nations should immediately pay Canada the millions of dollars it owes us so that we can keep our troops in place. It is unfair to ask Canadian taxpayers to do it all. Second, it is high time other countries paid their fair share. Large and wealthy nations which do not now supply the UN troops should not only do so, but they should help underwrite the major costs of Canada's efforts.
Finally, it is also time that our peacekeepers got the heck out of Cyprus. For 28 years now Canadian taxpayers have kept troops in place there and that is surely long enough.
I call on the government to end this mission now to make sure that Canada's brave troops are used efficiently, effectively and in a manner that is fair to the citizens at home who support them.

Today the NDP government has decided to scrap the Ontario Student Association grant program. This action is shameful. Without these grants many students will be forced to abandon their education.
During the last provincial election the NDP government promised to increase funding for education. Once elected, the NDP betrayed the students and their families by reducing funding for education.
I call on my colleagues to deplore this brutal NDP attack on Ontario colleges and universities and this horrendous assault on access to education. This policy shows that the students are not a priority of the NDP. It simply shows that the NDP do not understand the needs of the students.
Canadians must be aware of the NDP strategies. They make promises to the people but they never follow through with action.
Shawn Rapley, a Carleton University student president, is outraged and Ken Craft, chairman of the Ontario Federation of Students, is appalled at the decision. He said: "They are supposed to have vision, but this vision ends at the end of their nose".
The NDP plan to put an end to student grants is socially and morally regressive and irresponsible. This is another NDP action against something they once said they supported.
If the NDP think this is a solution to bringing its debt under control, they are mistaken. This is not a solution, it is a short-sighted abandonment of our young people, of our educational institutions, and of this province's future.

Mr. Speaker, this week has not provided many examples of co-operation in this place. Indeed visitors and those watching our proceedings may question if there is ever any co-operation here. Well, there is, and I would like to thank all members for one good example.
Earlier this week members of this House gave unanimous consent to declare votable my private member's bill seeking to re-establish the Victoria Cross.
In addition to speeches of support from colleagues on the government side of the House, both the Liberal and New Democratic critics for veterans affairs spoke in favour. The New Democratic Party's critic, the hon. member for Regina-Lumsden, felt strongly enough that

November 26, 1992
Oral Questions
he made an impassioned speech even though he was in considerable physical distress. I understand the hon. member's back pain required his admission to hospital the very same evening. I suspect that he is going to be following the proceedings from his hospital bed. I want to thank him for his support and I am sure on behalf of all members of this House also extend our sincere best wishes for relief and recuperation and an early return to health.

Mr. Speaker, this week over 30,000 members of the Baha'i faith from around the world have gathered in New York City for the second Baha'i World Congress and to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the passing away of their founder, the Baha'u'llah.
Central in the Baha'i teachings are the unity of religions and the unity of all peoples. The Baha'is believe that all of the great religions teach an identical and universal truth. They also believe in the equality of the sexes and the oneness of all people.
The Baha'is take great effort to live their lives in accordance with their beliefs. They work selflessly for the eradication of racial, class and religious divisions and prejudices.
Due to their beliefs, they have suffered much persecution in the 100 years since the founding of their faith. Yet in the present world of terrible racial and religious wars and strife, their message is one of hope. They have faith that a new world order of equality, social and human justice, will prevail. They have faith in the inherent goodness of all people and the awakening of that goodness in us all. It is a very contemporary message needed to be heard in these troubled times.

Mr. Speaker, I was outraged to read on the front page of today's The Globe and Mail of the planned release of convicted paedophile Wray Harold Budreo.
This dangerous offender is to be released tomorrow as a result of the decision by the National Parole Board despite the fact that this decision was not supported by Budreo's case workers. These professionals are as aware as I am that sexual offenders are highly likely to reoffend.
Children are the most valuable and vulnerable citizens of our country. As such we must make every effort to protect them from threats to their safety.
The parole board seems willing to acknowledge that this paedophile with a 30-year record of repeat offences may again reoffend, but it seems to believe this will not cause serious harm. When a child is molested serious harm is done.
Our Solicitor General has said that "protection of society is more important than giving another chance to these individuals who just cannot be rehabilitated". I strongly urge, even plead with him, to do eveiything in his power to overturn this decision of the parole board and to do what he knows is right.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask a question of the Prime Minister.
A lot of people thought there would be economic instability after the referendum. For two weeks it was very stable. Suddenly, 10 days ago, the Prime Minister made a speech and said he would stay the course. Then confidence went away completely. The dollar has fallen and interest rates have gone up by almost 3 points.

When will the Prime Minister instruct the Minister of Finance to stop this crazy policy of fighting inflation at all costs and introduce a policy that will create growth and hope in our nation?

The
idea of suggesting that we should stop fighting inflation is one that would only be applauded by the Liberal backbenchers. In point of fact, in any of the great trading nations that have enjoyed economic resurgence, be it in Germany or in Japan, their success has been built on low inflation.
When my hon. friend was the minister, inflation went to 12.9 per cent. It bloody well just about killed the Canadian economy. That is why we have had to fight and work so hard to bring it down to 1.3 per cent.
Low inflation is an important pillar upon which economic resurgence can take place. Growth and productivity, which is up 5.2 per cent this year, is another important one. Relative unit costs are down by almost 5 per cent over last year. These are all very important factors.
If my hon. friend has some specific ideas as opposed to these easy slogans, let him stand up now, stop the criticism, and give the Minister of Finance the benefit of his wisdom.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, going back to the years when I was Minister of Finance, I am the only one who, over 20 years, had no growth at all in expenditures over a two year period. However, I am not here to talk about 1978 or 1869.1 am here to talk about 1992 and 1993.
In case the Prime Minister thinks I am alone in what I am saying, yesterday I quoted La Presse. Today I will quote, not a socialist rag, but The Financial Post and not Bob Rae's economic adviser, but Diane Francis: "High interest rates have been killing enterprises, strangling the economy, aggravating government deficits, boosting our current account deficit, causing higher taxes, and throwing people out of their jobs. Individuals and businesses, big and small, are being crushed in a vice".
When will the Prime Minister realize the time has come to swallow his pride? When will he realize it is time to have a policy that makes some sense and that will be conducive to creating growth in Canada so that the
Oral Questions
Canadian people can work and have the dignity of working?

What
would that policy be? My hon. friend criticized low inflation in his first question. Now he criticizes interest rates when he was part of a government that had interest rates at 22.75 per cent and we reduced them very substantially to 9 per cent.
As my hon. friend knows, the genesis of the problem in public finances is overspending by governments. There is no question about that. When governments spend too much money, much more than they bring in, eventually the problem grows and it suffocates economic growth.
My hon. friend made a statement that there was no growth at all in public expenditures when he was there. He was President of the Treasury Board between 1974 and 1976 and spending increased 33 per cent. Government spending increased 33 per cent in two years and in that time he entered the history books by saying that a 16 per cent spending jump was great restraint.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, at the time my neighbour here was not even a Canadian. He was in Lebanon. I suggest we stop talking about the past and concentrate on what is happening today.
In the same article in The Financial Post, it says that because of this policy of fighting inflation at any price-I never said we should not fight inflation at all-more than $50 billion has been added to Canada's debt, which means that today, the government has to pay $5 billion every year in interest charges because they fought inflation at the wrong time.
Is the Prime Minister finally going to realize the kind of situation the country is in today? When will he wake up and give Canadians jobs, with a policy based on economic growth?
Mr. Speaker, the International Monetary Fund says that next year Canada will have the highest rate of economic growth in the industrialized world.

Oh, oh.

November 26, 1992
Oral Questions

But that is not important, of course.
The International Monetary Fund also says that next year, the inflation rate in Canada will be the lowest of any major industrialized country. And far more important, the International Monetary Fund states that next year, the rate of economic growth, the rate of job creation in Canada will be the highest of all the G-7 countries.
I think that today my hon. friend will have to admit that despite all the problems in the industrialized world, despite the major problems facing Japan, France, Great Britain, Germany, and other countries, despite this international trend, Canada is comparatively well off, and I say comparatively. It is basically thanks to our focus on policies to maintain inflation at manageable levels while constantly improving our rate of growth, and it works according to our national indicators.

Mr. Speaker, the Auditor General in commenting on loopholes in tax rules for foreign affiliates of Canadian corporations states that "it is reasonable to conclude that hundreds of millions of dollars in tax revenue have already been lost and will continue to be at risk".
Does the Minister of Finance realize that in saying, as he did yesterday, that there is really no conclusive evidence that the amount of money identified as being lost by the Auditor General can be substantiated, that he is doing an enormous amount of damage to the credibility and integrity of one of the most important institutions in the Canadian parliamentary system of government: the Office of the Auditor General?
Is the minister prepared to review those comments in the light of the kind of damage he can do to one of the few remaining respected institutions in this system?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to assure the hon. member and all members of the House that I in no way want to undermine the integrity and the importance of the Office of the Auditor General.
I agree whole-heartedly with the hon. member. I was simply quoting from the departmental response contained in the Auditor General's report which says that the claim as yet has been unsubstantiated.
We are prepared to sit down and review this situation with the Auditor General. Obviously this issue will be before the public accounts committee where it can be fully explored.
If there are some realistic proposals that can flow from this particular finding, I am prepared to look at them. However, I want to reiterate that the Office of the Auditor General is an important one in our parliamentary system of democracy and I in no way want to be associated with undermining the integrity of that office.

Mr. Speaker, in light of the minister's response, would he then be prepared to acknowledge to the House that unlike the response contained in the Auditor General's report from the Department of Finance, this Auditor General is not the first Auditor General to bring up this matter?
In fact Auditors General have been requesting these changes to the tax legislation since 1987 to reassure Canadians that at least the Office of the Auditor General still retains the respect of the government.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, indeed so. The government Whip has just indicated to me that this issue has already been raised in the public accounts committee. I think there is general agreement to proceed with a full examination and to explore all the evidence and all the background with respect to this. We will certainly co-operate fully.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the right hon. Prime Minister who often comments on the value of competition in the effort to keep consumer prices in line.
Does the Prime Minister really believe that it is in the best interests of Canadian taxpayers and Canadian consumers to have a policy that would see the foreign multinational drug companies have an exclusive monopoly on the discovery of new drugs enabling them to charge excessive prices then to consumers? Does he really think that this is in the best interests of Canada, Canadian consumers and the Canadian health system?
November 26, 1992

Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very surprised to listen to that because when Bill C-22 was put in place in 1987 there was an increase of 2.9 per cent in patented drug prices and we had a price index increase of 4.4 per cent. We were far below this increase.

I must also say that there are more than 2,000 patented medications now on the market which can be copied because their patents have expired. Fifty to seventy patents expire every year and the drugs can then be copied by generic drug companies.
That being so I think that increases in the price of patented medicine in Canada have been kept below the rate of inflation. In my opinion this has been a fair and equitable policy for Canadian consumers.

Mr. Speaker, I would think the minister would know that as far as Canadians are concerned, all they see are drug prices escalating. They are continuing to go up in spite of the kind of rhetoric he is able to perpetuate here in the House of Commons.
The right hon. Prime Minister will know that for decades the American drug lobby has been pushing Canadians to give away our fair generic drug programs. Finally, with the Canada-U.S. trade agreement they got there half way.
Now under NAFTA one of the conditions is that they go the rest of the way. As a matter of fact, the other half is being sold out in section 1709 of the impending North American free trade agreement.
Will the Prime Minister confirm that section of the North American free trade agreement will prevent any future Canadian government from changing legislation and restoring the right to issue licences for generic copies of patent medicines?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, everyone knows, and the hon. member should know, that compulsory licences were an exception to patents which throughout the industrialized world are valid for 20 years.
Because the government instituted a fair policy to match that in other industrialized countries, drug companies have invested over a billion dollars since 1987. When we announced changes through Bill C-91, $500 million in investment and job creation were announced.
Last night on the television news Mr. Durivage of Radio-Canada said: "Five years after Bill C-22 passed, the gloomy scenario predicted by this bill's opponents has not occurred. The price of patented medicine increased by only 3.3 per cent". That is the reality.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the minister. Only the minister, his government and the pharmaceutical industry would refuse to admit that the anti-generic drug policy will cost the already beleaguered health care system across Canada hundreds of millions of dollars.
The ministry of health in the province of Ontario calculates that its taxpayers in that one province will be loaded with an extra billion dollars in extra costs over the next decade. Will the minister and his government, rather than trying to support the multinational drug companies, stand up for the health care of Canadians and say no to the multinational drug companies?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is incredible that a member of this House cannot use more accurate information when he talks about health care costs. He should know that patented medicine accounts for only 3 per cent of all the medication used in Canada, so 97 per cent is not subject to the bill he is referring to.

November 26, 1992
Oral Questions

Before saying anything about the health care system, make sure you have good information, please.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance. Since 1986, the Auditor General has recommended that the Minister of Finance eliminate tax loopholes for affiliated foreign corporations. In 1988 when general anti-avoidance measures were introduced the minister did not deal with the problem.
Why does the minister continue to say that he has no money to announce an infrastructure program that would give thousands of Canadians work, while he continues to make gifts to multinationals that do not pay Canada a cent of tax?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I answered that question and I have nothing further to add.
I thought I responded to his colleague indicating that we are prepared to sit down and examine this in full detail with the Auditor General. As I said, in the Auditor General's report there is no substantiation of this. We will sit down and co-operate fully with the committee in exploring this issue.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, this has been going on for six years, since the first report on this matter from the Auditor General. In 1988 the government did not address this issue. In 1992 the Auditor General tells us that $92 billion in investment was given and interest was deducted from those investments which created $4.2 billion of dividends without paying one cent of tax to Canada. Why do ordinary Canadians have to pay high taxes and multinationals pay no taxes?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as I said yesterday and earlier, the government has introduced the general anti-avoidance rule into the income tax system. There have also been a number of loopholes closed that were left by the previous Liberal administration which were costing taxpayers billions and billions of dollars. We took action on that. We have closed loopholes and we will be
prepared to close further loopholes if there is clear evidence.

Mr. Speaker, my question for the Minister of Transport concerns the $50 million in financial assistance offered to Canadian Airlines this week.
I would like to know why the government will not disclose the conditions that have been imposed on that loan. Why has the government not tabled a copy of the loan agreement in the House of Commons? I would like to know whether the real purpose of that loan is to buy the silence of PWA Corporation while the government pursues a one airline objective?

Mr. Speaker, if the member is really intent on saving 16,000 jobs in a region of this country, he should be very careful about what he says. This is not a joking matter. This is a very serious matter.
We have gone into this to save that company by asking them to take some very drastic action. In order to get access to mathematics and figures of the company we entered into a confidential agreement which we will not divulge until the appropriate time.

Mr. Speaker, we are treating this very seriously. Clearly if this loan was given on the condition that PWA will not ask for any further assistance, then it is the largest payment of hush money in the history of Canada.
Two days ago the Minister of Justice acknowledged outside the House that it may be necessary for further loan guarantees to be given. If that is the case, why will the Minister of Transport not acknowledge that more has to be done if there are going to be two profitable national airlines competing in Canada?

Mr. Speaker, we made it quite clear that our main reason for deciding to intervene was the strong employee involvement in efforts to save the company. We agreed to provide one-time financial assistance totalling $50 million, so that the other partners, provincial governments and creditors would also be involved in a solution originating from inside the company, through restructuring and reducing debt, making this a concerted effort on the part of all those concerned about saving Canadian Airlines/PWA.
November 26, 1992

Mr. Speaker, yesterday I asked the Minister of Finance a question about legislation that was tabled in the House today. He was distracted by something else that I said and did not get around to answering my question. I want to give him another opportunity today.
Would the Minister of Finance be prepared, in order to show credibility when it comes to deficit reduction and to sharing the burden of that deficit reduction fairly, to withdraw the legislation which was tabled today having to do with extending the 21-year tax exemption for private family trusts in this country, what some of us have come to call 'the Upper Canada College clause', and show Canadians that this government does not exist just to give tax breaks to the wealthy in this country but that everyone is expected to pay their fair share?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the implication of the question is totally and grossly distorted and I disagree with the observation that the hon. member has made. Therefore on the basis of that illogic, I would not propose to honour his request.

Mr. Speaker, time and time again I have asked this question in the House and I have not been able to get any Minister of Finance to directly address this particular loophole, to justify it or to even mention it.
Do you know what? It is a big, dirty, dark secret what is going on in this country, the way the rich are looked after particularly by this government as they were before by the Liberals.
The money estimated to be tied up in these trusts is in the billions and billions of dollars. If he is serious about reducing the deficit, will he not withdraw this legislation? These people have had 21 years to get ready to pay this tax and they should bloody well pay it as of January 1, 1993.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if the hon. member is
Oral Questions
serious about getting the facts of this issue, why does he not allow the bill to go ahead and let Parliament decide? Maybe after the debate commences on this bill, the hon. member will be enlightened and he might find himself agreeing with the proposition as well.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
The establishment of a centralized immigration centre in Vegreville, Alberta, to replace face-to-face interviews in all parts of the country including the west by a paper review and computers is another crazy move by this government to save an electoral seat.
The pilot project showed that this new system caused longer delays, was inefficient and opened the door to fraud and criminality.
I want to ask the minister how he can justify such a program which so poorly serves both immigrants and the Canadian public and will lose thousands of jobs both in the west and the east? Why is the government giving us such a nonsense proposition?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I see that the Liberal member took his cue from the NDP question of yesterday. That question was answered yesterday.
I saw the hon. member on Newsworld reciting a list of, I hope it is parlementaire falsehoods about this move. This is about taking an office that is open from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., five days a week, and using technological breakthroughs to give the people of Canada 24-hour a day service, seven days a week. This is about trying to reduce the cost to taxpayers of government services.
The big joke of the Liberals is that they talk about security and fraud. Just this year the department issued 31 million cheques of UI out of a system that will be similar to this one and we have not been defrauded by Canadians.

November 26, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, I have had conversations with several immigration officials from his own department and I have been told that this proposal is tragically flawed.
Decisions that once took two days are now taking five and six weeks and the door is wide open to fraud and criminality in the presentation of those applications.

Oh, oh.
[Editor's Note: Disturbance in gallery.]

I want to ask the minister when will the government learn that policy should be based on what is right for the country and not what is right to elect the Deputy Prime Minister? When will the government cancel this ridiculous program?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Warren, next time leave your fan club outside.
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext: If the minister wishes to answer the question he should do so.

Mr. Speaker, on a serious note, the issue at stake here is whether or not the department can take advantage of new technology to give better service to Canadians.
He points to long delays. Obviously the member is not lining up in an immigration office at five in the morning. They line up and they wait maybe three, four or five hours just to put in a little application to an immigration officer. They could obtain the same service by filling in a form which can be processed by a computer which will give quicker service to the person.
This is about better service. This is about less taxes for Canadians and I think they will support it.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is depressing to see a government that seems paralysed and totally at a loss about how to deal with the economy. The recession continues and the deficit keeps building up despite what the government says.
Can the Minister of Finance give us the assurance that his economic statement will contain accurate and reliable forecasts with respect to the deficit as well as concrete measures to create jobs now for our unemployed? Canadians really want to work.

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would argue with the hon. member's contention that we are still in recession. We have had five consecutive quarters of growth, certainly not robust, but it has not been negative growth.
As a matter of fact, in August, we had our strongest performance in over a year. The composite leading index is up, continues to increase and has been continuing to increase over a 17-month period. The help wanted index is up. We have had increases in employment in five of the last six months, 64,000 new jobs created, 83,000 permanent jobs created in the months of September and October.
I will admit that the recovery is not as buoyant as we would like to see it, but Canada is part of a global community. Canada's rate of growth relative to the other global economies is right in line. We see some pick-up in the United States. We are seeing some pick-up in consumer demand. We are seeing some pick-up in department store sales.
I think my statement on Wednesday will help in providing further encouragement and further optimism and hope for the future.

speakerposition: Deputy Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, obviously the government does not understand what is happening with the Canadian economy.
I ask the Minister of Finance: Seeing that municipalities have sewer and water projects ready to go, will this government's economic statement include an infrastructure program shared not only with the provinces but with the municipalities so that Canadians can have jobs as soon as possible?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, one of the biggest expenditures the Government of Canada makes is in the form of transfers to provinces. In terms of cash and the transferal of tax points it amounts to $39 billion a year.
November 26, 1992

The other major transferral is transfers to people, to people who receive old age pension, veterans allowance, family allowance, unemployment insurance. This amounts to almost $42 billion per year.
What I am saying is that the transfers to the provinces are specifically for programs which come under the jurisdiction of the provinces. Municipalities have a responsibility and are creatures of the provinces. Why would the hon. member want us to invade provincial territory?
What we have to do is work together in co-operation. We have had discussions with the provinces. We will try to do what we can, but we will not unilaterally interfere-

speakerposition: Speaker of the House of Commons
speechtext:
I think we should move on.

Mr. Speaker, many small business operators in my riding think they spend far too much of their time filling out government forms when they would rather be taking care of business and creating jobs.
Now the Minister of National Revenue has announced yet more changes concerning how small businesses are taxed. Will these changes actually help our entrepreneurs, or will they just make it easier for the government to tax them?

speakeroldname: Hon. Otto Jelinek (Minister of National Revenue):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the restructuring exercise which I announced to the Canadian Tax Foundation yesterday was designed to make things easier for the small business community particularly. In a nutshell what we are doing is dovetailing all the operations of Revenue Canada into one-customs, excise, GST and taxation-which will make it simpler, more efficient and easier for the small business community.
For example, instead of three auditors, there will be one. Instead of three or four tax returns, there will be one. There will be savings to the business community in the hundreds of millions of dollars and elimination of tonnes of paper which prompted John Bulloch, President of the Canadian Federation of Independent Business, to say yesterday: "Jelinek's announcement will be signifi-
Oral Questions
cant for small companies because of the benefits of one-stop approach".

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of State for Grains and Oilseeds.
This year's Farm Credit Corporation survey shows that the combination of giveaway prices and the 4.2 per cent increase in farm debt has resulted in a further big drop in the net worth of Saskatchewan farm families. This means that since this government was elected the value of farm assets in Saskatchewan has fallen by over $8 billion.
As if this was not bad enough, the changes to the method of payment to the Crow benefit which are being flogged by this government at the present would cause another huge drop in the value of these same farm assets.
Therefore I would like to ask the minister to explain why his government is trying to railroad changes to the Crow benefit which would result in a further undermining of the market value of farmland, threaten the viability of thousands of communities and drive hundreds of farm families from the land.

speakeroldname: Hon. Charles Mayer (Minister of Western Economic Diversification and Minister of State (Grains and Oilseeds)):
speakerposition: Minister of Western Economic Diversification; Minister of State (Grains and Oilseeds)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the premise of the hon. member's question is just not accurate.
There are discussions under way as to how to use the $720 million that is available. Nobody is talking about taking that away from farmers. If there is a change-and I will get to the second part of his question in a minute-the same amount of money will be transferred to the farm community. How he can suggest in any way that is going to lower the price of farm land is beyond me?
Second, there have been all kinds of discussions. We have had four or five meetings federally and provincially with ministers of agriculture to discuss the process. The most recent one was 10 days ago in Toronto. It was agreed then that every government would go back to take a look at a set of draft proposals for discussion and come back some time around December 1 to make some more decisions.

November 26, 1992
Oral Questions
Nobody is attempting to railroad anything. There have been discussions with full public consultation and, above all, with a very good working relationship with the provinces. That in no way can be construed as anybody trying to railroad anything.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the same minister.
The discussions that really count have already taken place, and that is those that occurred with the farmers of Saskatchewan who would be most affected. Over 70 per cent of them said that they did not want to see any change in the payment of the Crow benefit.
Along with promoting the changes in the method of payment, the government is also floating ideas about restructuring the Department of Agriculture and deregulating the industry starting with a wide open free-for-all in the export of barley.
Therefore I would like to ask the minister: Why in heaven's name is this government applying the same model of restructuring and deregulation to agriculture- it has been so disastrous for the airline industry-when what farm families really need is some stability?

speakeroldname: Hon. Charles Mayer (Minister of Western Economic Diversification and Minister of State (Grains and Oilseeds)):
speakerposition: Minister of Western Economic Diversification; Minister of State (Grains and Oilseeds)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, again the hon. member really does not know what he is talking about. As usual it is high propaganda and very low validity.
Let me tell him what has happened since the free trade agreement when we gave producers, and the Canadian Wheat Board included, a better chance to sell into the United States without worrying about the Americans closing their border with their section 22 of the agricultural adjustment act. I will send him over the numbers just so he does not ask these kinds of questions again.
Our exports to the Americans in the last three years since the free trade agreement have almost doubled. That means we sell enough to make them our fourth largest customer. They are the biggest exporter of grain in the world. More important, they are the second highest priced market in the world after Japan. Not a bad record for some opportunity for people to do business on
a set of rules. That is all we are trying to do by looking at regulation in general.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Finance.
Instead of obstinately maintaining a monetary policy that is strangling the economies of Quebec and Canada, I suggest the government face the facts, and the fact is that it is unable to control and reduce the deficit. The easiest and most obvious way to reduce the deficit and cut spending is to get rid of overlapping jurisdictions, starting with manpower.
Why does the government keep refusing to transfer full jurisdiction over manpower to Quebec, which would save $300 million annually right there?

speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
speechtext: That is what you call being consistent.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if that is what you called being consistent, he spent two months telling everybody not to go along with that, and now he wants us to do it.
With regard to the manpower issue raised by the hon. member, I admit that manpower training is a matter of concern, not only to the Government of Quebec but to all Canadian provinces. I am referring to the desire to avoid duplication and overlap. I am sure that no one on either side of the House is particularly keen on duplication because we are all taxpayers.
What we want to do, and this will happen in January when I meet the provincial ministers, is look at ways to maximize harmonization and co-operation and avoid undue duplication and overlap, so that taxpayers get their money's worth.

Mr. Speaker, the minister has just proved that in addition to not understanding the referendum question, he did not understand the answer given by the people of Quebec and Canada. He was never given a mandate to continue with the current overlapping and the attendant outrageous waste of resources.
How long does he intend to ignore the legitimate request made by his friend, Mr. Robert Bourassa, to transfer manpower policy to Quebec?
November 26, 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, at this stage of Canada's economic situation, it is important that all levels of government work together to revive the economy and create the jobs which our people need, and that depends on training. What we need to do is not keep our heads in the constitutional clouds like the hon. member but to get involved with those who are in the market-labour, management, the provincial and federal governments, to and see how we can give our labour force the best training possible so that our economy is competitive throughout the world. That is what we will do.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
The minister will know that the Ontario NDP government will be cutting student grants, moneys needed by college and university students to get jobs. On several occasions the Secretary of State has said in this House that there would be a new student aid program. Last year a government study indicated that the 1984 criteria which have not been updated were totally inadequate.
When the minister makes the economic statement on December 2, will there be a plan to address this particular issue of student assistance, student unemployment? Will the students be forgotten again, or will they simply be treated as the NDP has treated its own students, with more cuts?

speechtext:

From what I recall, about a quarter of a million students are assisted each year and it is a very important program for all Canadians.
I might add that in the year 1991-1992 some $330 million were provided to Ontario students. That was up $100 million from the previous year.
Oral Questions

In his annual report the Auditor General said:
We stress that amendments to the Canada Student Loans Act and
Regulations are urgently needed.
Urgently needed. Can we expect immediate follow-up that will meet students' needs and aspirations? Yes or no, and when?
Hon. Gerry Weiner (Minister of Multiculturalism and
Citizenship): Mr. Speaker, I am sure that the minister will answer soon that a study has been done on the subject and you will have an answer once the minister is ready.

GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in the absence of the Minister for International Trade I will direct my question to the Deputy Prime Minister.
The final negotiations of the GATT round are about to begin next week. Last month the Minister for International Trade met with his counterparts of the European Economic Community and from the United States and did not even raise the question of Canada's supply management system.
I want to know why. Why, with this special opportunity right in Canada, did the minister not raise this important issue to try to influence those ministers to be sure that we got the maximum consideration in the final negotiations of the GATT round which is about to begin?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am surprised at my hon. friend's ill-informed question.

Oral Questions
In fact a number of ministers went just a few months ago, a number of them took the same occasion to be there to speak on behalf of article XI and to call for clarification of it and strengthening of it.
This has been the government's position all along and virtually every minister that touches the trade file has articulated that position.

subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I simply quote the minister from the Canadian Press report.
Last February 40,000 farmers stood on Parliament Hill to protest the lack of action by this government in the trade negotiations. The chief negotiator for the agricultural sector said this morning that Canada had only two countries supporting its position. Last February when the rally occurred there were five.
How can the minister say that this government is serious about negotiations when it only has half the support from other countries around the world that it had six months ago? How can it really say that it is fighting for the farmers?

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre Blais (Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Minister of State (Agriculture)):
speakerposition: Minister of Consumer and Corporate Affairs; Minister of State (Agriculture)
subtopic: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Canada has always done its utmost to defend farmers. Since we received the farmers who came to support us in February, we, the ministers and members here, perhaps not on your side, have received several thousand letters of congratulations and thanks to the government for the position it took to defend farmers.
We are aware that the arrangement reached between the Americans and Europeans will change the Dunkel report. Canadians will be there next week when the negotiations resume in Geneva and we will defend the Canadian position with all our energy. We met all the representatives of the farming community this past Thesday in Saskatoon to inform them of the changes and they will be with us to the end to support Canada. That is how we have acted for nine years, by co-operating very closely with farmers, and we will continue to do so.

Mr. Speaker, I was pleased to see the Prime Minister last week commit to deal with violence on television as he signed a petition presented to him by Virginie Lariviere.
You may recall my private member's motion that was unanimously accepted by this House last February which called upon Parliament to review the media's role in the portrayal of violence against women and children.
I and all members of Parliament have a significant interest in this subject, one I know will take a great deal of perseverance to resolve and one I know we cannot resolve on our own.
My question for the government is therefore: Can the government tell Parliament if it is prepared to give this item priority consideration during an early visit between the Prime Minister and the President of the United States?

Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member mentioned, the Prime Minister last week signed his name when he met with Virginie Lariviere to add his name to the other 1.2 million Canadians who are concerned about this problem.
We have already indicated to Canadian broadcasters that we expect to seek concrete proposals from them at an early date to reduce the level of gratuitous violence on television.
In addition to that, I can inform the hon. member that the chairman of the CRTC will be directly contacting his counterpart with the federal communications commission in the United States to raise this issue as well as raising it with senior people in the American production industry.
I have asked my staff as well to draw up a number of names of potential fora in which we can raise this issue internationally to try to secure the support of other countries as well.
November 26, 1992

Mr. Speaker, it has now been eight months since I have been away from Parliament and it has been almost five months since my heart transplant surgery.
I missed this place. I missed all of you and I missed what this place is about. I missed the honourable activity of politics. I have noted that around here some things change, and others never do. I note, for example, that when you come to the exit door, the green bus still pulls away just as you are approaching and 80 per cent of my mail still has a big red tab on it that says: "Urgent, for member's eyes only" and inside is a magazine subscription.
However I missed being here to help shape public policy and to be effective with my constituents in Crowfoot and for Canada. I want to pay a special thanks to my staff for the very special way in which they took over, helped constituents and worked on behalf of our country.
I want to pay a very special thanks to my wife and my family who were so tremendously supportive, so extraordinarily helpful. They were there not just frequently, but always. I do want to counsel my seven-year old son that I do hope that when he asks the question about when is my next biopsy he will get it straight, and not ask me when is my next autopsy.
Hear, hear.

Mr. Speaker, I want to pay special thanks to the heart transplant team of the University of Alberta in Edmonton. It is a marvellous pool of competence, talent and sensitivity. Here I am. We have the technology, the ability and I am now Parliament's $600 man.
You will notice some changes in me. Obviously, after transplant surgery you are on a number of drugs. Some of them are fairly potent, one of which causes very rapid and different hair growth. I say to the hon. member for Churchill or Notre-Dame-de-Grace or Fredericton- York-Sunbury that I am not in the retail business and they need not come to me. I now have a set of eyebrows that look like they are made from prairie sagebrush. When I come out of my farm home, the great horned owl that nests in the big spruce tree out there dances and gets a little excited. It thinks I am one of them.
Privilege
One thing that happens when you are away is that you come to see this place differently. I want to mention just two things. One I will take just a moment on. One thing about Parliament that is seen different is that of course as political parties we are different in this House. Of course our ideologies are different. Of course our policies are different. Of course we disagree and of course, that is right. That is what Parliament is all about. That is why we are two sword lengths apart.
Mr. Speaker, I got from you, and I thank you for it, a very lovely note as I did from all of my caucus friends. The support was so generous and overwhelming that I was in disbelief at the support. Somehow I expected that too, but I was also surprised. People outside of this place do not know the enormity of comment I received from the Liberals and the New Democrats who said to me: Best wishes, good health and hoped that I would be back soon. I want to thank each and every one of them and Parliament for what all of Parliament is and how we have learned to have civilized debate here.
Hear, hear.

I want to take a moment to just steal another thought. When I was away I came to where I saw news broadcasts in a different light. What I saw was that they appeared as manifestoes of truth. They took on a new predominance. Forgotten was my privilege of being a member of Parliament where I had an inordinate other range of sources by which I could seek other opportunities for research and knowledge. I found out that when the media prepares the seed bed of knowledge, it almost always harrows and seldom ploughs. Moreover, when it does plough it is usually looking for worms rather than for turning up more fertile soil.
By and large the news is too negative. While I was away, I watched dead body TV news broadcasts, features where bodies from Yugoslavia, Somalia, South Africa, airline crashes, convenience store hold-ups or wherever else they might be found. No one would deny that these subjects are newsworthy, but news ought not to be limited to being a catalogue of misery. News disseminators must go beyond presenting an index of what went wrong on a given day. We have a legitimate right to ask: Where are the achievements, the advancements, the excellence, the happiness, the joy, family, camaraderie, peace, opportunity, heroics and a thousand other positive dimensions of human life? I am 55 years of age. Apart from funerals, I have seen one dead Canadian body in my life. In the news death is a daily diet.

Privilege
I am a member of Parliament and I have witnessed excellence and achievements from groups such as women, men, youth, educators, scientists, industrialists, agriculturalists, new Canadians, established Canadians, senior citizens, artists, musicians, across a spectrum of trades and a host of other categories. News tends to be an overemphasis of graphic treatment of violence and disorder. Too much attention is given to champions of wrong.
Many Canadians, unfortunately, are becoming dropouts to news observers and I found it very amazing, the number of educated people that I associated with in hospital who said they no longer watched news. I say to the media: "Scrutinize we who are politicians because you should, but note you enjoy a special privilege. You are uniquely immune from formal criticism. If there is to be hope and happiness, we need a free press but we need one that balances good and evil, hope and despair".
I want to make three quick comments that reflect on my surgery and then take my seat.
I am feeling well. I feel very well. I am also cognizant of the fact that it is only by the coincidence of luck that I and my needs were able to be attended to and corrected because I was among the fortunate whose needs and this technological moment in histoiy coincided. This is not a situation I planned or made happen; it is purely a fact of existence beyond my control. I am grateful for my fortune.
Second, though I have realized this before, now more than ever, I am thankful for being Canadian. Not only am I a citizen in a nation of medical excellence, but also one who was privileged by the reality of our medical affordability. Some other nations as wealthy as ours cannot make that claim.
Third, my present existence is a blessing that is not in disguise. My family's relief flows from another family's sorrow. My opportunities continue because another's ended. My gratitude toward the family of an unknown donor is daily and it shall be life-long. To whomever those persons are and all others who are willing to become organ donors, I express my thanks.
I want you to know, Mr. Speaker, that I would never, even after my inordinate advantage, ask all Canadians to become potential organ donors. First, there is not such an extensive need. Second, there are many who for personal and moral and sometimes religious reasons have cause to resist being organ donors. This is a legitimate opinion and it must be respected.
However for those who upon examining their consciences are willing to allow themselves to be organ donors, I appeal to them now to talk about it with their families and loved ones, affirm their conclusions, and then sign the donor permission card and carry it on their person. Importantly I say: "Don't do it this weekend or over the Christmas vacation or some other time in the near or distant future, but make a note now and do it at your very first opportunity".
In a survey done by the Kidney Foundation of Canada, 90 per cent of respondents expressed a willingness to be organ donors, yet only 20 per cent have talked it over with friends and family or signed organ donor cards.
Today the need for organ donors is much larger than our available capacity, yet our need could be met if only 50 per cent of potential donors had provided an affirmative signal to be one. The need is most acute and most unfortunate among children.
It is an interesting irony that I come from a small community in Alberta, the community of Camrose with only 13,000 persons, and two of us from that area within a month required transplant organs. The two differences between us, significant differences, are that she required a liver and I required a heart. The other difference is that I was nearly 55; she was just 5. But her situation was very critical and very urgent in terms of the amount of time she had left. An organ was found from another community, from another province, and Jenny, a beautiful, ambitious, active child, is healthy and well today. But she is so, again because a program was available.
For the hope of Canadians, and there are so many, I simply plead: "If it is within your conscience to sign an organ donor card, do so because you are being so helpful to so many others".
November 26, 1992

As I take my seat, I want to restate how pleased I am to be back among all members and to be working together on behalf of Canada and Canadians. I wish to share with them that they are as lucky as me for while I have benefited directly from the marvels of modem medicine, all of us as members of Parliament and all us as Canadian citizens have the assurance that Canada is a caring place capable and willing to help should we ever be in a situation where that need occurs.
I say, Mr. Speaker, thank you, Canada; may we always stand on guard for thee.
Hear, hear.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question of privilege to raise with you, but before I do so I want to congratulate and to thank the hon. member for Crowfoot for his very positive remarks and to say how pleased we are to see him back in the House.
During Question Period the Minister of Employment and Immigration associated me with the demonstration which took place in the south balcony. I want to say very emphatically that the demonstration came to me as a complete surprise as much as it did to anyone else in the House. The minister indicated that these were my friends or a fan club. I must tell him that as far as I know I do not know any of them. I did not organize any such demonstration in the balcony and I did not know that one was to take place.
I would hope that the minister would withdraw the suggestion that I had anything to do with that demonstration.

Madam Speaker, during the remarks of the hon. member for Halifax she mentioned on two or three occasions the circumstances lying behind the dissolution of the Law Reform Commission.
I can recall that during committee hearings on the subject of this bill we were definitely made aware of very unfortunate implication, as we saw it, in the dissolution of the Law Reform Commission.
