The Law Reform Commission had evolved into a vehicle capable of listening to and accommodating the views of our judges with respect to law reform in a non-partisan comprehensive and appropriate way.
November 26, 1992

Now that the Law Reform Commission is to be dissolved, I suspect many of the judges across this country who want to participate are losing this very unique vehicle. I wonder whether my colleague from Halifax has a perspective on that in her own experience as an MP and as a lawyer.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I do have some thoughts on that.
There has been a great deal of discussion both here and outside of this Chamber, regarding the role of judges in our legal system. They have very little or no opportunity in their current incarnation to have input into public policy in the research and development way. They have the ability to write decisions on those questions put to them in the courts and in the normal way if they happen to be appellate court judges. Obviously there is a limiting factor there.
Other levels of the judiciary, particularly those at the most active level in dealing with the public, which are known in my province as provincial magistrates, have no opportunity of the kind my hon. colleague mentioned.
I have risen many times in this House and discussed the need for mandatory training of judges, for example, in gender sensitization. I would hazard a guess that if the Law Reform Commission were still in existence, a number of judges would see the problems with gender sensitization, not just within their own brethren and sisterhood, but across the board in our society because of the cases they face. Indeed, they have now lost the opportunity to input this kind of data into a body such as the Law Reform Commission.
There is another area of great concern to Canadian women that would have been an area the Law Reform Commission would have studied. That is the whole area of sexual harassment. There is not a woman in this country, Madam Speaker, and I know you agree with me on this, who has not had to deal with this pernicious development at some time in her existence.
This week I have twice raised a situation in this House relating to two of my constituents, members of the Public Service of Canada, who have lodged a complaint founded on sexual harassment. I also raised this point last week.
Government Orders
It is absolutely clear to women within or without the public policy area of this country that the whole question of sexual harassment is not fully understood by many of our male colleagues, males in managerial and senior positions and many department heads. It is my strong impression, particularly following the problems with Anita Hill, Clarence Thomas and the Senate judiciary committee in the United States, that the area of sexual harassment is the newest area for deep response from organizations such as the now defunct Law Reform Commission of Canada.
It is a tragedy we no longer have this vehicle. It is a tragedy for the judiciary in this country. It is a tragedy for lawyers, but most particularly, it is a tragedy for the people of Canada.
I would hope that before any of us are very much older we will see a resurgence of a body similar to the Law Reform Commission of Canada through some form of intervention .

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I want to enter into the last stages of this debate. I think the discussion which has taken place with respect to elimination of these institutions has ranged across a wide number of different areas, but deserves to be focused as we come close to the end of the debate.
We really have a question before us as a country, as a Parliament, as members of this House of Commons, whether we are prepared to invest a small number of resources to ensure expert continuing input is provided to us on an independent basis as policy making goes forward.
As things stand at the moment, for instance, in the area of economics and economic policy, there is not a single institution in this country that has the responsibility to act independently to provide policy advice to governments across this country or, in other words, to fill the role the Economic Council previously filled.
We can look at some of the institutions the government has talked about as being able to fill this role, such as the Fraser Institute. It is very much shaped by a specific ideological view of the world and very much supported by large scale private business.

Government Orders
The C. D. Howe Institute has a slightly different perspective of the world and is again supported by private business. There is also the Conference Board of Canada. These are all reputable institutions and contribute important viewpoints which are helpful to government, but not from an independent perspective because of their source of funding.
In the case of the Conference Board, for instance, the funding again comes entirely from private business.
The University of Toronto Institute for Policy Analysis provides some policy advice, but at a very arm's length basis from political reality in many cases. It is funded partially by the private sector and partially by the public sector but through the university mechanism.
There is a problem with all these forms of institutional support and policy advice. There is not a large enough gathering together of resources to support the detailed research and large scale projects that are often needed in a much more complex world to get at the heart of economic issues which have to be understood in this relatively small country in financial and population terms. TTie same thing is true of many of the institutions we are talking about eliminating with this piece of legislation.
The Science Council of Canada has provided important advice in the past to government, not just about science and how to deal with science, but advice about the economy and how science should be brought into a more powerful and contributing role in our economic growth in Canada.
We can talk about institutions like the Law Reform Commission, and the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. All of these institutions have filled a tradition in this country which governments have previously been proud of. It is a tradition where institutions have the freedom to act and yet are provided with financial support on an arm's length basis.
This tradition is not just limited to this country. We can look at other countries in the world and see they too have institutions of this sort which play a similar role. For instance, France has a social and economic council with 200-plus members who meet twice a month. It has a large research staff. It provides important information
and advice on economic and social issues to the government.
Japan has the Japan Economic Research Centre. The United States has the Council of Economic Advisers, which is again supported by various research staff. The United Kingdom has the National Economic Development Council.
It is true we have some institutions in this country that still live. We have institutions like the Canadian Labour Market and Productivity Centre and the Canadian Labour Force Development Board. They are able to operate with some independence and provide some advice, but frankly not with the depth of financial support some of these research institutions which we are winding up with this legislation have had to contribute in the past.
What if we were being asked to judge these institutions by the government and it said it was not certain whether they were contributing to the country or not? Perhaps the government would have an independent inquiry, or even a parliamentary committee probe their contributions and give some kind of independent assessment of what these various institutions have been and could contribute to the country.
If these independent inquiries and reviews had come back and said to Parliament these institutions were costing too much money, were not providing independent advice or contributing to better policy making and therefore they should be eliminated, that would have been a sensible route for a sensible government to take in policy analysis.
Instead, we had a government stand up on budget day, having given at most two or three hours warning to these institutions, and simply decide to eliminate them without any assessment, without any review, and without any chance for the people of Canada to analyse the contributions that these institutions have made to our country.
I have to make the assessments myself. It seems to me, from what I know of it and I have not had an independent review to help me, that it does make sense to eliminate the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council.
November 26, 1992

It seems to me we have other institutions that can provide independent advice and help, such as the Canadian Labour Force Development Board and the Canadian Labour Market and Productivity Centre.
When I look at the other institutions I do not see that. I do not see the way in which their work is going to be replaced, and I do see immensely valuable contributions that these institutions have made in the past and could make in the future.
For instance, I think of the work of the Science Council in analyzing some of the problems with multinational corporations and their activities in this country. It is work which led to new approaches on the part of policy makers to try to push multinational subsidiaries in this country to begin using their branch plants in Canada as bases for development and export of particular specialist product lines.
I think of the work of the Economic Council of Canada in examining the question of our relationship with developing countries in a very detailed study called Toward a Common Future. It developed a set of recommendations which in many ways have led government to recognize that trade, and trade relations, with developing countries is the most important way in which we can help poor countries in the world to expand their economies and to achieve development success.
Those countries have benefited as a consequence of the Economic Council's work. I think of the work of an institution like CUPS which has been out in the high schools providing information to our secondary school students so they have a better understanding of the complex changes taking place in the world.
I think of the International Centre for Ocean Development which, as well as contributing to Atlantic development, to the development of our Atlantic provinces, made useful suggestions and developed and administered useful projects in various Third World countries to help them build up their fish resources for the future.
At no stage has the government ever justified the elimination of any of these institutions. At no stage did the minister appear before committee and attempt to explain why the Economic Council should be guillotined or why the Science Council should be put before a firing squad.
Government Orders
At no stage were these kinds of explanations given, either to the House of Commons or to the people of Canada. Instead the government simply moved ahead and eliminated a whole set of institutions; a set of institutions whose one common thread seems to be the fact that they were established under the auspices of another political party. The Economic Council of Canada, the Law Reform Commission, ICOD, CUPS, all of these institutions were established under Liberal governments. Despite that, I say as a New Democratic that they have done useful, non-partisan work.
However, this government, a Conservative government, decided that it had to get rid of them. It has justified that by saying that this was going to save people in Canada tremendous amounts of money. My colleagues this morning and last night clearly demonstrated that there were other immensely more profitable areas to tackle if the government wanted to save money. It could have saved millions by enforcing taxation more effectively and it could have saved billions by seeing to it that family trusts were not given a free ride in tax terms in the future.
Did the government choose those areas to move in? It did not. Instead, it chose to move in what can only be analyzed, in the end, as a partisan means of eliminating institutions to which it objected for reasons that could only be understood, it would appear, in political terms. It is shameful that this was the approach taken by this government.
What is even more shameful is that having decided to eliminate these six institutions the government then brought before policy makers of this country the so-called prosperity report which recommends the establishment of six new institutions in this country. They are she new institutions to deal with the economy, to deal with the teaching of science in our schools, to deal with questions of quality in the production processes of our country-many of the issues which these institutions being eliminated were already dealing with.
It is unforgivable to see stupidity being implemented for partisan reasons. It is even more unforgivable to see that stupidity revealed for the hypocrisy it is by suggesting a short seven months later that we establish a whole new set of expensive institutions which I am certain will cost us far more money than the minor amounts to be saved by killing off these institutions that provided a

November 26, 1992
Government Orders
forward guidance system for the policy-making process in Canada.
I stand in the House as somebody who worked, before I joined this House of Commons as an elected member, with the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada. I have seen them from close up.
They are non-partisan, thoughtful institutions trying to contribute to the betterment of this country's future, and they have been butchered. They have been butchered by a government that has not seen the responsibility it has to maintain independent thinking in the future of our country's government.
I hope that this piece of legislation will be rejected. I hope that it will be possible for us to recognize fairly and independently the value contributed to this country by these institutions that this government is seeking to kill.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to contribute to the debate today by pointing out what Canada will lose when the Science Council of Canada goes. The council was created in 1966 when Mr. Pearson was Prime Minister of Canada. When the council was inaugurated, Mr. Pearson said that it was in the interest of governments and Canadians to receive advice from an independent body on establishing constructive links between science and technology on one hand and economic growth, resource development, health, the environment and national infrastructure on the other.
He charged the new agency to draw upon all the wisdom of the natural sciences, pure and applied, as well as the social sciences and humanities. He stressed how important it was to apply the scientific talent of Canadians to social problems that affect the whole world and to evaluate the impact of science and technology on society. That was in 1966.
Since then the Science Council of Canada has met Mr. Pearson's challenge. According to its last chairman, Janet E. Halliwell, the production of the Science Council of Canada is rich and multi-faceted. We need only consider the publications following more than 25 years of study: working papers, workshops, lectures and studies.
These publications are a solid collection of summary documents, analyses and policy papers, widely recognized in Canada and abroad, as the frequent references to them in national and international literature attest.
The council's most important function perhaps has been education, not in the sense of acquiring knowledge but of helping people to rethink old problems in new ways and to identify new issues and new challenges. The council had about 20 members who came from all parts of the country and all backgrounds: the private and public sectors, industry, government, education, medicine and so on. Of course the council brought together French and English speaking people. I would like to return to the Science Council of Canada's national vocation in a moment.
I should also point out that with the exception of the chairman and vice-chairman of the council, members worked without remuneration. The Science Council gave them an opportunity to discuss the various problems being analysed by the council and consider possible solutions.

In a letter to members of the committee which studied this bill to dissolve the Science Council and the other commissions such as the Law Reform Commission and the Economic Council, Janet Halliwell, the last chairman of the council, observed that while the council's work extended to many subjects there were perhaps two themes which dominated and influenced Canadians over the course of the past 25 years and the understanding that we have of science and technology and society. These two subjects are what is today called competitiveness and sustainability, words which were not in vogue perhaps 15 to 20 years ago but which nonetheless have preoccupied the council for the past 25 years.
From its beginning the council consistently stressed the need for Canada to become more innovative. I believe that Ms. Halliwell is right to say that the council's work has had a profound impact on the national agenda and that the council's thinking underlies the government's current prosperity initiative. Witness the fact that Ms. Halliwell was asked by the government to co-chair the task force on science, technology and related skills which was one of the task forces which made up the prosperity initiative.
November 26, 1992

With respect to sustainable development, the Science Council anticipated the Brundtland report by more than 10 years in a report entitled "Canada as a Conserver Society''.
With this record, it came as a shock to many people that the Science Council would be unceremoniously dissolved by the government. Of course this decision was announced in the February budget. The decision to abolish the council was taken without formal evaluation of its work or consultation with the chairman or the members of council. Indeed, the chairman was advised that the winding down of the affairs of the council should not be considered a negative comment on the work of the council.
The Minister of Finance has said that other groups can do the council's work. Perhaps he had in mind the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology which is chaired by the Prime Minister. NABST does not operate independently from the government. On appointment, the members of that board take an oath of secrecy. Its reports are not always made public or are often made public after considerable delay.
Professor John Polanyi, the 1986 Nobel prize winner in chemistry, who has been a member of the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology, appeared before the legislative committee studying this bill and explained that governments must have not only in-house sources but arm's length sources. "Why is that", he asked. He answered that in-house advisers have to deal with immediate crises. They often cannot afford to take a longer view and are subject to political constraints. They do not report directly to the public and sometimes they do not report at all to the public. That is why we need independent, arm's length bodies.
Canada is left with only two independent long-range research organizations that are examining science policy and innovation and both happen to be located at the University of Quebec in Montreal. Neither has the integrated strength, national purview or scope of the Science Council. I believe it is accurate to conclude, as did Ms. Halliwell: "The demise of the Science Council will sharply reduce access to independent in-depth
Government Orders
analytical work in science and technology policy, the underpinning of good decision making".
The government has said the motive for terminating the Science Council is to save money. This is a motive we all share. However as Professor Polanyi put it: "The money being saved by the dissolution of the Science Council is about $3 million per year". It sounds like a lot of money but as he said: "It is a trivial sum compared to the cost of just one technological error".
Dr. Polanyi also told the committee that if we abolish the Science Council we will have to recreate it, and he listed a number of considerations which we should look for in the existing and in the future Science Council. I would like to review three of these considerations.
First, he said it must be credible, which means it must be in touch with the scientific community. It also takes time to establish credibility and that is why it is such a tragedy we are losing the 25 years of experience we have in the Science Council. Credibility is item one and the Science Council had that.
Second, the Science Council must be fair and recognize a range of views and that is exactly what the Science Council did.
Third, the body must be visible. On this point Dr. Polanyi felt that the Science Council may get less in the way of good marks. It has to be visible he said to scientists, to scholars, the public, the media and decision-makers.
I would like to add a word or two on this point. I am concerned that MPs are not organized to benefit from the work of the Science Council or other groups that provide similar advice such as the groups at the University of Quebec or the National Advisory Board on Science and Technology. I believe we will have to make changes if we wish to benefit from a future Science Council.
Let me explain what I mean. Until 1986 the miscellaneous estimates committee dealt with the scientific and technological activities of the Government of Canada. It was that committee which reviewed the work of the Science Council and its reports, studied the activities of the National Research Council and the government

Government Orders
departments that deal with industry, science and technology.
In 1986 as part of parliamentaiy reform, the Standing Committee on Research, Science and Technology was created. One of the major features of reform was to give more power to committees and part of this power was the ability to undertake a study independently without a reference from the House of Commons. Also committees with a smaller membership were supposed to lead to specialization.
I regret to note that the enthusiasm for reform lasted about two years. By 1988 most of the smaller committees that were established in 1986 were merged into larger ones. Research, science and technology were lumped together with industry, regional and northern development. The committee's work I must say is hampered by changing membership.
In the United States the membership of congressional committees operates under rather strict rules of seniority. Adopting rules of that nature might improve the effectiveness of our own committees.
What I am trying to say is that while we might want a future science council to be more visible and to have the ear of decision makers, it is for decision makers, including members of Parliament, to listen and to organize themselves in a fashion that we are able to listen to the advice and to understand the reports that come from groups like the Science Council.
In closing, I want to add just one word about the national vocation of the Science Council of Canada. As I said before, we are left really with no national body to look at science and technology policy issues from a national perspective and from an arm's length perspective.
As I mentioned also, the Science Council was unique in being a national body in that it brought together anglophones and francophones from all over the country. By its mission and composition the Science Council helped secure both as prosperous and harmonious future for Canada.

I would like to quote Mr. Goyette, who wrote to the Science Council of Canada when it was announced the council would be dissolved. Mr. C. Goyette is president of a company in Montreal called Corestham. Mr. Goyette said that the Science Council provided a vision
of technological and scientific development commensurate with the reputation of this country, and capable of steering us successfully through the critical nineties. The council also had a unique network of scientists and engineers who, as reflected by their ties with the business and academic world across Canada, proved that the various regions of this country can work together and also reach a consensus on a vision of the future".
In concluding Mr. Goyette said: "On the basis of my experience, I can state that the Science Council was an essential component of Canadian unity".
The dissolution of the Science Council not only deprives us of an agency that would help us prepare for the future through an understanding of the challenges of science and technology, but also of another agency and institute that brought Canadians together and contributed to national unity. That is why all Canadians should and indeed must regret the dissolution of the Science Council.

The government side has indicated that their principal purpose in doing this is to make a leaner, meaner government. I know in his remarks the hon. member was just drawing toward telling Canadians where the funds to keep them going were going to come from.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
I thank the member for Skeena for his question. I guess in the months leading to the actual closing of the Science Council, in the time between the budget and the end of June when the Science Council had to close its doors, the chairman, Janet Halliwell, prepared a proposal to revive the council known as the Phoenix Project. She hoped this new institute would be modelled after the Carnegie Institute in the United States. Funding would be provided by a number of sources, including the private sector and provincial governments, but certainly required a commitment from the federal government.
On April 8 I asked the Minister for Science when he appeared before the Standing Committee on Industiy, Science and Technology whether the federal government would be prepared to participate in the funding of such a new institute. His answer was no, flatly no, no interest whatsoever from the government.
November 26, 1992

We learned that the Phoenix Project would never see the light of day and that the government was not interested in preserving the council in any form.
Perhaps at some point such a council can be recreated as a purely private initiative. I am somewhat doubtful. I have spoken to people who have been close to the council and people who are in the private sector. They do not feel that the funding can be obtained solely from the private sector for this kind of initiative. There will have to be some kind of government funding if we wish to recreate the council some day. Such a council would perhaps be housed at a university or some other institution where it might be on firmer footing than as just an agency of the federal government, as it was in its first incarnation.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am happy to have the opportunity to speak on Bill C-63, an act to dissolve or terminate certain corporations and other bodies.
Canadians should know, and I want to repeat for them, the organizations that we are dissolving this afternoon: the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Economic Council of Canada, the International Centre for Ocean Development, the Law Reform Commission and the Science Council of Canada.
When the rest of the world is talking about training, retraining and creating centres of excellence we in this country are dissolving six institutions that contain some
Government Orders
of the best and brightest minds that our country has ever seen. They have been producing ideas on a whole range of issues.
I think specifically of the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada. These two institutions have been generating ideas for debate not only for this legislature but for every other legislature in the country. They have also provided specific information to those in the private sector who were interested, some of it concerning corporate development in the business sector and the education sector.
What bothers me most is that the government is suggesting that this entire operation is being done in the interest of addressing the deficit and debt of this country.
This government does not understand that as it proceeds on this course of cutting and dismantling these instruments it is weakening the galvanization process of this country. That is one of the things that really affects confidence.
I remember in 1961 when John F. Kennedy said: "We are going to put a man on the moon". That one sentence triggered a reaction which galvanized the will of the American people. That one sentence triggered a reaction in the grade schools, high schools, colleges, universities and think-tanks all over the United States. They said: "Yes, when we work together, when we have a hopeful thing to look forward to we can raise our productivity levels and we can become creative". These exercises in creativity produce all kinds of spin-off opportunities for job creation.
I believe that President-elect Clinton will be a catalyst for galvanizing the will of Americans once again. That is what we are missing in this country. We are missing that one big idea that will pull us all together, that idea of hope that will make us all feel good about ourselves and cause us to have the level of confidence that will cause us to spend again and will cause our job creation mechanisms to start kicking into place again.
If one good idea came from these institutions, I refer specifically to the Economic Council of Canada and the Science Council of Canada, that could trigger a change in the mind-set of this country then that alone could pay for all these institutions for the next 10 years or 20 years.

November 26, 1992
Government Orders
I am totally sympathetic with the notion that we must be cost efficient, that we must not waste and that we must not abuse taxpayers' money. I will not argue any of those points. However, what is really lacking in this country right now is the feeling that it is a good thing to be creative, that it is a good thing to unleash that creative process.
These institutions were internationally respected think-tanks. They did not always come up with ideas that could be used. They have not always come up with ideas that I have agreed with. However, they were instruments for advancing the debate, which is what is lacking in our country today.
The whole exchange, the whole concept of advancing debate is really stifled. It is only when the best and the brightest of minds are fully exercised in debate that we will generate ideas that hopefully will put this country back on a path to economic prosperity.
When I think of these organizations being dismantled I just cannot understand where the government is coming from. How much are we truly going to save? What are we going to do with these minds, with the human capital that exists in some of these institutions?
I am sure that some of this human capital, this great talent, is going to be transferred to other sections of government so that they will still be an expense to the taxpayer. Their data bases and libraries are being dismantled. They are moving some of them to Toronto. I do not know where all the data bases are being moved, but I am sure they are going to be parked in different sections of government, in different parts of the machineiy of government.
Think of the cost we are going to incur when we bring similar think-tanks back. We are going to have to reconstruct all the dismantling that is going on. I just cannot figure out where the government is coming from on this particular question.
I listened to the Minister of Industiy, Science and Technology talk about the prosperity initiative. I listen to the government when it talks about the fact that we must become globally competitive, must put more dollars into training, and must stimulate the community and stimulate the idea process to create new products at more competitive prices. I hear all these statements, but this action flies right in the face of them.
I refer specifically to the Science Council and the Economic Council of Canada. These are two of the finest think-tanks anywhere in the world. To chop them is the type of retreat by national governments that I am ideologically opposed to.
In the private sector we are encouraging people to put money into research and development. Two and a half years ago one of our more successful companies in this country, Magna International, which I had the privilege and experience of working with, had a very difficult time because of the downturn in the economy. The levels of profit had vanished and there was pressure from financial institutions to try to get this organization back on track.
Yes, there were some streamlining initiatives and steps that were included in the revised business plan but the one thing that salvaged Magna International, put it right back on track and made it once again one of the most profitable organizations in North America, employing close to 20,000 people, was the fact that it had a solid research and development centre. It was able to diversify its products because there were creative minds in that company who were given the resources to create new products at better prices and with better quality. That is what brought it out of the depths of this tough economic period.
What I do not understand is that when there are creative centres of excellence like the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada, if anything, we should be supplementing their budgets because right now we are looking for one or two ideas that will galvanize the will of this country, pull this country together, and give us the confidence to start moving again.
This government once again is not demonstrating the vision it should when times are tough. In my opinion, when times are tough we should not promote less but more. We have think-tanks with the best and brightest minds in the country working in a non-partisan manner for the good of the nation. When instead of encouraging them and giving them the tools and necessary environment to come up with something to give us guidance and lift us out of this demise the government writes them off it shows me that it is missing the very point. The government is missing the very thing that is required to help pull us all together and help put us back on track in terms of this economic malaise we are in.
November 26, 1992

I can only hope that something happens between now and the time when the final axe is dropped. Maybe there will be some kind of death-bed conversion. I salute the Prime Minister for admitting just a few days ago that he had made some mistakes in the last few years. Well, maybe for the sake of $3 million or $4 million he could admit that this is one of his mistakes and keep these fine institutions going.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands) moved
speechtext:
that Bill C-350, an act to amend the Criminal Code (hate propaganda), be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to rise today to move second reading of this important but very short bill.
This bill is an amendment to section 318.(4) of the Criminal Code of Canada. That section prohibits the incitement of hatred against an identifiable group. I quote from the words of the act: "distinguished by colour, race, religion or ethnic origin".
The bill would amend this section of the Criminal Code by adding to the list of persons or groups of persons, those who are distinguished by age, sex, sexual orientation or mental or physical disability.
This bill is based on a resolution which was passed last February by the Kingston Police Services Board. The board prepared this resolution after receiving complaints from members of the public who were upset with various comments in the press particularly, but comments these persons believed promoted hatred against segments of society which were not protected by the wording of the Criminal Code as it now stands.
The citizens were upset with statements which suggested, for example, persons infected with AIDS or HIV should be cast out from society and somehow excluded from the normal living standards the rest of us have come to expect because it was some kind of punishment they deserved for having contracted this disease.
It was felt that by changing the words of the act this kind of nonsense could be stopped because it would constitute hate literature and would not be published.
I believe this particular section is important in our country. It is a hole in the law, notwithstanding the fact that prosecutions under section 318(4) of the Criminal Code have been exceedingly rare. I do not want to go into the history of prosecutions under this section particularly. I do not think they are terribly relevant today, but I must say prosecutions have been exceedingly
November 26, 1992

rare under this section either successful or otherwise. I understand very few have been launched but I do not have precise figures on that.
By expanding the wording of the section I believe we can help create a fairer society for persons who suffer as a result of the publication of hate literature. I also believe some of the material I have seen occasionally must come very close to, if not constitute literature that does promote hatred against one of the identifiable groups I have listed in Bill C-350.
I want to thank the Kingston Police Services Board for drawing this hole in the law to my attention. I was pleased to be able to have this bill drafted and submitted to the House and that it made its way through the tortuous process of Private Members' Business to be drawn and made available for debate today. Unfortunately it was not chosen as a votable item. I would hope at the conclusion of the debate today there might be unanimous consent to allow the bill to receive second reading, notwithstanding that it is not votable, and have it referred to a legislative committee so it could be studied there. I do not think there would be general objection to the bill or any aspect of it in the House.
Looking at the history of this bill, section 318(4) of the Criminal Code was introduced into the code in 1970. The debate that took place then was a fairly vigorous one. There was considerable opposition to including hate literature as something that should be prohibited in Canada. The argument was very clear, that it was an infringement on the right of freedom of speech. There is no doubt it is an infringement on that right. It was introduced as such an infringement and it was clear the purpose of the infringement was to limit people in their exercise of their right of freedom of speech from carrying on in a way that was harmful and incited hatred for others.

Why are these changes that I propose today so important? Frankly I think the world has changed since 1970. In 1970 the House was prepared to agree to a list that included colour, race, religion and ethnic origin. Since that time we have become much more aware of the women's movement, for example, of the importance of the elderly and of young people and the violence that is done to both age groups in our society. We have been through the International Year of the Disabled and our awareness of persons with disabilities is far greater in 1992 than it ever was in 1970.
We have changed our approach in dealing with these people in a host of ways. We have allowed them and encouraged others to raise awareness of the problems that are confronted by persons who fall into these categories. In so doing, we have not made the law sort of catch up with the way we feel about these kinds of groups and the way we have reacted to these kinds of groups and responded to their concerns. Because the groups have become vocal and are expressing the needs, wants and desires of the members of their groups, they naturally have raised their profile and have become subject to attack. It is that kind of attack when it takes the form of hate literature that this legislation is designed to prevent.
The purpose of the legislation is to protect these groups from this kind of hatred, from this kind of publication. The need was simply not there in 1970 because these groups were not as active, were not as vigorous, and were not promoting the rights and responsibilities of their members the way they are today.
Some may say it is unfortunate that we have groups promoting their rights, that it is very divisive in our society. It may be. However I am prepared and I think most members of this House are prepared to live with those divisions. We have all become accustomed to those divisions. What we have tried to do is say: "Yes, we recognize that you have a legitimate role to play as an advocate for the group that you represent". The interests of the members of that group are very important. We try to balance those interests and create a situation
where all citizens are treated fairly, regardless of the distinction that is based on the items I have listed.
By seeking to protect those differences, those different rights, and the specific rights that belong to each one of us, I think we are safe in saying that we should protect those rights by ensuring they are not made the subject of hatred by reason of the publication of hate literature. That is why I think this amendment is so important.
Our society has aged and perhaps that has something to do with why we would want to include age in such a list. Certainly sex has been a subject of considerable debate for the past decade at least. I am sure, were my colleague from Halifax here, she would want to say something on that subject and the importance of the changes that have taken place in women's rights in this country in the last 10 years or 15 years. That was not an issue in 1970 to the extent that it is today. Public awareness was simply not there.
These changes, while they may seem very simple and very basic, are ones that frankly are moving to bring the law into the latter part of this century, certainly into the 1990s. Had these issues been simmering at the point they are now simmering or boiling, however we want to describe it, in 1970, they would have been included in the original amendments to the Criminal Code. But they were not and so we are faced with a situation where I think the code should be brought up to date and that is what I have sought to do by this amendment, having been urged to do so by the Kingston Police Services Board.
I do not think there is much I can add to explain the bill to hon. members. As I say, perhaps at the conclusion of the debate we might look at the possibility of expediting the bill, giving it second reading and forwarding it to a legislative committee. Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the opportunity to address the proposals which have been advanced in Bill C-350 by the hon. member for Kingston and the Islands. I know the hon. member for Kingston and the Islands and I know his interest in legal matters and reform of the legal system. I have had the opportunity to serve with him on the privileges and elections committee. I enjoyed that very much and I am pleased to take part in this debate today.

Bill C-350 proposes that the definition of identifiable group as found in section 318 of the Criminal Code be expanded to include the terms age, sex, sexual orientation or mental or physical disability.
The issue embodied in this bill is one of fundamental importance. Parliament in the past has seen fit to provide for the prohibition of hate propaganda against an identifiable group as is currently defined in the Criminal Code.
The hate propaganda provisions restrict at present the freedom of expression in Canada, but they do so in order to prevent injury to members of the identified group and to the public at large. They do it in such a way as to be viewed as a reasonable limit on the guarantee to the freedom of expression.
I note the hon. member introduced this bill last June. In August the Supreme Court of Canada held in its decision, Regina v. Zundel that section 181 of the Criminal Code, spreading false news, violated paragraph 2(b) of the charter which protects freedom of expression and was not justifiable under section 1 of the charter. Section 181 of the Criminal Code prohibited knowingly publishing false statements causing or likely to cause injury to a public interest. Accordingly it was ruled by the court that this section was unconstitutional and of no force and effect.
The finding of the Supreme Court of Canada that section 181 is unconstitutional may have some impact on the hate propaganda provisions of the Criminal Code. One wonders whether this decision has created a gap in the law, in our ability to deal with hate propaganda, in the sense that conduct which would have previously been prevented or deemed illegal by virtue of section 181 would no longer be caught by that section which has been overturned.
It would be useful to study this decision of the Supreme Court of Canada and then assess its implications for government policy in the area of criminal law generally and on the issue of the relationship between freedom of expression and hate propaganda in particular.
It is important to remind the House in this regard that attempts by accused to have the courts strike down the hate propaganda provisions of the Criminal Code have been successfully resisted.
In the case of Regina v. Keegstra the Supreme Court of Canada by the narrowest of margins upheld subsection 319(2) of the Criminal Code, otherwise called wilfully promoting hatred, as a reasonable limit of the
Private Members' Business
guarantee to freedom of expression within the meaning of section 1 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. It agreed that there is a societal interest in prohibiting hate propaganda.
In examining the definition of identifiable groups in section 318 of the Criminal Code, in the context of whether the subsection could be a reasonable limit the majority of the members of the court in a five to four decision, a narrow decision, noted that the provision of the Criminal Code was targeted against the intentional fostering of hatred against particular members of society as opposed to any individual.
Subsection 318(4) defines the expression identifiable group as meaning "any section of the public distinguished by colour, race, religion or ethnic origin". Expanding the definition would broaden the type of speech that would be caught by the hate law and therefore could potentially put the hate propaganda provisions at risk.
In view of the Supreme Court of Canada in the Keegstra case, subsection 319(2) was designed to extend the measure of protection to visible and religious minorities so as to prevent their being exposed to hate messages and to promote racial and religious tolerance and understanding.
Expanding the definition of identifiable group to include other characteristics such as those proposed in Bill C-350 would significantly extend the narrow purpose of protecting visible and religious minorities approved by the Supreme Court of Canada in Keegstra.
Any amendments resulting in a broader range of speech caught by the legislation could give rise to the argument that these provisions no longer represent a minimal impairment of the freedom of expression. As a result, the hate propaganda provisions as amended by Bill C-350 could be more vulnerable to a finding by the courts that they constitute an infringement of the charter guarantee of freedom of speech and that they are not a reasonable limit prescribed by law in a free and democratic society.
To broaden the definition it would probably have to be established that there is a pressing and substantial objective in Canada of a significantly substantial amount of hate propaganda aimed at particular groups. Such findings would likely have to be made and sustained with respect to groups of persons characterized by age, sex or physical or mental disabilities for the proposals in Bill C-350 to be found constitutional.

Private Members' Business
As a result it may be a more prudent course of action not to amend the definition of an identifiable group unless and until there is evidence of the existence of a significantly substantial amount of hate material to cause harm to a group not now covered by the definition. It is expected that federal-provincial territorial ministers responsible for justice will examine a wide variety of issues associated with the hate propaganda provisions, including the issue of how the identifiable group in section 318 should be defined at its next meeting.
A thoughtful and extensive review of the hate propaganda provisions of the Criminal Code is well under way. In the interests of bringing about a comprehensive and sound law reform in this very important area, it would in my estimation be preferable to allow this process to conclude before the House considers any amendments to section 318 and section 319 of the Criminal Code.
The hon. member should be congratulated, however, for taking an interest in this very important matter and for advancing a proposal for change which is serious and very topical.
I would like to congratulate the hon. member on bringing forward his bill. It is a very important issue but, as I have said, it may not be prudent at this point in time to expand the definition because it could put at risk the hate provisions in our law at the present time.
I will conclude with that remark. Once again I want to congratulate the very eloquent member for Kingston and the Islands. He has done a lot of work in bringing forward various private members' bills to encourage discussion and debate. It was timely that we discuss this one today. I hope that the provincial, territorial and federal ministers will conclude their discussions on this issue and come forward with some reform in the law.

Mr. Speaker, as the justice critic for the federal New Democratic Party, I am pleased to stand and respond.
I want to say this before we lose the hon. member from the government. The government members always amaze me. Be careful when they start congratulating you. They will kill you with kindness. He just said that the hon. member who presented the bill, the member for
Kingston and the Islands, was a wonderful member, then said how he has contributed so much to the House, and congratulated him. There was just one little problem: We are going to talk out your bill, or we are not going to refer your bill to the committee.
If I were putting forward a bill, I would prefer that the government got up and said that I was a terrible rogue but my bill had some substance and it was going to consider my bill and put it to the committee. I will take that and thanks for the congratulations. I cannot speak for the hon. member for Kingston and the Islands, but perhaps if he had a chance to speak again he would say that. Thanks for the congratulations but no thanks. Don't kill me with kindness. Just send my bill to the committee.
I do thank the hon. member for Edmonton-Strathco-na for putting forward some serious legal considerations. He mentioned the recent Zundel case in the Supreme Court of Canada which dealt with section 181 of the Criminal Code and that is spreading false news. The court said that was against the Charter of Rights and Freedoms and therefore falls.
This of course deals with hate propaganda. The government member for Edmonton-Strathcona, who just spoke, raised a good question as to whether the recent Zundel case dealing with section 181 on false news affects this section on hate propaganda.
We still have this section in the law on hate propaganda. It is in the Criminal Code in section 318.1 will come to that in a minute. He asked the question: "Will that affect it? Will the court decision affect this section?" That is a good question.
It seems to me that is why we should take this member's bill and put it into the committee. Let the committee have a look at that and analyse precisely that question. If you are going to wait for the federal, provincial and territorial ministers of justice-I love all of them to the last man and woman-you will wait until hell freezes over before they make a few decisions. They are still working on facilities for juveniles. They are still working on areas for better gun control. They are still working on native justice measures. They are working on them, but they work pretty slowly.
November 26, 1992

If you are going to wait for them, you will be waiting for a long time. The position of my party is that we will agree to this bill today going to the committee because I think the principle of the bill is right. Indeed, it advances some very interesting principles. We would agree with that now so that it could be done. I did not want to disturb the hon. member, but I just wanted to make that particular point to him.
Let me say a couple of things about the bill, and put it in the right context. This bill deals with section 318 of the Criminal Code. It is worth having a look. I have the Canadian Criminal Code here. Section 318 calls it "hate propaganda" and it says "advocating genocide". Section 318(1): "Everyone who advocates or promotes genocide is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years".
"(2) In this section, genocide means any of the following acts committed with intent to destroy in whole or in part any identifiable group, namely: (a) killing members of the group; or (b) deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction". That is of the whole group, the whole people.
"(3) No proceeding of an offence under this section shall be instituted without the consent of the Attorney General, and (4) In this section, identifiable group means any section of the public distinguished by colour, race, religion or ethnic origin".
The hon. member for Kingston and the Islands brings his Bill C-50 and proposes to add in section 318(4) age, sex, sexual orientation and mental and physical disability to the list of characteristics that may distinguish an identifiable group for the purposes of this section of the Criminal Code.
There is another bill in the House from my colleague for Burnaby-Kingsway. His bill received first reading on June 19, 1991. This bill received first reading on June 10, 1992 but the 1991 bill, the previous bill of the hon. member for Burnaby-Kingsway, just deals with sex or sexual orientation.
What has happened here is that the hon. member for Kingston and the Islands has gone further and has added
Private Members' Business
age, mental and physical disability to the list of characteristics. This is very interesting. This is open to a lot of debate and a lot of thought.
I am trying to picture in my mind a group advocating the genocide of a whole group based on their age, perhaps old people, perhaps killing old people or killing disabled people. That is a very big debate in Canada today, as members know. There is the woman from the west coast who is suffering from Lou Gehrig's disease who wants to be able to terminate her life.
We do not have yet the debate of people actually getting criticized or charged who are advocating that a group be terminated. That is what this bill would deal with. I find that a very interesting question. It is hard to pronounce on the question without some serious debate in the committee on that. I think that is what we need. Also sexual orientation is in there. We have seen the extent of gay bashing and the calls from different people for eliminating that group of people. Most Canadians do not share that. It is a very small minority. Again it would fit in the context of the hon. member's bill.
I just want to say a couple of other things on the general subject. The member for Kingston and the Islands and the House know that the issue of freedom of speech versus restrictions on the dissemination of hate propaganda has really been at the centre of the two most notable cases, the Eckville, Alberta high school teacher, Jim Keegstra, and the recent case of Ernst Zundel. Zundel was originally convicted of distributing racist literature through the mail, publications that question whether the Nazis killed six million Jews in Europe during World War II.
These are not academic questions. Watch the news and see what is happening with the neo-Nazis in Germany coming back. I personally am a civil libertarian. I belong to the Civil Libertarian Association, Amnesty International and other associations. I really do not want to see Nazis back. There is only one way to deal with Nazis. They have to be dealt with toughly. That is why we need to have these kinds of laws.

November 26, 1992
Private Members' Business
When people say that the holocaust did not happen, they are essentially rewriting history and trying to pave the way for the return of Nazism and fascism. That is what it is all about. We should not be fooled. It is not a question of civil liberties. It is a question of fascism and hatred and Nazism, ultimately.
I want to point out to the House that in March 1984 there was a special parliamentary committee on visible minorities in the Canadian society. They had a number of interesting recommendations. Section 35 called for the deletion of the word wilfully from that definition in the code. This would remove the difficulty that the Crown has in having to prove that the accused specifically intended to publicly promote hatred against an identifiable group. That is a very hard thing for the Crown to prove.
Recommendation No. 36 called upon the Department of Justice to amend the hate propaganda section of the Criminal Code in order to remove the necessity of having the Attorney General consent to prosecutions. That is not in the member's bill, but he might consider those two further aspects of the bill. If it went to the committee, it could look at that.
In July 1984 the Canadian Bar Association had a special committee on racial and religious hatred. It produced a document favouring stronger curbs on hate propaganda. I just want to refer to that: "After evaluating the conflict between egalitarian and libertarian values, the committee concluded that the weight of argument rested with the view that the law does indeed have a role to play in curtailing racial and religious hatred in the dissemination of hate propaganda".
Noting that the framers of our constitution supported the concept of legislative intervention, the special committee of the bar stated: "We ought not to shy away from strengthening the convictions which we have already put in writing in the Criminal Code".
The debate in Canada as to whether you like freedom of speech or laws that restrict freedom of speech is continuing and is at the core of these kinds of bills. As the member knows, we already have laws against libel, slander, defamation, contempt of court, obscenity and laws against incitement to riot. You do not walk into a theatre and yell fire. In other words, we do restrict
freedom of speech in some ways in the extremes. This is a case advocating genocide as an extreme that must be regulated.
I want to cite the cry that was attributed to Voltaire: "I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend with my life your right to say it". Voltaire is saying that you can pretty well say anything and he will defend your right to say it.

Mr. Speaker, I consider it a privilege to have the opportunity to not only second the motion put forward in the House by my colleague the hon. member for Kingston and the Islands on Bill C-350 but also to speak to the bill for what brief time I have.
There is a bit of deja vu because it was just last week when an attempt was made by myself on behalf of constituents in Hamilton West to have a Private Members' Bill move from second reading stage to committee stage so we could deal with amendments I had proposed to the Criminal Code with respect to parole and bail. I attempted to bring it to committee stage in order to have a complete, thorough, frank, and open discussion on a particular matter concerning the Criminal Code.
That is really what we were elected for in the first place, was it not? We were elected to bring the concerns of our constituents forward to the highest court in the land, as the member for Kingston and the Islands has done through his private member's Bill C-350, so that they can be put to a committee where there can be open discussion.
What we are dealing with here, as has been so eloquently put forward by the previous member and the member for Kingston and Islands, is the amendment the member seeks to section 318 of the Criminal Code, specifically subsection 4.
November 26, 1992

The hon. member is asking that the phrase identifiable group now mean:
any group of persons who are distinguished by colour, race, religion, ethnic origin,
And here are the additions:
age, sex, sexual orientation or mental or physical disability.
We say to the government: "Welcome to the 1990s". I would like to remind the House of a speech made in this House by the former hon. member of the riding I now have the privilege to represent. The Hon. Lincoln Alexander said in a speech on the original section 318:
You cannot legislate love, nor can you legislate against prejudice. But, Mr. Speaker, surely you can legislate against the overt act of discrimination. I do not know whether this bill will work, but I hope it will. It can work in this area, in that it is a form of education. But it is a form of education the hard way.
It is a form of education.
What does Bill C-350 do? It updates us to the 1990s because today we are talking about, as the member's bill states, age, sex, sexual orientation, or mental or physical disability.
Back when the hon. member for Hamilton West, Lincoln Alexander, made his remarks in 1970 they were very applicable. In 1970 we did not realize the difficulties facing the disabled in our society. We did not appreciate what the physically disabled in our society had to put up with.
That is really what they did. They had to put up with the lack of services that affected them in everything from entering a grocery store to dialing a phone in a phone booth. In the 1990s we can say we have recognized their concern, in part because of the hard work by those organizations representing the disabled. They have come forward to us and said: "Look, here is our problem, help us out", and we acted to help them out.
This is an opportunity today for the Criminal Code to be updated to incorporate their concerns.
The member for Kingston and the Islands expressed very eloquently how the Criminal Code must be updated. There are many sections in the Criminal Code. It is a pretty thick book. There are many aspects of this book that do need to be brought up to date. We can only
Private Members' Business
accomplish that if we can allow an initiative to get to committee stage.
There is no ulterior motive on the part of the member for Kingston and the Islands. This is not a press grabbing issue. This is not something that the member for Kingston and the Islands is trying to get some headlines with. He has just taken a piece of the Criminal Code, on behalf of the constituents he represents, and he said: "Look, all we have to do is get with the times here, folks. Get with the times. Age, sex, sexual orientation or mental or physical disability should be added to the list of those identifiable groups already found within the Criminal Code in section 318".
The hon. member for Edmonton-Strathcona said that the government has proclaimed that the job of expanding the definition of section 318 is somehow vulnerable in the courts of our land. He certainly has not demonstrated to me or anyone on this side of the House exactly where it is vulnerable.
He referred to the Keegstra decision. The Keegstra decision was on section 319 not section 318. The hon. member is presenting a bill dealing with section 318. To broaden the definition, says the member for Edmonton-Strathcona, would be to identify the existence of a greater problem. Glory be, no kidding. That is exactly why the hon. member wants to put forward this amendment.
Where can we do it? In this place there must be an appreciation that the government should not always be responsible for all change. Tragically, I am seeing more and more that other members, who are caring and sensitive, on the other side of the House or even in their own party, who sit on the backbenches or in opposition have legitimate issues to bring forward through a private member's bill or a private member's motion, but time and time again there is a thin, narrow, weak excuse to kill the bill or the motion. That is a shame.
The hon. member for Kingston and the Islands is not asking for this amendment, through his Bill C-350, to become law today. It will not become law if we say: "Yes, we are in favour of this idea". It is a request to have it moved to committee stage so that we can have an open and frank discussion. That is all he seeks the floor to do today.

Private Members' Business
We ask the government to give him, an opposition member working hard on behalf of his constituents, the opportunity to do just that.

Mr. Speaker, I too am privileged to speak on this Private Member's Bill and answer some of the points raised by the previous three speakers.
I must say at the start that I am going to smother my good friend with more kindness. I am unable to give unanimous consent to this bill, but for some very good reasons.
First, on private members' hour, my good friend knows that this is a valuable debate to have. It goes into the general discussion pool. It will be discussed by the ministers of justice from all the provinces and territories and the federal government. It will go into that mix. They will take our discussions today into consideration. There is no doubt about that.
This bill, far from being a criticism of the current law, really endorses the current hate propaganda provisions. It does so by extending the groups to which the provisions would apply by adding groups defined by age, sex, sexual orientation, and mental or physical disability. It will not even be lost because it will come up again as a private member's bill. Unfortunately, it was not one of the five chosen to go to a vote in this session of Parliament. However, even going to a vote is a very unique provision. The power that we now have as private members of Parliament has been augmented dramatically, in a geometric fashion, with the Parliament passing those changes to the Standing Orders which permit five Private Members' Bills to come to a vote.
I wish my good friend who just spoke had been here five or ten years ago with a private member's bill. Nothing got anywhere. Therefore, we are still a major step ahead.
With respect to the intervention by my friend from Port Moody-Coquitlam in which he said that the ministers of justice are perhaps too busy and therefore it should be sent to the justice committee, I would like to say that at this point in this Parliament the justice committee is very busy too.
We are doing a major study on crime prevention for which some very interesting witnesses are appearing. A subcommittee of the justice committee is looking at the national security, as well as the codification of a new general part of the Criminal Code which raises those issues of consent to death and euthanasia.
We are currently reviewing two cases of parole that resulted in the death of police officers. Then there are the usual annual reports and GIC appointees. Therefore, the justice committee itself is really pressed at this moment.
Parliament is going to recess in a couple of weeks from now on December 11. Given the need to have an election by next November it is quite possible that the House would come back in February, there might even be a prorogation. We might then go out and have an election straight away.
Therefore, the likelihood of a committee being able to do much work on a practical day-to-day basis is quite small. That is not to say that this is not valuable though. The reason I want to speak is so that my comments will also go before those ministers of justice.
Section 318 of the Criminal Code right now prohibits the advocating or promoting of genocide against any section of the public distinguished by colour, race, religion or ethnic origin. Inciting hatred against a protected group by communicating in a public place statements which are likely to lead to a breach of the peace is dealt with in subsection 318(1).
Communicating statements other than in private conversation which wilfully promote hatred against a protected group is dealt with in subsection 319(2).
I want to make a comment for my friend opposite, and I wish in the next round to hear from him on this. As we know, at least if my recollection is correct, when it has heard these cases the Supreme Court has declared that these parts of the code are prima facie a contravention of the Charter of Rights, but they are saved by section 1 of the charter because they are a reasonable limit on our fellow citizens' fundamental rights.
It is important to consider whether, if this bill were to pass, it would expand section 318 so far that the court would not save it under section 1 and we would therefore be doing what none of us want to do, which is to wipe out the whole section. Therefore we would then be faced without a law dealing with the incitement of hatred against a protected group by communicating in a public place or with statements likely to lead to a breach of the peace or that advocate or promote genocide against any section of the public distinguished by colour, race, religion or ethnic origin. It is a very interesting point. I am not sure in my own mind what I think about that, other than I know we want that section to be in the code.
November 26, 1992

In this day and age, these very powerful special interest groups totally lack the ability to see the world in its broad context. They are very much caught up in tribalism, whether it is racially or ethnically motivated or just in their ideas and have no ability to realize that other people's ideas are equally valid and their ideas are really wrong. We accept the fact that we are all human beings in this world. Surely there are not many people who would deny that, but I guess there are a few.
Till South Africa started to move, the fundamental basis of apartheid was the acceptance by people who believed in apartheid that the majority were not human beings. That is the whole fundamental underlying basis of apartheid, that another group of humans is not in fact human.
It is the same with fascism, nazism. They just deny the reality that some people are human beings, based on their religion and their ethnic origin. It is absolutely an abominable thing. The point is that we do not want to put in words at this early moment that which might lead to the whole section being struck down.
In addition, the Criminal Code provides for the seizure and forfeiture of hate propaganda kept in the premises for sale or distribution. TTiat is section 320(1) and (4).
A person charged with advocating genocide is liable to five years imprisonment if charged with the offence of the public incitement of hatred or of the offence of communicating statements which wilfully promote hatred.
A person is liable is two years imprisonment if prosecuted by way of indictment or to six months and/or a $2,000 fine if prosecuted by way of summary proceedings.
The Criminal Code also provides for four special statutory defences which an accused may raise if prosecuted for wilfully promoting hatred. These are: (a) the statements communicated were true; (b) the statements expressed or attempted to be established by argument in good faith and opinion upon a religious subject; (c) the
Private Members' Business
statements were made on a subject of public interest which on reasonable grounds are believed to be true; and (d) pointing out in good faith for the purpose of removal, matters producing or tending to produce feelings of hatred.
Except for the offence of public incitement to hatred, the consent of the provincial attorney general is required to obtain a seizure or to initiate a prosecution under the Criminal Code's hate propaganda provisions.
Mr. Speaker, I guess that is my final point. You are signalling that my time is finished. That is the final reason why it should go before this group of provincial ministers, the federal minister and the territorial people. I am sure they will come back with recommendations that are very reasonable.

Mr. Francis G. LeBIanc (Cape Breton Highlands -
Canso): Mr. Speaker, I would like to return to a question I asked on May 11 concerning an extraordinary meeting of the fisheries commission of NAFO, the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization, to deal with blatant overfishing by the European Community, principally by Spain and Portugal, on the nose and tail of the Grand Banks. That special meeting of the NAFO fisheries commission, which was called at Canada's request, ended in uncertainty. Canada came away with little more than proposals for reform or, worse still, the EC's flat out rejection of their role in the stock crisis.
At that time my colleagues and I told the government that this situation was far too serious to leave solely to diplomacy. We urged the government to act, to introduce legislation now, to extend Canada's custodial management zone to include all of our continental shelf. The fisheries minister said no. He did not want to "howl and bawl and use exaggerated rhetoric". Extending jurisdiction is not a new or wild notion and calling upon the minister to implement such a policy is not wild rhetoric.
Much has happened since I asked my question on May 11. In June governments across the world met in Brazil for the UNCED. This impressive international meeting of state leaders offered our government another chance to change things. To its credit, Canada joined about 40 other countries in sponsoring the resolution on high seas fishing conservation and management, a resolution which passed.
We still could not convince influential countries like the U.S. and the EC to support it. We will have an opportunity to follow up on the UNCED when a special international conference late next year addresses fisheries issues, especially those regarding straddling stocks.
It certainly cannot happen soon enough for Atlantic fishermen. In July the minister imposed a domestic moratorium on the Newfoundland northern cod fishery,
putting over 20,000 Canadians out of the fishery, some for the length of the moratorium and many others forever.
Also in July government scientists released their domestic stock assessments and quota advice for all 1993 Atlantic fish stocks. It calls for drastic cuts, in some regions up to 80 per cent. Frustrated fishermen, plant workers and communities everywhere are bracing themselves for a rough ride next year.
Some hope arose from the September NAFO meetings when the European Community made a solemn promise to follow NAFO quotas in 1993, something which it has never done.
At the same time the EC scuttled Canada's attempt to change the objectors clause, the very loophole through which EC overfishers have jumped for years. There is absolutely nothing stopping the EC or any other NAFO country for that matter from using it again, except perhaps the knowledge that Canada is fully prepared to extend its jurisdiction if they do.
I hope the federal government will make it perfectly clear that it is prepared to act in this matter should it be required. Canada spends about $400,000 annually in membership dues to NAFO. The minister of fisheries must ensure that this money is well spent.
The Liberal Party has decided to recognize the small steps that have been achieved on the international front. Progress has been made but much more will be necessary to ensure the future of our fishery and the future of the individuals in communities that depend upon it for their livelihoods.
Fishery communities in my riding are watching this government. Fishermen are realistic and most recognize that domestic catch reductions and other restructuring measures may well be necessary to sustain the fishery in the long term through this crisis.
They also know that the federal government must stay tough with its international friends. Unless it does, fishermen will find it extremely difficult to accept the tough quota cuts and jobs losses being imposed on them.

speakeroldname: Mr. John A. MacDougall (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to respond to my hon. friend from Cape Breton who, by the way, represents the area where I was bom.
November 26, 1992

At Canada's request, the fisheries commission of the North Atlantic Fisheries Organization, NAFO, met in a special session at Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, last May to discuss Canada's proposals to improve surveillance and control of the NAFO regulatory area outside Canada's 200-mile limit.
New measures developed by the special session were reviewed and adopted at the annual meeting of NAFO in September. All NAFO members, including the EC, have agreed to put them in place. Together these new measures represent yet another important step forward in ending overfishing on the Grand Banks outside Canada's 200-mile zone.
The measures adopted in September include a pilot project for an observer program of the NAFO area. Canadian fisheries managers have found the use of observers to be an effective surveillance measure inside the Canadian zone. Beginning in January 1993, observers will be placed on vessels outside 200 miles during 10 per cent of the fishing days.
Important new measures were been adopted to eliminate fishing for undersized fish. Minimum mesh sizes and minimum landing sizes were established. A one net rule was adopted whereby vessels would not be permitted to have nets on board with mesh smaller than the minimum size. These measures will apply to all ground-fish fisheries in the area which will help considerably to reduce catches of juvenile fish. In addition, the adoption of minimum landing sizes will make it illegal for undersized fish to be sold to EC and other markets.
This government, in working with the industry, is doing its utmost to help solve a very severe problem facing the fishing industry.
