speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on several occasions I have risen in this House to ask questions concerning the Westray coal mine, and in particular with the disaster which occurred in Pictou county killing 26 men.
It has become abundantly clear in the last number of months that with the evidence that has been put on the record, and the information that individuals now have that one of the most important things that we could do as
Adjournment Debate
a national government would be to have an inquiry into this particular operation.
It would be an opportunity for the government to present its case, both with regard to the financial dealings surrounding this particular mine as well as some of the political interference which obviously ran rampant through the Westray coal mine project.
I received a letter recently which I wish to table and I will read it in part. It says: "We were shocked and outraged to read in today's Chronicle Herald that the Commons industry committee voted four to two not to proceed with an inquiry into the financial dealings surrounding the Westray mine project".
"As residents of Pictou county, we can assure you that their decision does not sit well with the majority of us if what people are saying on a grassroots basis is any indication. The talk in Tim Horton's coffee shops, our local garages and on the streets is that we are all amazed that six months after a horrific mine disaster in which 26 young men lost their lives not only are we back to square one but we may never get to first base again".
"We want some accountability from the Nova Scotia Department of Labour, our premier, our Prime Minister and the federal MPs and bureaucrats involved. In the meantime, why do not we invite those committee members who did not see the need to look into this matter any further to come down to the Christmas parties of the children of the 26 dead miners".
That is signed by Mary Gorman and Percy Hind, Jr., and I wish to table that.
The evidence is there for everyone to review and to examine. What is needed is an inquiry by the national government in order to fully address all of the concerns of the people who have been involved in this tragic occurrence. It is not sufficient enough for the Government of Canada to say: "Well, maybe Nova Scotia will have an inquiry". It was found by a Supreme Court justice that their inquiry was unconstitutional, but the justice did state that there was an opportunity here for governments, if you will, to have an inquiry.
I urge the Government of Canada to stop the cover-up, to have the inquiry, to produce the evidence, to respond to the charges and the concerns of many individuals, to give a thorough examination of all of the evidence, all of the witnesses regardless of one's political fate.

Government Orders
I believe strongly that the Government of Canada has a moral responsibility as well as a political responsibility, if not a legal one, to proceed with an inquiry either through the auspices of the Standing Orders of this House or indeed, to have the three political parties come together and agree on the mandate that would be taken.
It is irresponsible for the Government of Canada to turn its back on those dead young miners in Pictou county, their families, their loved ones and the community. I urge in the strongest possible terms that the minister gdford himself of the opportunity in order to have this matter heard in its fullest possible way.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to point out the six commission boards that have been effectively killed by this legislation have been very valuable and viable services for this government.
The Law Reform Commission's mandate was to provide ongoing review of the statutes of Canada and make recommendations for improvement, modernization and reform of legislation. It undertook some of the basic research and contracted out other works to consultants to try to modify and amend shortcomings in Canada's laws. It has been a very valuable service. We save $4.8 million by cutting this service.
Let us have a look at the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. This institution had a mandate to increase knowledge and understanding of the issues related to international peace and security from a uniquely Canadian perspective. We save about $5 million by killing this institution.
The Economic Council of Canada was established some 29 years ago and has served admirably in its capacity. This council's objective was to provide advice on how Canada could achieve the highest possible level of employment and efficient production so the country could enjoy a high and consistent rate of economic growth and all Canadians could share in rising living standards.
November 26, 1992

This council had 28 members. The estimates indicate about $10.6 million in terms of its annual budget. One hundred and eight person years have been chopped to save about $10.3 million.
These are not major expenditures for the amount of work these organizations do.
The International Centre for Ocean Development focused exclusively on the oceans. Its mandate was to provide assistance, information and training programs for developing countries to help improve their management and utilization of ocean resources. We save $13.3 million by killing this program.
Let us have a look at the Science Council. It has been a particularly valuable institution for defending the need for research and development in this country. I think it is being killed because it has been very critical of this government. As this government has done with virtually every institution, it wants to shoot the messenger. It does not want to hear the bad news, so it has deep-sixed these organizations.
The Science Council had a mandate to assess scientific information and technological resources and increase public awareness of scientific and technological problems. The council had 30 members. Its budget was about $3.2 million and that has been killed by this legislation.
The Science Council of Canada has been a vocal critic of the government. The government has not responded to the criticisms. Instead it has chosen to shoot the messenger.
I just want to read a quote from John Polyanni who is the winner of the 1986 Nobel prize in chemistiy. He said: "Killing the Science Council of Canada is short-sighted and will leave Canada without an independent voice on the future of science and technology. In our concern that the ship of state is too big, we are simply removing the rudder".
Killing all six of these very valuable institutions saves us $22 million for the fiscal year. Members of the government have said $22 million is not peanuts and we have to look at every avenue of savings. I want to point out there are a lot of other areas where we could save a heck of a lot more money than simply $22 million.
Government Orders
I am referring to the 1992 report of the Auditor General of Canada. These are follow-up recommendations that were the issues of previous reports and have not been attended to by the government. Under the title of "Military Conditions of Service", the Auditor General points out they examined a range of services and benefits intended to either adjust for special military conditions or develop military commitment and military ethos. The direct pay and allowance alone cost the department $3.3 billion, 29 per cent of the 1989-90 budget, almost $3.5 billion, to adjust for special military conditions and develop military commitment. That is a heck of a lot of money and $3.3 billion is a lot more than $22 million.
Let us go on to where it talks about the commissioning plans for officers. It states: "In the 1990 report the Auditor General recommended national defence periodically evaluate the efficiency and effectiveness of its commissioning plans. It pointed out at that time the department spends some $18,000 to $47,000 per student per year, depending on whether the officer cadet is sent to a civilian university or a military college". It gets worse.
Let us have a look at follow-up recommendations with regard to the Department of National Defence official languages training. I have been a long-time supporter of the official languages policy, but I am not a supporter of the flagrant misuse of public funds for the inefficient utilization of these policy directives.
Again the Auditor General's report states: "We reported that this program had cost the department about $500 million since 1980 and was expected to cost some $1.4 billion over the next 15 years". There were 7,600 individuals on language training between 1990-91. It also points out "the department's plans still do not focus training resources to address the shortage of bilingual anglophones. We noted in 1990 the Canadian Forces language system is designed to offer a low level of training to many, rather than train fewer individuals to maximum proficiency. In 1989 the 9,000 anglophones at the language level closest to becoming bilingual were not given priority access to resources that would have enabled them to become effectively bilingual". It goes on to say the Department of National Defence has not

November 26, 1992
Government Orders
implemented recommendations to incorporate posting priorities into its language training. There is still no departmental posting policy to assign trained individuals from all courses to positions designated as bilingual, while respecting operational task priorities. The current departmental bilingual manning policy affects only 250 or so graduates. Although this course lasts a full year and costs over $80,000 per person, in 1990 and 1991 only 66 per cent of its graduates were actually assigned to bilingual positions.
There is more of a horror show here. Again the Auditor General reports the Department of National Defence should identify where Canadian forces schools cost more. This is under training efficiency and economy. It says: "We reported that the Department of National Defence should identify where Canadian forces schools cost more and should use this information to reduce costs".
It gives the following example. In 1990 the Auditor General reported it cost some $265,352 for a fleet school to train a single marine engineering technician, whereas it cost only $71,000 in the community college system. That is an outrageously inflated cost for something that could have been handled much more effectively in the community college system.
I want to move on to another area where this government could and should be saving money. Rather than cutting the fat and waste out of these particular programs it chooses instead to cut these six very valuable councils. They no longer exist and the services they provided have now bitten the dust.
Let us go again to the Auditor General's report. Under the Department of Finance it mentions outstanding loan guarantees amounted to $5.7 billion in 1990 and 1991. He also points out ongoing loan guarantees with lender risk sharing arrangements covered only 26 per cent of the total outstanding. In other words, three-quarters of that money loaned by the federal government has no arrangement in terms of shared risk or equity. It is just money that has been given out to the corporate sector by the government. In 1990 and 1991 that amounted to some $5.7 billion and the total authorized amount stood at $13.7 billion.
It just gets worse and worse as you look through the Auditor General's report and see where the government could have saved money or should have saved money but chose not to.
Again, let us go back to the Department of National Defence major capital projects. It says in the Auditor General's report: "We obtained a listing from the Department of National Defence of all initial provisioning contracts", purchasing contracts, "in effect at the time of our audit. The contracts date from as early as 1982 with a total cost of some $657 million". It reads further: "We focused only on the first comparison and limited ourselves only to those parts where price comparisons could easily be made. This involved some $158 million in spare parts contracted out over a 10-year period. We then compared the prices paid by the Department of National Defence with the listed prices of the same items available for sale or actually paid by the U.S. Department of National Defence". Lo and behold what do we find? The difference between the prices paid by DND, our Canadian Armed Forces and the prices indicated in these other sourcing alternatives varied widely. In the majority of cases it exceeded 50 per cent.
I know you cannot see the small graph on the page but in some cases it identifies overexpenditures of between 500 and 1,000 per cent greater than the comparable cost of the item. This is an outrageous and completely unconscionable waste of taxpayers' money in purchasing items for the Department of National Defence that were substantially cheaper using other purchasing sources.
The report goes on to say that even a 10 per cent reduction in procurement costs could result in savings in excess of $20 million each year. A 10 per cent reduction in the procurement costs would have saved Canadian taxpayers over $20 million.
That number is very significant because this legislation in front of us is talking about saving $22 million by cutting six very very important institutions and organizations including: the Law Reform Commission; The Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council; the Economic Council and the Science Council.
November 26, 1992

All six councils bite the dust at a savings of only $20 million. By a 10 per cent reduction in procurement in the Department of National Defence we could have exceeded those savings and it is right here in the 1992 Auditor General's report.
That is not all that is in there. I want to go over another item and the more one reads this, the more amazed one gets. This is with regard to the Canadian Armed Forces. It says that the vast majority of both militia and communication reserve units have no assigned roles or operational tasks and have been organized on the model of regular force operational units.
What is he talking about? Let us have a look. A militia lieutenant colonel, for example, supposedly leads a unit of some 200 to 300 positions, but in actuality it only averages about 100 people. In the regular force a sub unit of 100 people would normally be led by a major while a lieutenant-colonel would be in charge of about 600. There are no instructions requiring unit commanding officers to fill their units efficiently, wasting again, administratively, the taxpayers' money of Canada.
Again, under the project costs for the Department of National Defence, the Auditor General comments that the department bought two used offshore supply vessels for approximately $10 million. This in response to the minister's request in late 1987 that naval reservists be provided with the means to commence mine counter measures training for that summer. Although officials sponsored the project, they told the approving authorities that the vessels were in excellent condition based on an initial survey. It was found that an additional $16 million was needed for unplanned repairs after the purchase was made.
The purchase of a remote operative vehicle, called an ROV, cost the taxpayers some $955,000 to train reservists in mine hunting. It was not adequately evaluated at the time and proved to be too complex for use. At the time the audit was done the total costs had escalated from the original purchase price of $955,000 to well over $2 million. That did not include unplanned costs for facilities and the development of a training package.
Another point is that the department purchased 199 Bison armoured vehicles and 22 specialized M-113 armoured vehicles required to meet militia needs for $161 million before there was even maintenance personnel and facilities available to service them. The Auditor General points out that he estimated the Department of

National Defence has incurred a loss costing $17 million to the Canadian taxpayer which could have been avoided if the programs had been set up before actually purchasing these vehicles.
The horror stories that are in the Auditor General's report, and I have only pointed out a few, indicate there are many avenues in which this government could have and should have been able to save far more than the $20 million it is saving by chopping these six institutions.
The record speaks for itself. The government has chosen to silence its critics by killing these institutions. It really has nothing to do with saving taxpayers money.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Bill C-63 is another example of this Conservative government's drive to stifle free expression and thought, including independent research and policy development.
Here we have a bill which abolishes the major independent-and I emphasize the word independent-research councils in Canada, ones that have existed for a number of years including: the Economic Council of Canada, the Law Reform Commission, the Science Council of Canada, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security and the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council. Today I want in particular to speak about the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council because that is the one I have been very close to over a number of years.
For the past year I have been the opposition critic for immigration and for the previous seven years I was the opposition critic for employment. I must say that the reports of the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council were extremely helpful and useful to me in that opposition role. They were very helpful as well to non-governmental organizations and other outside groups. In addition, prior to the change of government in 1984 I was the chairman of the Standing Committee on Labour, Employment and Immigration and, once again, had close contact with the work of this advisory council.
The mandate of the Employment and Immigration Advisory Council is to provide the Minister of Employment and Immigration with independent-and I stress that word again-private sector advice on policy issues pertaining to immigration, labour market issues, and unemployment insurance.
The council was structured in such a way that it had 21 members drawn from business, labour and other non-aligned groups. It was the only independent body directly reporting or advising the minister that was not part of his public service, part of his department.
This advisory council put out some extremely important reports over the last number of years. For example, in April 1990 it put out a report on full employment entitled "Full Employment is an Achievable Goal". The year before they put out a report on structural unemployment entitled "Regional Unemployment in Canada:
Government Orders
A Nation out of Balance". It was published in November
1989.	Prior to that, in 1985 it published a report entitled "Older Workers: An Imminent Crisis in the Labour Market". It also had reports on the Atlantic fishery and on single industry communities.
Previous speakers in this debate have been absolutely correct. The real reason the government is abolishing these six independent advisory councils is that it does not like criticism. I can recall very well, with the Canadian Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, when the government was putting through its bill, its major reform on unemployment insurance in the last Parliament, the advisory council which for the most part had been appointed by the minister, the men and women on the council had been designated and appointed by the minister of the time, took a position against many sections of that bill. It criticized those sections. It did it in a very scientific and diplomatic way, but in fact it stated positions of major disagreement with the minister. Its information and its statistics were very legitimate but the minister did not like it.
I can recall standing in this House and raising the issues put forward by the advisory council in opposition to sections in those unemployment insurance cuts which were very controversial at the time, and the minister tried to slough them off and put them aside.
It is like previous interveners in this debate have said. It was a question of when you do not like the news you kill the messenger. The messengers in this case were from business, labour and the university sectors. They gave their best advice on many of these issues. When the minister did not like them, she put a black mark against them.
I am thinking of the minister of the time, the hon. member from Kingston who I think was defeated in her constituency in Kingston for the terrible, insensitive reforms that were made to unemployment insurance which cut people off the unemployment insurance rolls and made unemployment insurance more difficult to obtain.
By that reform-and that was stated by the advisory council-by the federal government cutting back on unemployment insurance, all they were going to do was shift this entire group of people to the provincial welfare rolls. That is what has happened.

Government Orders
I can recall very well stating that at the time, citing the different paragraphs in the advisory council report. We said: "If you go through with the cuts, sure, it might look good for you at the federal level; but as far as the Canadian taxpayer is concerned you are simply going to shift the burden to the provincial and municipal welfare rolls". That happened.
The municipal and provincial welfare rolls increased considerably. That advice was given. The minister and the government were pre-warned, but they did not like the advice. They had their own agenda and they pursued their own agenda slavishly, and we have seen what happened. The country is in a terrible mess today where there is massive unemployment, where there are not sufficient resources to take care and retrain the unemployed, and so on.
I was just listening to the hon. member on the government side who was trying to argue that the real reason for these cuts was to help with the deficit and to reduce expenditures in order to reduce the deficit. You never reduce your deficit with respect to programs that could help you increase your productivity as a nation.
They say that today, in the 1990s and as we move into the next century, the greatest assets a nation can have are know-how, ideas, technology, scientific research. These are the things that will make nations great, which will make nations stand among the leaders in the world.
In times of difficulty you do not cut back on your educational systems as this government has done. You do not cut back on your training programs as this government has done. You do not cut back on your major institutions, major agencies that do research and development and provide independent, alternate advice on economic matters such as the Economic Council of Canada did; legal and social matters such as the Law Reform Commission did; the Science Council of Canada; on questions of peace and security such as CLIPS did; or the Advisory Council on Employment and Immigration.
In this modern age, just having resources in the ground and having a large nation with a lot of people do not mean we are a powerful, number one nation. Once again, when we look at a country like Japan, it has built its greatness as an economic power on its ability to develop, research, science, knowledge, know-how, new
products, and so on. When the government says it wants to reduce its deficit by cutting back on these institutions that develop new ideas and develop alternative ways of doing things which give us the basis for know-how, it sounds rather shallow and without support.
The hon. member from the government said as well: "We were able to cut these institutions back because the work they were doing was being duplicated in other areas". He mentioned as an example the Fraser Institute and the C. D. Howe Institute. I will deal with that.
Some members have cited, for example, that the functions of the Canadian Employment and Immigration Advisory Council have been absorbed into the ministry. Let me deal with that first. In the ministry the research and development that are done are subject to the political agenda of the government of the day, of the minister of the day. I know because I was a minister for seven years and I had to deal with the research and development wings of my department.
You are not getting what I would call independent, critical research. You are getting good research on some matters. There is no doubt about it. You are getting excellent research, but it follows in support of or pursues the government's political agenda. That has to be done and I respect that, but it is not covering the entire field.
With respect to private sector research, many of these private sector research bodies are dependent on their financial resources from large business, the corporate sector, the multinational business sector, and many of them serve their agendas. Once again one wonders whether we are getting the full range of independent research and development we need. I think not. Whether it is the C. D. Howe Institute that has published some good reports or the Fraser Institute for which I have less esteem but has published some good reports, they still do not provide the independent, critical research we had in this country when we had the Economic Council, the Science Council of Canada and the Advisory Council on Employment and Immigration.
It is a sad day when a country such as this, on the pretext of saving money, cuts back those institutions that provide us with independent thinking, ideas and knowhow. It is a very sad day. We in this party are objecting to these cuts. We think it is the wrong way to go.

There are many areas the government could cut in order to reduce the budget. I raise again the Auditor General's report which states where there has been a lot of waste, a lot of money siphoned out of the country. Those are areas where money could have been saved. We do not save money by cutting back on the institutions that give us high powered knowledge and information.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened with great interest to the hon. member when he talked about us silencing our critics.
I would like to remind him, for example, that the Economic Council of Canada predicted that the free trade agreement would bring, if I remember the figure correctly, either 200,000 or 300,000 jobs over the course of many years. That figure was used by the government, by business and so on, in support of arguments for the free trade agreement.
The Economic Council of Canada-and certainly it may have criticized the government in some areas-was supportive of the government in many other areas. This is not an issue of silencing critics. This is more an issue of Canada being a mature nation with mature universities today, many of which are over 100 years old. The university from which I graduated, the University of Alberta, celebrated its 75th anniversary a few years ago. It is probably celebrating its 80th anniversary now. There is a source of research for us and we have other institutions.
My question for the hon. member has to do with the role of Parliament. For years and years Parliament and the governments of the day have created these external agencies asking them for advice, but it seems to me that Parliament itself should be a policy-making body or policy should emanate from Parliament. We do not have enough committees studying the role or producing policy recommendations.
We have reformed Parliament. The McGrath commission in 1986 reformed Parliament. It would seem to me appropriate that maybe we should now consider beefing up the research bureaus of our committees, unleashing the potential of members of Parliament and restoring some of the esteem the public should have in Parliament, rather than always devaluing Parliament by spinning off policy-making agencies and think-tanks and
Government Orders
people looking to those groups as agents for social change and other things rather than to Parliament. I think Parliament should regain its role as a policy recommending body and committees should try to increase their stature in that manner, and many have done that.
Does the hon. member think that Parliament's role has been devalued by having this plethora of different agencies? Might we now re-assert ourselves as parliamentarians, give our committees extra power and produce policy recommendations in that way?
My next question concerns the economic argument here. These agencies cost a lot of money; $5 million is a lot of people paying taxes. We have to borrow that money. Then each year we have to pay interest on that borrowed money and we have to borrow money for interest. There is a never-ending, vicious cycle of compound interest, debt and so on. Certainly we could pay heed to some of the recommendations of the Auditor General, but that would not solve the problem of our massive debt and continuing deficit.
The Liberal Party and the NDP have called for increased spending every day. I sit in the House of Commons and every day I hear calls for massive programs, economic stimulus and so on. All that does is create inflation in the long run and devalue our currency and productivity.
We have to think seriously about the economic course of the nation, about the public purse and about keeping things on an even keel so that people have productive jobs.
We certainly have eliminated these agencies, but how do we get the deficit in check? What suggestions does he have on the big ticket items? His party seems to be saying: "Spend more, spend more, spend more". I will leave it at that and ask him to respond.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would be glad to respond. There are really three questions here.
First, with respect to whether the creation of these independent research agencies demean or take something away from Parliament's ability to do research, not at all. It is not a question of one or another. I fully agree with the hon. member that we should beef up and improve our parliamentary research capacity.

Government Orders
In the years I have been in Parliament, it has improved considerably. We now have in every committee one or two researchers who help us with our work. It is still not enough. There is a very excellent research branch with the parliamentary library which helps committees as well but let us be frank, when the committees do serious studies, they get their information not just from the research branch of the Library of Parliament, but by calling as witnesses the major industrial, labour, university, think-tank bodies in this country and we ask for their views. They do the research and then they input that research into our parliamentary committees. The good parliamentary committee is one which listens to many points of view.
I have just finished doing the work on the legislative committee for Bill C-86, the immigration bill. We heard from the section of the Canadian Bar Association that deals with immigration. We heard from the social agencies that dealt with immigration. We met with the various ethnocultural groups which did work on immigration. We got our information from many sources and from sources that did considerable research.
I might say that when I was with the Standing Committee on Labour, Employment and Immigration, we used to have very often before us the Economic Council to give us its advice on some of these major issues that were before Parliament and on which members of Parliament had to take a position.
I believe you can do both. You can have independent economic research agencies such as the Economic Council and the Science Council of Canada and improve your research capability within Parliament as well. I do not think it is duplication.
The member referred to the fact that the Economic Council supported free trade. Yes, it did support the concept of free trade. I was very much involved in that debate. I was on the committee prior to the election in 1988 that dealt with the free trade issue. The Economic Council also issued two reports which said there would be losses of jobs in several industrial sectors and something should be done about it, and that advice was not followed.
It also made major recommendations for retraining, upgrading and restructuring in areas that would be hit hard by the free trade agreement and that advice was not
followed as well. While the Economic Council supported free trade in general, it had something to say about the details of the free trade agreement and what had to be done to properly implement it, which was not followed.
The last question the hon. member asked was about these institutions costing a considerable amount of money. They cost money. The saving here is supposed to be $22 million. It is a sizeable sum of money but I look on money spent on developing ideas, developing scientific know-how as an investment in the country and in productivity and not as money being simply thrown out the window on consumption.
If we carry the argument of the government to the logical extreme and if we want to really save money, we could cut back all our funding for universities, we could cut back our public education system. We would save a lot of money, but we would end up a pretty ignorant country. I put these agencies in that area.
These national councils contribute to our national ability to produce at a high technological level, which is essential at this age in the 1990s and into the 21st century. This is not the kind of thing we cut. There are many areas where we can cut but we do not cut our ability to produce ideas, know-how and scientific first class information.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as has happened all too often in this Parliament of Canada, I am standing again this evening to express my sincere dismay at yet another foolish piece of government legislation. Today the disheartening legislation in question is Bill C-63, an act to dissolve or terminate certain corporations and other bodies.
I had the opportunity to speak on this bill at second reading last May. At that time I outlined that the government had announced in its budget of February 1992 its intention to eliminate, consolidate, defer or privatize 46 Crown agencies, corporations and commissions, all for a projected savings of $22 million.
This bill here this evening deals with only six of those 46 agencies. Those six agencies are the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security-better known as CUPS-the Economic Council of Canada, the International Centre for Ocean Development, the Law Reform Commission and the Science Council of Canada.
November 26, 1992

We on this side of the House agree that some of the 46 agencies are extravagant and need to go. Many of these were established by this same government. Furthermore, while I am not opposed to privatization, I am opposed to limitations being placed on organizations which continue to usefully serve the public policy process. There are several among the 46 which continue to provide such a service. In particular, the six agencies due to be axed by the government in this bill provided an invaluable service to Canadians.
All the government is accomplishing with this bill is more closely aligning itself with the far right Reform Party. I am embarrassed for this government. Will it stoop to any level to cater to a regional party which is equal only to the Bloc Quebecois? Before taking a closer look at a couple of the six agencies about to be given the heave-ho by the government, I want to first draw the Blouse's attention to the blatant disregard this government has for Parliament.
Yesterday an effort was made to contact each of the she agencies mentioned in this bill. It was quickly discovered that the government had already closed five of the six agencies. I repeat, five of the six agencies have already been closed by this government. This is well before Parliament has even voted on the legislation to do so. Such a total lack of respect for the Canadian parliamentary system is an absolute disgrace. Furthermore, closing the organizations before the bill is passed could be against the law.
An official at the Canadian Institute of International Peace and Security, which is the only agency of the six still open, said that it is only open because it received a legal opinion which indicated that the operation must continue until the legislation is passed. If this is the case for CUPS, why is it not the case for the others?
It is also important to note the callousness with which this government informed the employees of the various agencies about their closure. Judith Maxwell of the Economic Council indicated to the legislative committee on Bill C-63 that she was advised at 12 p.m. on budget day that the council would be dissolved. At least three of the four were treated in the same way.
Government Orders
Has this government no shame? At least Conservative government members will have 60 days from the time an election is finally called to begin packing up their boxes before the Canadian people fire them. I do not know why you could not have given the agencies the same kind of treatment that you yourselves will be treated to by the Canadian public when you lose your seats in the next election. You have 60 days to pack your bags.
In my previous address in this House on this bill, I outlined the importance of each of those six agencies. Now I would like to take a closer look at two of them which will certainly have a significant impact on human rights, the area for which I am the critic for this party. The first agency is the Law Reform Commission.
Established in 1971, one of the commission's mandates was to maintain an ongoing review of the Statutes of Canada, to make recommendations for improvement, modernization and reform legislation. In its almost 22 year existence, the commission issued 32 reports, 61 working papers and 76 studies containing recommendations covering Criminal Code reform; hate propaganda, plea bargaining, safeguarding of genetic heritage, pornography, euthanasia, sexual assault, arson, mental disorder and on and on. As of 1990, the commission's studies have been cited in 211 reported Canadian court decisions, 39 of which were Supreme Court of Canada decisions. Yet, this government thinks this commission is so unimportant that it is getting rid of it.
This commission has played a vital role in the advancement of human rights in Canada. All of the issues I have just mentioned are matters of considerable importance today and most will, without a doubt, be debated in greater detail in the coming years.
The commission is an important element of the public policy process on which our laws are based. Indeed, a claim to a human right is very often advanced as a justification for public policy.
Often, as we can see by the aforementioned matters the commission has addressed, certain issues are controversial and the government must seek the advice and counsel of non-partisan bodies which can evaluate the given matter without political interference. By abolishing the non-partisan commission, the Conservative government and, in particular, the current Minister of Justice

Government Orders
are trying to silence their biggest critic. The minister has been endeavouring to do so since 1990. At that time she left the commission without a quorum. This made it impossible for the commission to approve any reports which would have included suggested changes to federal legislation.
The second organization being closed by the legislation that I want to talk about today in the context of its effect on human rights is the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. Established in 1984, CUPS mandate is to increase knowledge and understanding of the issues relating to international peace and security from a Canadian perspective with particular emphasis on arms control, disarmament, defence and conflict resolution. In today's ever-changing global environment, what could be more important than these issues?
I have sat in this House on several occasions and listened to the Prime Minister and his colleagues in the Conservative Party talk at great length about the need to make every effort to bring about a more peaceful world for our children and our children's children. Wonderful words. Unfortunately this government is high on words but low on action.
We are standing here today to debate an issue which should not even be on the agenda for debate. We have an Institute for International Peace and Security and this government is saying: "No, we do not need that". By voting to abolish CUPS, this government is saying that we do not need an institute which will increase knowledge and promote understanding of issues relating to international peace and security.
By voting to axe CUPS, this government is sending a clear message to Canadians that it is not committed to limiting the out of control arms trade. This morning's Ottawa Citizen outlined just how out of control the arms trade has become, detailing the role that Canada played in the arming of Iraq in the years prior to the gulf war. In fact, this government allowed a company supplying munitions to Iraq to test artillery and special shells at Canadian military bases just months before Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait.
By voting to abolish CUPS, this government is saying that we do not need an institute dedicated to discussing
issues which could ameliorate the deplorable crisis we are witnessing in Yugoslavia. East Timor, Somalia, Sri Lanka, Mozambique, Liberia, Cambodia, China, Burma, Iraq, Iran and the list goes on and on. By voting to do away with CUPS this government is acknowledging that it lacks a real commitment to doing its part for a more peaceful world.
In conclusion, this bill is not about saving the government some money. If it really wanted to do this, it could take steps to implement some of the recommendations of the Auditor General. We all know that there are more than a few. Bill C-63 is not about fiscal restraint, it is about abolishing agencies which have always acted in the interest of Canadians. This government is embarrassed by these agencies because it does not always do the same. Rather than debating the issues this government has chosen to kill the messenger. It may be easier but in the end we all suffer because of the loss.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, we are debating Bill C-63 but, as my colleague mentioned a little earlier, all of the agencies have been closed since June 1992. One would ask, what is the point of a member of Parliament standing up in the House to defend an agency that is no longer in existence. The doors have been closed. In some cases the telephones do not even exist. They have been disconnected.
I was wondering what the fairness is when we have a situation like that. Legislation is introduced and even before the legislation is passed action has already been taken. It is quite intriguing. Our role as members of Parliament has been minimized if not ignored in this case.
The organizations that the government in its wisdom decided to close down are the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Economic Council of Canada, the International Centre for Ocean Development, the Law Reform Commission, and the Science Council of Canada. All six agencies have in the past provided government, as well as interested groups, with great third party opinion that was not influenced by government or special interest groups. Most of those opinions come from experts, from people who know and who are willing to listen to both sides before they make their recommendations.
November 26, 1992

To shut down these organizations for the mere sake of saving $22 million when we are losing this excellent advice and are laying off in excess of 300 employees is a shame.
Just recently the NDP government in Ontario dedicated close to $1 billion in the hope of creating up to
100,000	jobs. I was informed about a week ago that after it spent in excess of about $20 million it was able to create only 200 jobs.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: They need advice, don't they.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
The NDP does not listen. That is its problem.
There are people who are trying to create jobs but they do not know how to do it because of lack of experience and lack of talent. However, there are already agencies in place that have been doing a great job in providing a tremendous amount of service and support to the government and to people at large, yet we are closing them down.
What has intrigued me the most is the closure of the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security. This institute was established in 1984 with one thing in mind, to provide that third perspective or advice.
To close it down in the time we are in is really shameful. It is inappropriate and it is veiy ill-timed. All we have to do is look at countries around the world, look at the former Soviet Union, look at the disintegration of Yugoslavia, look at what is happening in Somalia, look at what is happening in certain parts of the Middle East, look at what is happening pretty well in every part of the world.
If anything, what we should have done is enhance the role of this institute, and encourage it to go even further and try to deal with world disputes and find resolutions to those issues and those disputes.
We have seen a tremendous amount of pressure coming toward Canada on the international scene and international community. There is more and more demand for our peacekeeping forces. There is more pressure on external affairs. There is more pressure on the minister herself.
The world views us as being in the best position to provide neutral advice, advice that is well balanced and moderate. As Canadians, this is something that we
Government Orders
should be very proud of. Canadians should be proud of the fact that the whole world is listening to us as a middle of the road power. Canada is not a big power and not a small power but a mid-sized power. We are in the best position to provide leadership, ideas and suggestions to countries where there are problems and disputes.
I thought this particular agency would have been one of the tools that the government could have used and could have promoted world-wide to help solve some of these problems. I say this because when people look at Canada from the outside they see a Canada that is compassionate, caring and willing to help. I do not think we should take that for granted, nor should we ignore the fact that it is one of the best assets we have.
Our image is one of our best assets, not only to the outside world but to the inside world. The outside world looks at Canada with an admiring eye and the inside world, from time to time, wonders about the wisdom of our government when it comes to institutions such as this one. We wonder why the government is closing it.
It is my hope that the government will see the wisdom and reinstate some of these agencies. If it were up to me I would reinstate all of them. However, it looks like the rest of the agencies, with the exception of the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, have given in. They have decided that it is time to close down.
I want to commend those people who are answering the telephone at CUPS. Obviously they have decided to stay there until the bill goes through the House of Commons and the Senate.
It is my hope that we will have an election before the Senate approves those bills. It is my hope that my party, in which I am confident, will have a second look at those agencies and try to inject life into some of them to ensure that Canadians who have been accustomed to the quality services of those agencies will continue to receive them.
What has also particularly intrigued me is the situation of the Science Council of Canada and the Economic Council of Canada. What a couple of organizations. We can see the correlation between the two: science and the economy. We cannot just divide the two because when we think about it if there is any one single tool that is necessary to succeed it is the educational tool. Unfortunately we do not have it right now. Our work force is not fully equipped to produce the kind of wealth that we are interested in.

November 26, 1992
Government Orders
First, on the international scene we are not scoring as high as we should in terms of productivity. Second, the production of our universities, schools and so on compared to the production of other schools and universities around the world is not as good as it should be. We do not seem to be scoring high in terms of the quality of education our graduates are receiving.
The same is true when it comes to applying those degrees in the work force. We do not see the output that we should be seeing, and that is not the fault of the student. The student will learn what is taught in the curriculum. That is a fault of the system. We must have a system that encourages, creates and graduates the kind of students who are willing and capable of being fully productive in society.
Not only that, we must give them the tools to do so. That is why I would have hoped that rather than closing them down the government would put more emphasis on agencies such as the Science Council and the Economic Council.
I do not think members will disagree that unless something is done with our educational system over the next few months we are going to see ourselves lagging behind the rest of the world.
I am amazed, and it does not matter which chart I look at, that when we compare ourselves to the big G-7 countries we seem to always be hitting the bottom, whether we look at productivity, investment in research and development, our level of output in terms of students who go into high school, or the level of literacy. No matter how you slice it or look at it we seem to have a problem.
The solution is extremely simple. We should, and we must, have a national standard for education all across the board. We should and we must work with the industries a little more closely than we have been doing in the past. More important, we must listen to advice, which is what the Science Council and the Economic Council were doing in the past. They were trying to provide that third party advice to the government, which the government did not seem to be listening to.
We have to go to industry and listen to it to see what it wants us to do with the government rather than trying to
complicate the tax system, increase the red tape, and trying to drive industry away from provinces such as Ontario. When it comes to attracting industry from the outside we seem to be scaring it off so it is not coming in.
The savings that the government is getting in the short-run are going to cost us in the long-run.
That is why I would like to join with my colleagues in calling on the government to have a second look at these agencies, in particular agencies that have provided quality service in the past. I do not see why the Law Reform Commission has to be shut down. I do not see why the government has to close down the Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council when we are accepting, on an annual basis, in excess of 250,000 immigrants to this country and when there is a shortage of public servants.
Today I was at a rally of public servants from Employment and Immigration. I heard, over and over again, that they need more staff. They need more resources if they are to deal with and support the level of immigration that we have.
The International Centre for Ocean Development, the Law Reform Commission, the Science Council of Canada, the Economic Council of Canada, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, all these agencies are fine, fine agencies. I wish and hope that the government will listen to the opposition and reconsider its position.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am delighted to rise in the House to discuss this particular bill.
I want to be as objective as I can. I want to address the issues honestly and directly. This is a bill about dismantling many research facilities that are available to government today. They are research and development facilities and ones that give expert advice on a host of issues.
The government ought to realize that there is some contradiction here. First, the government talks about competitiveness, it talks about increasing productivity. It has the tools at its disposal to help it do that. I shall try to prove that case. What does the government do? It decides to dismantle these essential organizations.
November 26, 1992

Why would the government attempt to do this when this is the situation that we in Canada face today. I said earlier in the House that some of our greatest challenges were the social problems facing us. Yes, there are political problems and economic problems, but the social problems are Canada's greatest challenges.
There are over 1.6 million unemployed Canadians as we speak. There are in this country more than 2.2 million Canadians who will be receiving social assistance this year. There are over 2 million Canadians, 40 per cent of whom are young people or children, who are going to be nourished at food banks this year. There are close to 5 million Canadians who are at the level of poverty or living in poverty. There is abuse in our country that needs to be investigated so that we can come up with policies that will reduce this kind of situation, which is completely unacceptable to countries such as Canada.
We have problems of aging and I do not say that in the pejorative sense. We have a population that is growing older which will necessitate different solutions in the future. We have environmental challenges-and we could be a leader if we chose to be-that are virtually insurmountable if we do not have these tools working for us.
My colleagues have mentioned the role we have in peacemaking. We have been, perhaps continue to be, but certainly should aspire to be, first in the world to be involved in peacemaking around the planet.
Just in case people are not completely aware of some of these organizations and what they do, I want to quote from some government papers. The Canada Employment and Immigration Advisory Council is an advisory board to the employment and immigration minister. It provides the minister with advice from those affected by the department's policies and activities. Surely that is important. It acts as an independent institution. Surely this is extremely important.
Let me share with you some of the things that the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security is intended to do, that it will no longer be able to do. Here is part of its mandate: To increase knowledge and understanding of the issues relating to international peace and security from a Canadian perspective. It undertakes research in order to assist in peacemaking.
Government Orders
Let us look at the International Centre for Ocean Development. This organization's prime objective was to improve the management and utilization of ocean resources as a source of food for those nations that do not have enough food to nourish their people.
Another organization, the Law Reform Commission, has a bit of a stuffy title but it did have an important mandate. It was going to make recommendations for improvement, modernization and reform of legislation. It undertook research in order to assist.
Let us look at the mandate of the Science Council of Canada. It was to assess scientific and technological resources, requirements and potentialities of Canada and increase public awareness of scientific and technological problems and opportunities. It undertook research, published studies, reports and provided advice to the minister.
Let me deal with the final one, the Economic Council of Canada. What was its mandate? It was to achieve the highest possible levels of employment and efficient production in order that the country may enjoy a high and consistent rate of economic growth, that all Canadians may share and have rising living standards. It undertook research. It was a departmental corporation operating at arm's length from ministers to provide independent advice to the minister.
Every single one of those organizations I have mentioned provided expert advice and research so the government could do a better job.
When I look at what the Economic Council of Canada produced in this booklet which is called: A New Face of Poverty I can understand why a government might be loathe to continue to support it because it gets to the root of a problem when it examines the face of poverty in Canada.
I mentioned just a few moments ago that we have close to five million people living at or below the poverty level, over one million of those are children, the vast majority of whom are women. Let us look at this booklet and give a couple of examples of some of the things they say that might in fact make governments shudder a little bit: "Unemployment insurance does not serve the needs of some of the unemployed. Good jobs have become difficult to find, creating economic difficulties", and it goes on to talk about economic stress and what have you.

November 26, 1992
Government Orders
I can understand why governments would be nervous about that kind of advice. On the other hand, if we are committed to tiy to improve the human condition, if we want to wrestle our problems to the ground, to make Canada a better country, surely we should not shy away from hearing the truth from experts who have worked long and hard in trying to determine what it is that needs to be done.
What are the reasons for dismantling these organizations? We have heard about the economic reasons. We know they are not true. Of course there will be some savings in a way, but if we look at the losses as a result of the dismantling, what are the real savings? No one has come up with that figure. Savings are not the real reason. That is a smoke screen. That is to camouflage the dismantling. That is simply to try to find an excuse to explain it in away to Canadians.
We know that some $20 million is a lot of money. I do not want to minimize that. But I suspect that $20 million could be saved by reducing the size of cabinet. Let us start with cabinet and some of the perks that its members get.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext: Get rid of those Tories.

subtopic: AN ACT TO DISSOLVE OR TERMINATE CERTAIN CORPORATIONS AND OTHER BODIES MEASURE TO ENACT
speechtext:
We could reduce the size of the ministerial staff and save much more than $20 million. We could cut down on the polling and government advertising and already we have saved several millions more. If the intent was to save $20 million, there were some targets which were much more appropriate that would have been much more acceptable to Canadians and would have been much more honest.
Saving money, no, but government is attempting to get closer to this reform agenda. Why? Because it has noticed that the reformers are in fact crowding into its boat. What do you do? You adopt some of their stances, some of their policies or you get as close to them as possible without getting burned.
There is a lesson to be learned here by government members and by the people of Canada. This kind of cutting, this kind of slashing without regard for the human condition, for the workers who were there, without looking at the real cost that is going to be incurred because of the lost research and the lost expert advice, just looking at the superficial $20 million is what the Reform Party would do. That is what it is all about. It is skimming the surface. It is taking complex problems
and giving simple little solutions in 30 seconds or shorter clips. That is exactly what it is all about.
Let me tell you another reason why there is dismantling here. You will recall that the government cut down the civil service. When I ask how much money was spent on contracts because some of that work still had to be done, lo and behold, there were no records. I must confess, I find that surprising.
There is deep suspicion that there is even more money being spent today than before those civil service cuts took place. Where has the money gone? Where has your money, my money, my colleague's money and other Canadians' money gone? I suspect that it has gone to private firms and to private agencies.
What is going to happen over here? We know full well the governments, no matter their political stripe, will need to continue to have expert advice. We know full well that the money that was supposedly saved will be going to corporations, firms and friends of government. I am going to be watching closely and my friends will as well.
If that is what happens, then it is hypocrisy of the highest kind. I see a similarity between these reductions here and the reductions that took place in the civil service.

They cut organizations. It could be said of most of the people involved who know the problems and were trying to solve them that they did an excellent, thorough, enlightened job that helped us parliamentarians look as objectively as possible at our society's problems and come up with much more flexible, sensitive solutions.
Why did they do it? It was not to save money. It was mainly to make Canadians believe that they were reducing the size of government and trying to cut government spending. But, as I already said, that is not the case. They are just shifting some expense items around. I am willing to bet that this money will be spent somewhere else as they did with the Public Service. Admittedly some positions were abolished, but the work was contracted out. I would really like to have the answer to this question. I would bet a year's salary for a doughnut that the government spends more now than it would have spent if it had kept those positions.

It looks good to some people. Some people have accepted this government propaganda, and I find that unfortunate. As I said a little while ago, if the government really wanted to save, there are advertising budgets and all sorts of surveys ordered by the government that could have been cancelled and they would have saved much more.

I am willing to have my colleagues from the other side ask me all kinds of questions and challenge everything I have said. I encourage them to do so. What I would like to propose is that the government consider setting up a third party blue ribbon committee of outstanding men and women who will look at this government decision and who will determine whether or not these agencies were in fact providing useful services for what it was costing Canadians. Surely that should not be too difficult to do.

What I would like-and I will say it in both official languages to be sure that I am well understood-is for the government to promise to set up a veiy credible committee of men and women from all across Canada to review the government's decisions and tell the Canadian Parliament whether or not it was a good and wise decision.

Surely that is not too threatening.
In closing I would hope that my colleagues would be sufficiently shocked by what I have said, because they are all supporting this bill, that they would rise in their place and ask profound questions of me to see whether or not Canadians believe what I have said or what it is that they say, or what it is that they propose to do.

speechtext:
They are ashamed and they should be ashamed because the bill is doing untold damage to the fabric of our country. One of the extraordinary things about the government-I know the hon. member for St. Boniface, who has a particular interest in this subject will know this-has been their alleged enthusiasm for research and development. The Economic Council of Canada did a great deal of research and development. The Science Council of Canada helped foster research and development. The Law Reform Commission did all kinds of work to assist in legal research in Canada and help our country develop

November 26, 1992
Government Orders
new laws. Indeed, the Law Reform Commission, as I indicated in my speech yesterday, was in fact very highly regarded by foreign law reform commissions that carried on similar work in their own countries.
We had an outstanding organization the government is now throwing out with the stroke of a pen with this bill. The shocking feature of the whole thing is it has done it without waiting for the bill to pass. In other words, we have become a rubber stamp for government action that followed on the budget. It is scrapping all these organizations and all but one of them does not even have a telephone line any more. The government has just decided to let them have it and has given them the old boot the chop. This is what it has done in a most undemocratic and irresponsible way.
It is fine to plead this is an attempt to save money. We all recognize Tory times are hard times and we have to save money. We do not have to go about giving these organizations the heave-ho without a very careful look at how much we are actually saving. What is the record? The government announced in the budget it was closing down 46 agencies and corporations at a saving of $10 million? As my hon. friend from Halifax West knows, it is peanuts for the number of agencies being closed down.
We should look at the total cost for the agencies. For example, the total projected savings for the Economic Council of Canada was something like $22 million a year. Half of it could be saved on the Economic Council alone. Add up the others. There is something wrong.
The government has moved a whole lot of the work these agencies were doing into other organizations. I do not know this for a fact, but I can only speculate they have moved them in so they can shift these responsibilities to government departments where they can be under the thumb of a minister. You know how they like to put the thumb to them and make sure their reports comply with the minister's wishes. Instead of independent and valid reports that reflect reality, the government wants something that backs up the minister's view of reality. That is what the government is after. I think that is what it is trying to do in this case. It is transferring the
responsibility from an independent arm's length agency to a government department where it can put the screws to people if they do not come up with the report the government wants.
If a report is unsatisfactory in a government department, we know what happens. It gets buried. It never sees the light of day. The minister does not release it. An independent agency releases its reports and the public gets to read them and understand what is really going on. So it was with the Economic Council, the Law Reform Commission and the Science Council. All these bodies had the right to release their own reports.
Yesterday in the House one of the members of the New Democratic Party, the hon. member for Skeena, was making a speech and got a bit carried away. He referred to the cabinet in less than flattering terms. He spoke about their educational qualifications in a general way that was not polite or accurate. Understandably the government House leader, a Ph.D., the hon. member for Calgary South I think it is, came into the house and listed some of the outstanding qualifications of some of his cabinet colleagues. We were very pleased to see that. It was an enjoyable speech. It is unfortunate he is not here tonight to participate in the debate because he would enjoy it if he were. We would enjoy it.
As he knows, he was provoked into action last night. I see, Madam Speaker, you are threatening to wring my neck.

speechtext:
I would be happy to see any one, but of course if the government House leader were here in particular, I would be thrilled. He is an outstanding debater. He has a Ph.D. He is much better qualified than I am to speak on subjects like the Science Council of Canada. My degrees are not in sciences. They are in the humanities and social sciences perhaps, but not in the very distinguished and stratified atmosphere of a Ph. D. like the government House leader.
I see my colleague, the hon. member for Edmonton- Strathcona is now getting a bit overwrought. I urge him to control himself. If he would like to make a speech or ask me a question at the conclusion of my address, I would be more than happy to hear from him.
What I wanted to say is we had the government House leader come last evening and tell us about how some of his cabinet colleagues were particularly well qualified to deal with these issues. The issue he did not address in his speech that sort of surprised me, was the fact all these people with Ph.Ds. and qualifications in science and engineering were abandoning the Science Council of Canada willy-nilly.
You would think if they had all this expertise in the cabinet and knew about these things they would say: "Well, we are grateful to have somebody like the Science Council of Canada give some independent advice on which way we should go".
But no. I guess they figured they had enough of them in the cabinet that they could make up their own minds. Yet all of these cabinet ministers have made speeches supporting R and D. I remember hearing the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology at a meeting of the Royal Society of Canada a couple of years ago at a conference. He made a speech saying how Canada was so short on research and development, how we had to get more government funding for research and development. Research and development was absolutely essential for the continued growth of Canada and our economic development.
Government Orders
Yet here we have the government giving the chop to organizations that fostered and sponsored research and development in Canada. There is no sense to its arguments. There is no sense to its rhetoric. There is no sense to its logic. It says one thing one day and does something else the next.
This government is frankly a disgrace. It has failed to address the issues that confront Canada. I would like to turn briefly to its economic record, which explains why we are going through these painful chops.
The government came into power in 1984. It is getting so long ago now it is hard to imagine. You would think it was yesterday from the way it complains. It's big theme was it was going to solve Canada's problems. It had all the answers. It was going to solve the deficit. It said the deficit was Canada's number one problem of 1984. It is still Canada's number one problem but not because it was in 1984. It is because the government has doubled the debt in the meantime and increased the payments so much. It has become a problem that is almost beyond solving thanks to the incompetent management we have witnessed from the government opposite for the last eight years.
Yet every time we ask a question in the House today in 1992, the same answer is given as was given in 1988 and the same one I know was given from my reading in 1984. That was, if we had not inherited this huge debt from the Liberals, we would not be in this pickle today. It is in the pickle today and it is not because of what happened eight or ten years ago. It is what happened over the last eight years. In every single one of them, the deficit has been enormous because of the government's mismanagement of the economic affairs of this country.
Now the government is getting rid of one of the principal organs of advice it had to give it advice, and that is the Economic Council of Canada.
The Science Council of Canada throughout its 15 year history did all kinds of things for this country. Let me read a brief list of its accomplishments. It recommended the creation of a Canadian space agency. It urged Canadians to recycle. It published reports on sustainable agriculture, water supply, biotechnology and technology for cold regions. These are just a few of the outstanding areas in which they moved to provide leadership for Canada.

November 26, 1992
Government Orders
The Economic Council of Canada is well known for its annual review, which focused on one of the problems confronting the economy.
A few years ago I recall the review-I have forgotten the title of it-that dealt with the problems of the deficit and national debt in Canada. Legacies, I believe was its name when I come to think of it. Perhaps Your Honour read it. It talked about the evils of the deficit and the debt, how large it was and how it was making it increasingly difficult for Canadian governments in future to provide for the necessary services and policy options that should be available to any government in this country. It spoke about the need for bringing the deficit under control. The study fitted in entirely with the government's avowed intention.
However, what it said was one thing and what it did was quite another. Deficit control has remained at the bottom of this government's list of priorities. It keeps announcing these little chops. I think it has announced that it will save $22 million a year on this deal, but where has it been spent? It has all been spent already. Every cut that was announced in the budget last February and all the savings that resulted from those cuts have been re-spent. It is all in the supplementary estimates that were tabled in the House of Commons this week.
You know that, Madam Speaker. I know that and the hon. members opposite who are left know that, even if they do not have a cabinet minister here to tell them about it. They know perfectly well that is what has happened. All the money has been spent recklessly because they have failed to manage the economic affairs of Canada properly.
I could go on at great length. I know I do not have the same time restrictions that I suffered from last night. I must say the first eight minutes of my speech went terribly quickly and I found that I was running out of time. However, tonight with the additional time of the 20-minute speech I have the option of speaking a little more slowly and enjoying the comments of my colleagues opposite a bit more.
The Science Council, the Law Reform Commission, the International Centre for Ocean Development, the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security, the Canadian Employment and Immigration Advisory
Council, and the Economic Council of Canada all have contributed to this country over the years.

As my hon. friend from Ottawa Centre says: "Tremendously" and now we are to say good-bye to all these organizations.
We put before the House a series of amendments to this bill yesterday. There were 50 or 60 amendments. This morning the government and its backbenchers, all its supporters in this House, voted against everyone quite mindlessly. There was no explanation tendered as to why these amendments were unacceptable. Some of them were quite good, but they just sat there and voted them down one after another, obviously they were quite unthinking and very much uncaring.
Some of the amendments deleted the inappropriate sections of this bill and every single one was voted down. I regret that the government has shown a complete unwillingness to show any flexibility in this case. It has clearly shown a lack of compassion in dealing with the importance of these issues for Canadians.
There is one reason for introducing a bill of this Draconian nature, and that is because it has allowed the deficit to get out of control and it is trying to save it. For $22 million, the government is getting rid of organizations that are costing a good deal more.
As I said at the outset of my remarks, it is attempting to move the work those organizations are doing into government departments where it can control the work and control the result. It is regressive. It is unfair. The government should be ashamed of itself for proceeding in that way.
I would only hope, even at this late date, the members opposite who have the opportunity would cast their votes against this government or absent themselves from the vote on Monday night if they had any sense. I say to them: "If you cannot vote against the bill, go out of town and stay out of town, stay away from the vote and maybe we will be able to solve this problem by defeating this bill and putting it in the trash-can where it should be".
That is the position of our party. I am pleased we have been able to rise and participate all day in this debate. We have frankly carried the debate. We have had no assistance from the New Democratic Party either.
November 26, 1992
