speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I wish to give notice that I will raise a question of privilege or a point of order tomorrow concerning an oversight, and I am sure it was not more than that. I spoke last night and my speech was attributed to another member. Perhaps it was because I bored some of my listeners. As usual, I talked about Israel and Palestine, very briefly, but I have been thinking about this since this morning. I do not want to bore the people who listened to us last night, or the members who are still in the House, by repeating what I said yesterday.
I am sure thousands of Canadians, and especially young Canadians agree with me. I do not like cut and dried speeches that put the blame squarely on the other side's doorstep, but what I really do not like is this government's decision to dissolve the peace institute we created in 1984.
Perhaps I may recall-since last night it seems some people did not realize this-that the Right Hon. Pierre Elliott Trudeau had launched a peace initiative in 1984. Subsequently a bill was tabled by the Hon. Allan MacEa-chen, minister of external affairs, to create an institute that, as you all know, examined these very important issues. The external affairs committee, which I had the honour to chair at the time was then called the Standing Committee on External Affairs and National Defence. The fact that both departments were handled by the same committee had always been a bone of contention. I say this as an additional bit of information for our listeners. In fact I received a lot of calls since last night about the short speech I made on this very important subject. We can talk about the economy, but if there is no peace, if the whole world is in a turmoil, the economy
Government Orders
may be important but we still have to provide a solid foundation and that foundation consists of peace, international understanding, and so forth.
In 1984 it was agreed we could establish an institute. Unfortunately the Trudeau era, as they say, was drawing to a close and we were racing against the clock I am doing this from memory. I did not want to speak this evening but when I saw last night's mistake I decided to join in the debate again. In April 1984 there was second reading of the bill standing in the name of Mr. Allan MacEachen, whose is now a senator and was at one time leader in the Senate. After second reading, as we say here, the bill was referred to the Standing Committee on External Affairs and National Defence. Last night I paid tribute to Mr. Stan Darling, who had always been a pillar of this committee, often at odds with his party colleagues.
At this point, perhaps I may mention that it was important to have the committee covering both external affairs and national defence. However, the Conservatives who are now in the government, had always wanted to separate them. Perhaps I should explain why I was against separation. It is quite simple. I think it is very sad when we see members who specialize exclusively in peace issues and foreign affairs, while other members concentrate only on national defence, without any dialogue between the two.
Some members say: "Oh, it is like social affairs. We will appoint all the women MPs to social affairs. For issues like foreign aid, we will appoint the good souls in Parliament. For national defence we will appoint the tough guys".
Personally I always combined the so-called tough guys with people who had some sense of internationalism and the two groups had to listen to each other. People who believed only in defence, defence and attack, had to listen a bit to the concerns of Third World countries which were represented by another group of members.
The external affairs committee had to race against the clock, because several members did all they could to sabotage the Institute from that time; they said it was a gift the Liberals wanted to give when Mr. Trudeau left office. At that time he had already announced that he was going. I was the poor chairman, caught between my colleagues, national defence types and people whose

Government Orders
main concern was external affairs and foreign aid. I had to make my way through that and I made everyone work day and night. That is how we got it. I reported to Parliament on June 27, 1984. Imagine, Parliament was dissolved. The Trudeau era ended on June 29, 1984 and I reported it to the House for approval on June 27, 1984.1 explained it last night but I will repeat it. Some say that for the first time in Mr. Trudeau's life he said what he thought of me. He said that it was thanks to the committee chairman's patience that we had the peace institute. I was away from the House because I was busy on the telephone solving an immigration problem for someone who had been denied entry to Canada; there was a big international conference on the Middle East in Montreal.
To get to the heart of the matter and not take too much of the House's time before we vote, I must say now that it is regrettable. This institute had 40 employees and a budget of $5 million. The first director general, a great diplomat, was the son of former Prime Minister Pearson. It was all peace people who had an idea of international security. For $5 million, we got a tremendous reputation throughout the world.

I will repeat and repeat for the young people sitting in this House and those listening the word Canada is too important in the world. The world talks about us in terms that Canadians sometimes do not even use and I regret it. I regret it in both languages. We are more popular outside Canada. I do not understand why Canadians do not realize and do not take more pride in this great country. We are perceived in the world as a country where, at the end of the day, we always find a solution between French Canadians, of which I am one, and English Canadians, which some others are, between the first citizens of this land and between the new Canadians who are now helping to shape this country. The rest of the world looks at us and says: "If Canada can succeed with all the young people of various origins living harmoniously together, there must be something special in that country".
The peace and security institute was an element of that, studying what goes wrong in the world. Imagine. It brought together here in Ottawa, as I said last night, people with a devotion for the survival of the state of Israel with people who are Palestinian-what a dangerous word in North America, a word I am familiar with. That was the kind of role the peace institute played, to bring these people together in a forum, in a debate, in a weekend discussion so that we could find a solution in order to live on a more harmonious planet. That was part of the role of the Canadian Institute for International Peace and Security.
On top of that, the board of directors had to be approved by various leaders and rightly so. It was not a packed political patronage or what have you. Names had to be submitted for acceptance to sit on the board and foreigners could sit on the board. It is quite exciting that foreigners could sit on the board. All that for $5 million.
Every modem country in the world has pride in that kind of an institute for many reasons. Canada had that institute. Knowing Mr. Trudeau, and let us say I have known him since I was 17 years old. I sat here with him for 20 years. I know he was so proud of that institute that brought together such a variety of people with various opinions.
As I said last night, and I repeat, it is regrettable. I do not want to attack because it solves nothing, but it is regrettable that we do not make the nuance between what is essential, what is the pride, what creates pride in young people to make them understand how complicated the planet is.
For those who believe that the world is all right now, think of the Soviet Union which I knew by heart. It has fallen. Now we have a new world order. Do not count on me to be applauding too much because I am afraid more of one dictatorship as benevolent and as friendly as the United States of America may be-and I am a friend of the United States and its citizens-but it is not healthy that there is only one dominant master in the world.
November 26, 1992

The peace and security institute was about to study all these matters. Those who are ready to go to sleep and to say that at long last we can sleep in peace because communism has fallen, as I said last night, I have news for them all.
This planet is more dangerous maybe than ever before because the death of communism has opened something unbelievable. It has opened all kinds of nationalism, confronting each other with hate and passion and producing what we see every night on television, the horror we see under the new world order. We have to study very carefully these new movements, these millions and millions of people who will not remain in their countries.
Canada may look like a do-gooder. We do not have major problems. We do not have many boundaries. We have two oceans. We have the north. We have the United States that can always be a buffer.
However think of Europe, think if you were a 19-year old Ukrainian or Polish person, or of any of the eastern countries, you would take your chances and go to Europe. The worst that could happen to you is that you would be shipped back. But that means the frontier. Now the problem of the frontier in Europe is very dangerous. Look at what is going on in the Balkans. That is exactly what the peace and security institute at times was studying.
Graciously organized parliamentary organizations came here. I will produce a report next week on parliamentary associations if the management and members' services committee does not produce it. The time has come to say what this is all about and the importance of parliamentary associations.
We worked closely with the peace institute. Members of Parliament of Canada are not provincial members. They have to have international preoccupation, but in order to have an international preoccupation. There must be a variety of informants or a variety of sources. Yes, you could count on the very devoted people at external affairs to inform you. But this kind of institute is also an extraordinarily good source of independent thinking. The sadness is that sometimes we say we will deregulate, that we will privatize everything because it looks good. It looks politically rentable. I do not know
Government Orders
how you translate rentable. Can anyone here say that quickly for me?

It pays politically.

It pays to look like you are for privatization but to talk about transportation, you are for privatization, of course. For those whose philosophy is anchored in one word, it looks good to have abolished all these institutes and everything else that my colleague spoke of tonight, and very more ably than 1.1 see them all here. They all spoke about that. Other members of other parties spoke about the dismantling of all these institutes.
Personally I want to be on record to say as strongly as possible, without the slightest partisanship attached to my comments, that we will live to regret the dismantling of the Institute for International Peace and Security. My colleagues across the aisle understand that it takes years to build something and before its reputation spreads around the world. Scholars of the world were talking about this peace institute of Canada, as were military minded people and the experts in defence, experts in security and experts in internationalization of conflict. We are talking about the peace institute.
Madam Speaker, you have great experience in these matters. I must say that you are a great credit to Canada. You represent our country, some macho would say with charm, but I would say not only with elegance but with knowledge. You do honour to Canada when you go abroad. We do not have to be scared by the press or other people who think that when members travel, it is a travelling agency. It is important because we are interrelated in this world, on this planet. We must know what is going on around the world before we vote for fisheries and wheat. We are inter-related not only in this country but in the world.
The Institute for International Peace and Security was about to become a jewel in something Canada has always done well in. Many other countries were glad and even envious to see that a country could take such initiatives. How could you expect an old parliamentarian like me not to say openly how sorry he is.

Government Orders
Come next election I assure you, as I said last night, if thanks to God-and God may be a woman-I am re-elected I will try to convince the new government of the day that it may have been a fatal mistake and we should reinstitute the institute. I see a lot of good in this institute on a troubled planet.

Young people must understand that Canada is for me perhaps one of the last beacons of hope for humanity in difficulty, where we can find solutions together while respecting our differences.

The peace institute was always studying and teaching all of those who came to study at the institute that you cannot have peace, you cannot have a harmonious world if you do not accept and respect the differences that exist in each one's country.
Canada has shown the way, and suddenly, sadly, for all kinds of reasons, we have disbanded the institute. I want to be on record as saying that I profoundly regret it.
